PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, those costs need to be shared equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
Take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 63 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 202 citizens), Mr N.A. Brown (from 63 citizens), Mr Ewen Cameron (from 65 citizens), Mr Chynoweth (from 492 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 405 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 110 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 416 citizens), Mr Duffy (from 48 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 40 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 12 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 36 citizens), Mr Millar (from 312 citizens), Mr Milton (from 110 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 239 citizens), Mr Snow (from 149 citizens), Mr Webster (from 58 citizens) and Mr White (from 85 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEDDALL; GRIFFITHS; HARVEY; HOWARD; JOHNS; MILES; MOORE
PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Pornography in Videos, Films and Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into Television Standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television Standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall (from 63 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 19 citizens), Ms Harvey (from 44 citizens), Mr Howard (from 20 citizens), Mr Johns (from 20 citizens), Mr Miles (from eight citizens), and Mr Moore (from 16 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell (from 81 citizens), Mr McArthur (from 27 citizens), Mr O'Neil (from 297 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 27 citizens), Mr Reith (from 21 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Katter (from 88 citizens), Mr Kent (from 36 citizens) and Mr White (from 1,048 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chynoweth (from 57 citizens) and Mr Langmore (from 200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms McHugh (from 882 citizens) and Mr John Scott (from 47 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Producers: Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned endorse the actions of Graeme Campbell, MP, in pursuing his stance against removing company tax exemptions for gold producers. We further commend the work of the Western Australian Government to have the Federal Government's decision on gold tax reversed.

Unlike the assistance provided to Australian manufacturing industry, the taxation arrangement applying to gold is transparent and therefore an easy target. Moreover, because of the concentration of the industry in remote areas of Western Australia, far from Canberra, the legitimate voice of the industry is drowned out by special interest groups close to the capital.

The proposed change to the gold taxation regime has already produced substantial distortions in exploration drilling activity and development plans of gold mines. Exploration drilling has declined and there is a real risk that some mines could begin the high grading of their orebodies which will shorten the life of the mine.
The Western Australian Government has strongly opposed the proposed tax changes because of these distorting effects.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ranjeet and Parmjeet Heer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned showeth:
We are gravely concerned about the future of Ramanjeet and Kamaljeet Heer following the deportation of their parents Ranjeet and Parmjeet Heer to India.

Your petitioners therefore pray that Ranjeet and Parmjeet Heer be found and returned to Australia immediately and that they be totally exempt from the conditions set down by the Australian Department of Immigration.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Parliament require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation relation to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax File Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament
The petition of certain citizens of Australia who draw to the attention of the House that:

1. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory in February by sending an admitted 55,000 to 77,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.

2. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations to the citizens of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in March by sending an admitted 29,000 to 58,000 tax file number letters to people who were either deceased or had changed address.
3. The Australian Taxation Office disregarded its privacy obligations by sending out a large number of tax file number letters during March in unsealed envelopes.

4. The Australian Taxation Office extended the deadline for employee declarations beyond the 31st March as defined by section 202C (4) (a) of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988 but failed to obtain a Proclamation from the Governor-General for this extension as stipulated by section 202C (4) (b) of the Act.

5. The Australian Taxation Office, in its implementation of the tax file number system, has failed to abide by the provisions of both the Privacy Act 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act 1988.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to refer the matter to the Finance and Public Administration Committee of the House of Representatives for purposes of an investigation into the administration of the tax file number related legislation by the Taxation Office and the role of the Taxation Commissioner in the above mentioned administration.

PETITION.TITLE: Lebanon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of residents of the State of Victoria draw to the attention of the House of Representatives the horrific loss of life and suffering of the people of the Lebanon due to the foreign invasion.
We ask the member of Parliament to raise, in the appropriate political forums, including the United Nations, the following:
1. An immediate cease fire in Lebanon.
2. U.N. assistance in bringing about a resolution of hostilities and withdrawal of all foreign troops.
3. That the United Nation's resolution on the above be implemented immediately.
We seek your urgent support.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of food irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government:
1. to phase out woodchipping for export;
2. not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

3. to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
4. to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices, including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: World War II Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth that-

The majority of World War II servicewomen, together with thousands of wartime servicemen who also did not hesitate to volunteer their services in the Defence Forces of Australia at a time when their country was at serious risk from an implacable enemy, did not serve in a theatre of war. This was not of their own choosing but as a result they are not eligible for a Service Pension under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Many receive a Disability Pension because of injuries or conditions resulting from or attributable to their wartime `home service' in Australia's Defence Forces and the fact that they did not serve in a theatre of war does not lessen their disabilities which have caused them considerable pain and frustration and spoilt their quality of life over a long period.

Any Disability Pension received by a Service Pensioner is not income for the assessment of basic Service Pension but is considered as income by the Department of Social Security, at times meaning the loss of fringe benefits as well as reducing the amount of Age Pension granted because of compensation for injuries or conditions accepted by determining authorities as war-caused. A Disability Pension is considered as combined income in the case of a married couple when the rate of Age Pension entitlement is being assessed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the parliament will determine that-

Social Security Legislation be amended to correct the anomaly which exists in the inclusion of a war veteran's Disability Pension in the assessment of income for the purposes of the Department of Social Security when it is not income for the purposes of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, this being an injustice which discriminates against the veterans of World War II who did not serve in a theatre of war.
And your petitioners will, in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's failure to allocate revenue collected from motorists and transporters at the petrol pump to the adequate maintenance and development of our highway infrastructure.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend existing legislation to increase immediately the level of spending on maintenance and development of our national road system.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully points out to the House that ``Food Irradiation'':
a. has been associated with blood abnormalities in humans and genetic defects, kidney cancers and testicular tumors in test animals.
b. makes food look fresh for longer but damages vitamins A, B, D, E and F, at a time when people are encouraged to eat more fresh foods.

c. has been used by major food companies to cover up and sell condemned foods. As there are no easy tests to detect irradiated foods, public health bodies cannot stamp out these abuses or guarantee irradiated foods will be labelled.
d. will make necessary the use of unwanted chemicals and additives to cover up the many unpleasant side-effects of the process on taste, smell, texture and colour.
e. inevitably, irradiated products from countries with questionable safety standards will be dumped on Australia, to the detriment of our health and our food producing economy.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House to:
a. impose an immediate moratorium on the process of ``Food Irradiation''.
b. impose an immediate ban on the importation of Cobalt-60 and Cesium-137.

c. exercise extreme caution in all processes involving ionising radiation, as there is now sufficient evidence to indicate long term detrimental health effects at radiation levels previously thought safe.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia humbly draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is free from Government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which ensures the availability of pharmaceutical benefits through local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
1. block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia, and
2. ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Cesium-137 and Cesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

1. Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme ``Authority only'' drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative products are readily available.

2. Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will reduce both remuneration to pharmacists and the standard of professional service and counselling provided by pharmacists to ensure that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider the restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights: Romania
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We the undersigned, are appalled that the Rumanian Government plans the commencement of the destruction in September of 7000 villages, hundreds of thousands of peaceful homes and homesteads, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries. With this barbaric action millions of people will be disadvantaged, even sent to their death with these Totalitarian actions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give these matters earnest consideration and request the Rumanian Government to abandon these horrific acts against the Rumanian Community and its minorities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure I present the Committee's report entitled The Election of Speaker, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just presented on behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure recommends that the House alter its procedures for the election of Speaker at the first sitting of a Parliament or at any time when the position becomes vacant. The Procedure Committee's consideration of this matter was instigated by a request from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) that it consider the matters raised in notice of a motion given by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). The motion proposed that the member with the longest continuous service who is not a Minister or Opposition officeholder preside at any election of the Speaker of the House. Our standing orders relating to the election of Speaker developed from the practice in the United Kingdom House of Commons where, for over three centuries, the Clerk of the House acted as chairman of the House during the election. Our Standing Orders contained detailed rules regarding the conduct of ballots for the election which were adopted by the House in 1937 and which the Committee does not propose to alter. This report is confined to the question of who should preside during the election.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has recommended that the member with the longest cumulative service in the House preside during the election of Speaker, both at the beginning of a Parliament and when a vacancy occurs in the course of a Parliament. The Committee has proposed this change for two reasons. The first is that it gives the House the opportunity to recognise and honour long-standing service to the House by a member. Secondly, it removes the House from a potentially vulnerable situation as the member presiding can be vested with the powers of the Speaker to apply the Standing Orders to deal with any difficulties that may arise. Under the current rules, the Clerk performs certain duties which are limited to what has been described as the `mechanical aspects'. He calls on members to speak, draws attention to the fact that a member's time has expired and puts the question if the closure is moved. As stated in House of Representatives Practice, however, many questions as to the role of the Clerk remain undetermined and it is unclear as to just what action he could take if members engaged in disorderly conduct. The House has been very well served by the Clerks in the past but there have been occasions where they have been placed in a difficult position. The action of the Clerk was questioned both during and after the election of Speaker Salmon in 1909 and during the election of Speaker Bell in 1934.

I add that the changes proposed are similar to those made by the United Kingdom House of Commons in 1972. More recently, the Canadian House of Commons adopted major changes to its procedures for the election of Speaker, including the provision that the member who has the longest period of unbroken service preside at the election of Speaker at the opening of a Parliament. The report proposes that the member with the longest period of cumulative service preside at any election of Speaker, but that it would not be appropriate for any Minister, party leader or deputy leader or Whip to preside. The duty would not be compulsory. Proposed standing order 2 (f) stipulates that until the Speaker is elected, the Chair is taken by the member `available' who has served for the longest period as a member. In the event of more than one eligible member fulfilling the criterion for length of service it is expected that, after consultation, commonsense will prevail in the determination of which member will preside.

It is proposed that the member presiding shall enjoy all the powers exercised by the Speaker during the proceedings, except that he or she shall have a deliberative vote only when casting a vote in the election of Speaker and in any division in the House. Should there be an equality of votes in any division in the House the member presiding would not have a casting vote and the question would not be carried as there would not have been a majority vote. I believe that the changes proposed will give the House the chance to recognise longstanding service, will remove the House from potentially vulnerable situations and will be supported by all members. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I originally proposed this matter and I spoke to it at that time. I would first like to thank the Standing Committee on Procedure for the report that has come forward arising from that, and the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for having it dealt with without the necessity of a long and protracted debate in this House. It does change a tradition which has existed in this Parliament for nearly 90 years. As has already been said, there have been only two occasions when problems have arisen, but there have been occasions when the potential for very difficult circumstances was there, and it was avoided by a handful of votes in the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to the consequences had not the then honourable member for Moreton, Sir James Killen, been elected in the 1961 election, when we would have had a circumstance in the Parliament where both parties had an equal number of voting members on the floor of the chamber and there were two non-voting members, both of whom were members of the Opposition. In theory, in the vote for the election of the Speaker, the Opposition could have had a majority of two. Had it nominated one of the non-voting members, that could have changed the majority on the floor of the Parliament by the fact that the Constitution would have given the non-voting member a casting vote. I think this matter as to the eligibility of the member for the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory would have been debated at considerable length on the floor of the Parliament. If I might say so, on the election of the Speaker, unless the Government then elected was stupid, it would have given them both full voting rights, which was within the power of the Parliament. But it would have been an impossible position for the Clerk, because there would have been rulings sought and other attempts to move motions in the course of those events which would have been part of the proceedings of the Parliament in a way other than the ceremonial function, which was and is normally expected to be that of the election of Speaker.

It has been mentioned that there have been problems on an earlier occasion. I warn that with the proposal to televise Parliament and the more spectacular type of publicity that is available and is obtained in this Parliament, in the circumstance even in the election of a Speaker, where there are literally no powers at the moment to discipline a member for whatever action he takes in this House during that period, there would be the temptation-it is not for me to say whether anyone would succumb to that temptation-for a member to act in a manner which was not in keeping with normal standards of, and would normally not be acceptable to, the House, and get a lot of publicity out of it. That has to be taken into account.

Should a crisis arise during that period, I believe the Clerk's prime responsibility would be to ensure that the proper advice was available to the person in the chair, which is not always possible when one has to concentrate on other duties. We have been well served in the past, but we should follow other parliaments in this change. It is not a momentous change and it will not make a great deal of difference to the operations of the Parliament.

It is my belief that we have to examine much more significant changes to the manner in which we do business in this Parliament. We now have the facilities to change. The sooner we bite the bullet and examine the manner in which we do business-I have long advocated that we have both plenary and committee sessions of this House in order to conduct our business-the sooner the Parliament's efficiency levels will be raised and the sooner the Parliament will function as a parliament should. I think it does not do that now.

There is one other matter which is of importance in this motion, that is, that it recognises the longest serving member of the House. It has already been pointed out that that has been done in other chambers. I draw attention to the fact that on the last occasion a Speaker was elected in the House of Commons, Sir James Callaghan, a recently defeated Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, took the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the discussion has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) notes that the world population is now in excess of five billion people, of whom three billion reside in Asia;

(2) considers that the overriding problem facing the world is that of a rapidly increasing population which is making ever increasing demands on the world's natural resources, thereby threatening ever greater environmental damage; and
(3) considers that this population problem is the most serious aspect of the world's overall environmental problems.

Many issues are raised each day in this Parliament; yet one topic that gets little mention is that of the rapidly increasing world population. Perhaps it is because we, as members of parliament, or indeed our constituents, do not see population as a problem for Australia. I would suggest that of all the problems facing this planet, the overriding one must be that of the rapidly increasing population. Australia, with a population of just over 16 million and a population density of 2.2 people per square kilometre, does not face the population related problems of many other countries. Indeed, for many years, through our own immigration program, we have sought to increase significantly our population.

Geographically we are part of Asia. Last year, in his launching address on the day of three billion in Asia, the Hon. Tasko Sato, Chairman of the Asian Forum on Population and Development, said that the Asian population is increasing by 54.5 million a year-about 4,540,000 people, on average, every month or 150,000 people every day. Indeed, seven babies are born every second. We, in Australia, cannot remove ourselves from the population problems of Asia. It is not only an Asian Problem; it is a world problem. For this reason, I am pleased that Australia is a member of the Asian Forum on Population and Development. Indeed, I represent Australia on the executive of this important group.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I did before you.

—Indeed. Nowadays we hear much about the greenhouse effect. It is a serious problem, but it is a problem that has been created, as some would say, by the overdeveloped world. I get rather angry when I hear well meaning groups in the United States of America, Australia, Germany, Britain and other countries lecturing to Brazilians about the dangers of cutting down the Amazonian rainforests. Of course it would be a tragedy if that happened and of course it would have a dramatic and disastrous impact. But the Brazilians did not cause the problem; the industrialised countries did. What we are, in effect, saying to the Brazilians is, `Look, the whole ecological balance is so precarious that you people must stay in your position of under-development so that we can continue with our own present lifestyle'. If we were really serious about the greenhouse effect, we in Australia, the United States of America, Germany or other industrialised countries will fundamentally change our lifestyle. We would reduce our over-indulgent lifestyle so that others can catch up. Then, in a cooperative manner, we can with some credibility approach the Brazilians.

SPEECH.PARA: Just as we cannot opt out of the environmental debate, nor can we opt out of the population debate. It is our debate as much as the debate of the people of China, India or anywhere else. In recent years, India has achieved tremendous success in agriculture, industrial production, science and technology and in diversifying the capabilities in the primary, secondary and tertiary sectors. Yet we have to recognise that each month India's population increases by approximately one million people. The Asian population broke the one billion mark in the 1950s. During August 1988 the Asian population reached the three billion mark. Population growth in Asia is still huge, not because population is so huge, not because the population growth is so high but rather because the population base is immense. The excessive population growth will result in shortages of food, resources and energy, which are limited on earth, and environmental destruction beyond national boundaries. Not only will it threaten the living base of human beings but it will also have the power to cancel out civilised society, even with the technological innovations and economic developments society has produced.

Asia, with its huge population, has problems of population growth, food, environment and development. To cope with these problems, Asian countries must build up their base of socioeconomic development to facilitate the absorption of the young labour force, improve agriculture productivity and industrialisation, diffuse education and improve health and medical services.

Population and environment issues are closely related when viewed from a global perspective. The world population passed the five billion mark two years ago and it is still increasing by 220,000 people a day, or more than 80 million people a year. A simple calculation tells us that it is increasing by one billion people every 12 years and it is expected that 90 per cent of the increase in population will be from developing countries. On the other hand, tropical forests are decreasing at the rate of 12 million hectares per year due to burning of fuels, commercial deforestation and the loss of top soil amounting to 26 billion tonnes a year. Elements such as unstable rainfall added to over-cultivation on sterile land, due to the pressures of population growth, as well as pasturing and excessive consumption of trees for firewood or charcoal, are aggravating soil, reducing farmland and promoting desertification. Six million hectares of new desert is created every year. It is a depressing picture to which we in Australia have not paid nearly enough attention.

Population policy should play a vital part when drawing up and promoting a national development plan for a country. We need to have a total policy, including environmental conservation measures, in a development plan. Based on such a total policy, we can strive for the stabilisation of population and environmental protection in an effort to actualise the sustainable development proposed by the World Committee on Environment and Development. Continuous and stronger support in this field is strongly expected from advanced countries. As I have attempted to illustrate, there is a close and inseparable relationship between population and environmental problems. It is absolutely necessary to strengthen cooperation beyond national boundaries in order to stabilise the population and to protect the environment.

The growth rate for Asia as a whole is lower than that for Africa or Latin America. Because Asia has such a large population base, the total number of people in Asia will continue to grow rapidly for some time to come. As stated, the Asian population is currently increasing by 54.5 million people every year. Even by the year 2025 the Asian population will be more than half the projected world population of 8.2 billion people. Population growth varies greatly among the different subregions of Asia. It has already declined substantially in South East Asia, and in many countries programs are beginning to show impressive results. However, in the countries of southern Asia, with the exception of Sri Lanka, the growth rate continues to be high.

Asia's population of three billion is in many ways a testimony to the victory achieved over the region's age-old enemies-famine and high mortality. What is clear now is the need for Asia, like other developing regions, to continue to lower birth rates, to stimulate economic growth and food production, and to provide jobs and food for its increasing population. This, I admit, is not an easy task, but Asia provides a good example of both what can be done and what needs to be done in the future. Asia's patterns of growth and associated problems are in many ways typical of other developing regions. They pose grave problems for the future. One of the most disconcerting is that, while population in the industrialised countries has slowed or stopped, it continues to grow rapidly in Asia, Africa and Latin America. This global population imbalance poses dangers to the environment, to international trade and, indeed, to peace.

When population growth outstrips its natural resource base it begins to destroy it. The destruction of trees and forests causes deserts to spread and creates worldwide climatic changes. Countries which have to devote much of their energies to cope with high population growth have little chance of economic improvement. This requires awareness and commitment by national political leaders; the creation, where they do not already exist, of government units to direct population efforts and resources; and strong population institutions to conduct research and to train population managers.

The population of the world is now more than five billion, and it will reach six billion before the end of the century, seven billion by the year 2010, and eight billion by 2022. Although overall the world's growth rate is declining, the numbers are such that the annual increase will continue to grow for another decade. Some 90 per cent of population growth is occurring in the developing world-by definition, in the countries least able to afford it. At the same time, the population of the industrialised nations has largely stopped growing.

Governments of high fertility countries are being forced to spend increasing amounts on essentials and have little left over for investment. For example, Kenya spends about one-third of its total budget on education, health, rural water supply and urban housing. If fertility rates remain high, total government expenditures on these items will have to be multiplied by a factor of nine just to maintain current standards. Because of the increasing outflow of capital from the developing countries for essential imports and for debt service, governments are spending proportionally less on social investments, such as in the education and health areas. The differential levels of development, international inequalities, coupled with acute poverty and lower incomes in many developed countries in the post World War II era, force the international community to think in terms of concerted international community efforts to attack the problems of poverty. The high population growth negated the fruits of development to the poor in the developing countries. Naturally, attention was focused on tackling the problems of such high population growth.

I have devoted much time in this speech to an overview of the Asian situation, but we in Australia cannot give advice from afar. Indeed, I do not think we can give advice at all, but we can give assistance to world bodies such as the United Nations in solving the problem. We must also take seriously our role in the Asian Forum on Population and Development. Let us dispel the myth that politicians are short-sighted and not capable of seeing and appreciating the issue over a longer timeframe. We must start to confront the issues with determination and on the basis of dialogue and consensus, with the unified and integrated objective of a better future for the countries of our region. We in Australia have a role to play and we must take up the challenge. We cannot isolate ourselves. We cannot continue to think in the short term, and we can no longer think only of Australia. We must think globally and, indeed, we must match our words with action. Threats to the very survival of the human race, so evident as the twentieth century approaches its end, and the need to deal with those threats more effectively at the political level, are forcing us to act.

It is evident that humanity has been reckless in the use of the planet's resources for development. Since the industrial revolution, in the name of progress, we have fouled air, water and soil worldwide. As populations increase resources are strained beyond their limits and environmental refugees migrate from the rural areas to the cities and across national boundaries. Despite technological advances, some 40,000 children die each day from preventable causes-malnutrition, dehydration caused by diarrhoea, measles and other diseases. The current world population growth of between 2 and 3 per cent is maintained through very high fertility which imposes special burdens on women, particularly high mortality and morbidity related to childbearing. Today, many societies are no longer threatened by high mortality, yet individual women and children are still dying needlessly because of high fertility exacerbated by poverty and the lack of health care.

The world agreed at three different United Nations conferences, in Teheran, Bucharest and Mexico, that family planning is a human right. Delegates agreed also that its oppression discriminates against the poor, the ignorant and the illiterate. I must say that I have always seen it as a basic human right for a woman to control her own fertility and, naturally, she must have access to information to do this. Giving parents the right to plan their own family voluntarily can improve everyone's health as well as that of their children, and bring rapid population growth under control. A sound population policy is essential to sustainable economic development. Perhaps one of the outcomes from the 1990 International Year of Literacy will enable people to gain access to printed literature to better control their fertility.

Let me, in the time remaining, return to the wording of this notice of motion. Since I have been speaking the world's population has increased by 2,550 persons. By this time next year it will have increased by 80 million worldwide and in Asia by 54 million people. This increasing population must be the overriding problem facing the world. We have no hope of solving environmental problems-indeed, a whole range of problems-unless we tackle this, the main problem. I hope that, in the many issues that we as politicians face every day, we can devote more time to this issue. If we do not I ask: What sort of future will we and future generations have?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is significant that today, as on so many other occasions since private members' business has been allocated more time and importance, two honourable members have taken the opportunity to draw our attention beyond the short term and party political issues to long term fundamental and global issues. I refer to the motion of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) on human rights in Brazil and to the motion of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) on population pressures on the global environment. I commend the honourable member for Throsby for his very cohesive and succinct speech which drew our attention to this very serious problem. It is on the latter motion that I have chosen to make some comments. The honourable member for Throsby has asked the House today to look beyond its debating chamber to those countries and regions which are under enormous resource and environmental pressure, and which are failing to cope with or meet those pressures. He asks us-I believe correctly-to consider our own involvement and responsibilities concerning what he implicitly presents as the overpopulation of this very fragile planet.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion proposed by the honourable member asks us to identify increasing population as the overriding problem facing the world and as the most serious aspect of the world's overall environmental problems. I believe that, while population growth is a serious problem facing the global community, it should not become the primary focus of policy solutions. I make that judgment, firstly, because of the repressive and inhuman policies of forced sterilisation and state-coerced abortion and infanticide which have characterised past and current experience in India and China when population became the central focus of state development policy.

My second reason is that such a focus would be analytically erroneous and, more importantly, politically dishonest. The real priority areas to be addressed when responding to unsustainable population growth are, firstly, socioeconomic and, secondly, technological and scientific. We know that one of the most significant factors affecting population growth is poverty and infant mortality rates. We know that by attacking poverty and the economic vulnerability of families in developing countries, and by attacking infant disease and mortality, we do, in fact, address the underlying disincentives for having fewer children. The honourable member for Throsby spoke very clearly on that issue. We are reminded that relentlessly every year over 14 million children under the age of five die from malnutrition and poverty.

I used the phrase `politically dishonest' earlier. I did so because we know that to tackle infant mortality and poverty and dependence in developing countries we have to tackle corrupt traditional and socialist agricultural systems, unfettered industrialisation of both capitalist and socialist varieties and oppressively hierarchical social and cultural systems such as caste systems, in most of the countries facing population pressure. The political reality is that it is a lot easier to focus on family planning and contraceptives, and to resort to sterilisation and abortion in those countries, than it is to undertake political, social and economic reforms. So, the point of focus should not be human sexual relations but human social relations.

The second priority area I raised was technological and scientific. I want to say two things in that regard, one negative and one positive. The reason population growth by humans seems to present the earth's environment and the earth's other life forms with a zero-sum dilemma is not with the fact of human existence in increasing numbers, but the choices humans make, particularly in the area of technology.

The greenhouse effect, which was referred to by the honourable member for Throsby and is on everybody's mind at the moment, has to do primarily with the automobile, power generation and industrialisation. The threat to the ozone layer has to do with the use of spray cans and refrigerators and other chemical products. Erosion of soils has to do with land management techniques. Oil spills and deforestation alike have to do with the resource demands of modern industrial societies. So, the policy focus should not be human fertility, in the first instance, but human technology. Increasingly, the answer must be a policy mix of incentives and sanctions which delivers modern society alternative, appropriate technologies and which nurtures attitudinal change in industrial consumer society.

The positive comment I wish to make about technology and science relates to the hopes we justifiably hold about human intelligence. In the early 1970s dire predictions about starvation and resource exhaustion were made. In the late 1980s we know that many of those predictions were falsified by human scientific and technological breakthroughs. We should continue to encourage and fund human ingenuity, especially in the areas of earth repair and earth sustenance. I have suggested that population pressure is a problem to be addressed, not on the surface by family planning strategies, but radically by reference to the patterns of human, social, economic, political and technological structures, relations and techniques. I have suggested a primary focus on human social relations and on technology, rather than on human sexual relations and fertility in the search for policy responses to population pressure.

The reality is that unsustainable population growth, and its environmental consequences, can be met by strategies which deal with poverty and dependence and by the move to alternative technology and models of development. These are the two areas of challenge we are forced to consider. As I have said before, we should commend the honourable member for Throsby for drawing our attention to those areas via his motion on population.

I have been dealing with matters of the head during this short debate. I would prefer to end my comments by dealing with matters of the compassionate and outreaching heart. We know of the human misery of over- populated cities in Africa, Asia, Latin America and other parts of the world. We know that peoples of developing countries are unable to survive, through famine, flood and erosion, or because of state agricultural and development policies and priorities. We know, as I have said before, that 14 million children under the age of five die each year because of disease and malnutrition-almost the population of Australia is dying relentlessly every year. Throughout this country, and throughout the world, we need to think about that fact continuously in a practical and compassionate way. Most of all, we know that, as we talk, there are others who are the front-line providers of compassion: providers of healing, sustenance and opportunity for those who suffer around the world. I think of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, the Save the Children Fund, the Evangelical Alliance Relief Response Fund-the TEAR Fund-the Catholic Relief Fund, World Vision and many, many others. I take this opportunity to acknowledge their commitment and their work. I also take this opportunity to suggest to this Parliament, and to the community at large, that perhaps we still have not provided the levels of support in cash or otherwise that these workers require to tackle poverty, dependence and equality. I challenge this Parliament and the people of Australia to have a much more compassionate heart and support, through these organisations, people who are in such desperate need in this great world of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise and support the motion put before the House today by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). Earlier in this debate the honourable member made an extremely worthwhile and valuable contribution to this House. The debate shows that many honourable members do not just go from issue to issue. They attempt to address the very difficult issues which affect all of us in the longer term, particularly those in the Asian region. This is important in the context of the motion before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Throsby mentioned that today the world population is in excess of five billion people. It is estimated, depending on whose estimates one accepts, that by the year 2100 the world population will be in excess of 10 billion people. In other words, in the next hundred years, we can, in all probability, expect that the world population will double again from around five billion people to 10 billion people. It was not so many years ago-1960, in fact-when the world population was only 3 billion people. So the growth which is occurring in the world population is quite dramatic and its implications for our survival, for living standards, for the environment around the world and for the resources of the planet are very significant.

I want to refer to some of the work that has been done in this area in relation to the world population. In 1988 a report was released by the United Nations (UN) entitled State of World Population. It is a very good report which basically concludes that the growth rate continues to widen the gap between the rich developed countries such as Australia, where the birth rate is low and per capita income is high, and the poor developing nations, which include much of Asia and Africa, where birth rates are high and incomes are pitifully low. The report exposes the distortions in production, trade and demand which have occurred. World food production, as members of this House would know, is quite adequate to feed everyone in the world. Yet one person in six throughout the world is unable to obtain sufficient food to sustain an active working life. So there is no shortage of food in the world, certainly not at this point, but there are serious problems in the way in which it is distributed around the world. While the Western World, the developed world, is able to stockpile grain and butter, the people of the poorest nations often lack the money and resources to feed themselves.

Improvements in farming methods have not been able to reverse the trend. For instance, African food production has increased by something like 20 per cent in the past decade but the population growth has substantially outstripped it, leaving per capita food production some 10 per cent below its 1977 level. So productivity is occurring in the way in which land is used, but in many of the less developed nations population growth rates, which are still very high, are simply outstripping the rate of agricultural production.

In the report State of World Population, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities warns of the serious economic and social circumstances facing the developed nations unless both the developed and the undeveloped nations are able to rein in population growth rates. Australia's population growth rate is about one per cent. The growth rate is below one per cent in the United States of America, Japan and West Germany and a little over one per cent in China. In Kenya, which is the fastest growing country, it is 4 per cent and that country's population is expected to double to 40 million people by the year 2005. The United Nations report makes an interesting point. In 1950 Africa's population was half that of Europe but it is expected to be three times as large as that of Europe before the year 2050. It is already larger and will be three times as large within the next 60 years. One gets an idea from that of the dramatic impact which population growth can have.

In turn, that affects relative standards of living. I make a comparison here, which is mentioned in the report, between Brazil and Japan. In 1960 Brazil's gross national product (GNP) was $900 per person compared to $1,400 in Japan. There was not a great deal of difference. But over the next 25 years Brazil's GNP grew at between 5 per cent and 10 per cent per year and it now stands at only $2,000 per person. Japan, with much smaller population rises but a similar economic growth rate, now has a per capita GNP of $16,000 per head. The relevance of those population growth figures in terms of living standards is quite dramatic. So, according to this UN report, there is a very clear link between population growth and health. It is too clear to be denied.

While I support the motion before the House, I want to say that in terms of world resources it simply is not good enough to suggest that the major demands on world resources or the problems for the world's ecosystems are caused primarily by the rapid population growth which is occurring throughout undeveloped nations. If one looks at the statistics of who consumes the world's resources, it is the people of Western civilisations-the developed countries like Australia and the United States-who consume many times more resources per head than those people who live in the underdeveloped nations. If one looks at the consumption of oil, electricity, energy in general, tin or even food-all of the crucial and fundamental resources of the world, the basic products-one sees that each of us, as well as our family pets, in developed countries, consume more resources per day than many people in the underdeveloped countries of the world. The real drain on resources is coming just as much from the excessive consumption habits of people in the developed world as it is from the enormous population growth in the underdeveloped world.

A couple of points can be made. The first one is that since we are talking in this motion about demands on the world resources and environment, it is important that we embrace strategies in the developed world which tend to put a lid on the consumption of resources. Perhaps we can do that through pricing mechanisms, as we in the developed world seem to do fairly well. Some countries ensure that consumption of oil is not too excessive by imposing high prices for it. We can also look at embracing strategies like recycling. Countries like Australia can make a significant impact on resource use simply by re-using resources. Recycled paper is an obvious example. I hope that the proposal of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for a mill to make unbleached paper comes off because it is the sort of project which offers potential for recycling in the future.

The other side of the coin is that developed countries should still be doing much more to assist underdeveloped countries in terms of foreign aid and development programs. As a member of the Government I have been disappointed-I know economic times have been tough in the last few years-that this Government has not been able to maintain its contribution in real terms to foreign aid in the last few years. I know that many Australians have had to make sacrifices but it concerns me greatly that as a relatively wealthy nation we have allowed our contribution to foreign aid to slip. I hope that in this year's Budget and in future Budgets we are able to lift our contribution to foreign aid above 0.4 per cent or 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product and that in the long term we meet the target of 0.7 per cent of GDP. There is no doubt that while we have had some tough economic times we are still immeasurably more wealthy and more comfortable than the vast majority of people in the world.

We have a role to play in resource use. Recycling can make a contribution from the developed world's point of view and we can provide significantly more aid to underdeveloped countries to assist them. One area in which we can particularly assist underdeveloped countries is in the education area which can have a major social and cultural impact on living patterns. It can make a major impact on issues such as birth rates in underdeveloped and developing countries and on understanding in those countries of the way in which they use their resources and the environment. I support the motion which is before the House. It has provided the opportunity for a valuable discussion. I hope that Australia can make a contribution towards overcoming some of these problems by providing an increase in the amount of resources which we provide annually for foreign aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to take part in this very important debate because there is no doubt in my mind that this motion, when it says that `the population problem is the most serious aspect of the world's overall environmental problems', correctly focuses our attention on a very important issue that faces the whole world. Some time ago I came across a quotation that I found very interesting, and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: What kind of spirit is there in a society which does not have the gumption to replace itself?

That quotation was made in relation to the Western industrialised countries whose population growth rate has fallen below the replacement level. Of course, one could vary that quotation and have it read `What kind of spirit is there in a society which does not have the gumption to avoid destroying itself?' and apply it to the world society. Both expressions of that quotation are equally correct because the problem of world population varies from country to country and from region to region.

As was pointed out earlier in this debate, the world's population is growing fast and will continue to grow fast. Even if as from tomorrow every country were able to achieve a replacement rate fertility level of no growth and no decline on a long term basis, there would be population growth in the world for the next 100 years. That population growth of itself would be difficult enough to cope with, but many of the big countries in population terms have fertility rates far in excess of the replacement rate.

In 1974 the agenda of an Inter-Parliamentary Union conference held in Tokyo included the topic of world population. Until the early 1970s, the question of population growth was regarded as the preserve of the demographer and the academic economist in the universities. There was not much political debate about the question of population growth. At that conference, members of parliaments from over 100 countries debated the issue. I was fortunate enough to be at the conference. I was impressed then, and have remained impressed since, by the common view, with one exception to which I will refer, that was expressed by members of parliament from a diverse range of countries from the four corners of the world that the world faced a population problem.

The one exception was the tragic area of central, east and west Africa. Because of the state of political development, the representatives from that area believed that talking about population control and limiting the expansion of world numbers was an attack on their ability to develop by those they regarded as former colonialists. One only has to look at the tragedy of central, east and west Africa since then-the desertification of the sub-Sahara desert and the famines that have affected those countries on top of internal political strife. I think the rest of the world has observed with horror that lack of understanding.

I am pleased that the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has brought this matter forward. During the debate some honourable members have said that it is not for us to tell other countries how to manage their affairs. But it is for us, having the experience of our own development and having an understanding of the development that is occurring in other countries, to play a part in the world political community, to draw attention to those countries which do not understand the damage that will be done to the survival of the human race if efforts are not made to restrict unbridled population growth. Where the population growth is growing at a very fast rate, the population is living at subsistence level and sometimes very much below that level. Yet those people have a yearning to have a higher standard of living, which they all deserve. The green revolution has shown that the world can get its act together and feed itself. We need to get our act together to uplift the standard of living for people in those countries where, for the most part, large populations are living at a subsistence or lower level.

There are some dilemmas, because we in Australia, as with other peoples of the developed world, have a different problem. We have to look at how we will replace our population. It seems very perverse that we should be advocating an increase in our fertility rates while expressing concern at the very high fertility rates in other countries. The world population is a function of those fertility rates, but it is also a function of mortality rates and, increasingly, mortality rates are having an effect on the increasing world population.

It is very important that members of parliament in all countries around the world are conscious of the effects of population growth. We should be having debates on how fertility rates, mortality rates and infant mortality rates affect population growth, and on a whole range of other interrelated issues that affect the future destiny of this world. We do not want a world society that destroys itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, while welcoming advances for the provision of human rights contained in Brazil's newly adopted constitution, this House:

(1) conveys to the President of Brazil its concerns about the killings of peasants, indigenous peoples, rural trade union leaders, lawyers and religious workers in the areas of rapid economic development;

(2) calls upon the Brazilian Government to take urgent measures to ensure that the rule of law is applied equally throughout Brazil and that goodfaith investigations be undertaken into those reported political killings; and
(3) urges the Brazilian Government it ensure that prompt and effective inquiries are made into allegations of arbitrary arrests and ill-treatment of peasants by local law enforcement agents.

This motion will be seconded by my colleague the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). It is with a great deal of pleasure that I have come to the House today to move this motion, which I have put firmly on the record for those who might wish to read what I have to say or who are listening in to this debate. I think all honourable members are familiar with the fact that I am a member of Amnesty International and am involved with the parliamentary group of Amnesty. The honourable member for Hughes is also involved in that group and is its President. A large number of members of this Parliament are associated with that unique organisation. All are no doubt familiar with the fact that Amnesty's charter obliges it to take up the cases of people who are locked up around the world because of their political views-people who are known as prisoners of conscience. Its activities have two other arms, which, simply stated, are its opposition to the use of the death penalty and its abhorrence of the use of torture on people who are incarcerated.

What has this motion to do with Amnesty? Amnesty is very much concerned when the rule of law in any country breaks down to a point where large numbers of people are unable to rely upon the legal system and law enforcement agencies to protect their personal well-being, in many cases their lives and their property. We have, unfortunately, seen in Brazil-and it has been recorded and documented over some years-a breakdown in the rule of law as we understand it. We have consistent, well documented reports of a pattern of human rights violations in rural areas of that country, carried out by local authorities or with their acquiescence. That is the situation about which we are speaking.

We all know from news reports that we have seen-I have one before me from Time of March-about the changes that are taking place in Brazil, the quest for development and the impact that that development is having upon the community. Environmentalists are concerned about the destruction of the jungles of Brazil and the erection of dams which displace large numbers of people. I think it is generally understood that a large number of indigenous people, the Indians, in Brazil are likely to be displaced by these developments. The Indian population in that country is about 220,000, and it will be affected by particular proposals. It is already threatened in numerous other ways but is now also threatened by the changes that the Government has been encouraging to bring in. These changes, of course, involve the international community. The World Bank in particular is being called upon to fund a number of dam developments. Many others who are likely to benefit from the access to water see opportunities for the exploitation of land that has not previously been available. So there is a tremendous conflict between those who see land as a traditional matter and are living in a traditional lifestyle and those who seek to graze livestock in one form or another or bring land under cultivation and who make claims for land and find these competing interests to be a distraction.

Amnesty does not seek to involve itself in resolving the question of land ownership. However, it does say that, in the context of resolving those matters, governments have to have regard to the human rights of those who are likely to be affected. Amnesty reports indicate that there are some 50 cases of peasants, community leaders, trade unionists and church workers who have been killed in trying to assert claims to land and labour rights in that area. The majority of these killings appear to have been carried out by gunmen hired by landowners, speculators and rival claimants, and in some areas there are indications of direct police involvement. We see the international community saying to Brazil, `Notwithstanding your constitution, the central government has to play a role in ensuring that these matters are resolved'. This is not a matter that can be left simply to local communities to resolve as they see fit.

One of the problems is that an enormous amount of evidence is emerging that local authorities not only tolerate the human rights abuses but frequently assist in them. Official inquiries into some of these killings that have occurred have frequently jeopardised and obstructed the quest for justice. Prosecutions have invariably failed to proceed and the scale of failure in these cases suggests very strongly that the obstruction is not coincidental but rather systematic and deliberately intended to impede the effective application and equal application of the rule of law.

Amnesty, when in January it published its last document that I saw on this matter, indicated that there had been over 1,000 cases of killings reported since 1980 but that it knew of only three cases in which gunmen had been convicted. There were no convictions of those who had hired those gunmen to commit those killings. Amnesty has called upon the federal authorities to open independent investigations into the cases documented and to use the federal police in parallel investigations of future cases. If we need a local example, I guess Amnesty is seeking the sort of intervention that we have seen in Australia, where concern has naturally arisen about the large number of deaths of Aboriginals in custody. Our Commonwealth Government has sought to ensure that there are no questions raised about the way in which human rights are protected in Australia and that there are proper inquiries to ascertain whether the rule of law is being properly applied or whether there have been breakdowns. We are asking that those same efforts be undertaken in Brazil.

In a debate of some 10 minutes it is very difficult to document the cases of those involved, but let me mention just a few. Chico Mendes was assassinated on 22 December 1988. The authorities failed to investigate six previous attempts on his life. He was one of the rural trade union presidents. Moises Vitorio dos Santos, a rural trade union president, was found shot dead and with his throat cut in November 1988. The previous month he had led a delegation to the State Governor to appeal for the disarming of gunmen in the region. In another case, Sebastiao Pereira de Souza, a squatter peasant, and his three-year old son were killed in October 1987. His widow reported it to the local police chief but he told her he could not register the crime, which she had witnessed, because he lacked pen and paper to write down the details. Over a year later no-one has been brought to trial for the murders. The widow and a local priest fled the town because they received information that their names appeared on a death list. The same list included a State deputy, Joao Batista. Gunmen shot and killed him in the presence of his family in December 1988. On the day of his murder, he told the State Legislative Assembly that two military policemen had threatened to kill him. I could go on.

Lest it be thought that between January and now there have not been further developments, I regret to say that the developments are not that there has been a firm intention at a federal government level to bring these matters to finality to ensure that the rule of law is applied equally and fairly. Rather, we see new allegations about excessive use of force, torture and ill-treatment. Over 1,000 State military police of Rio Grande do Sul expelled 600 peasant families which had squatted on the land in that area. Planes were used to drop tear gas and the like. The police then moved in. We received reports that 22 people had been arrested as a result of that. They have been held in detention since 11 March and they have been tortured. This gives further concern to Amnesty.

I take this opportunity to encourage my colleagues and others to let it be known to the Brazilian Government that this form of action is reprehensible in the eyes of the international community and that there is an expectation that the United Nation's declaration on human rights ought to be upheld by the Brazilian Government. The declaration states:
Everyone has the right to life, liberty and security of person.
No one shall be subject to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.
No one shall be subject to arbitrary arrest, detention or exile.
This matter is of grave concern not only to the members of the Parliament involved with Amnesty but to the whole Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. It is not unusual for me to second, support or indicate my strong backing for propositions put forward in this House by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). I have great pleasure in working with the honourable member in the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International. Indeed, it is really that group which sponsors the motion before the House today. People may wonder why we in the Australian Parliament, on the other side of the world from Brazil, seek to take up these issues of human rights. The answer to that is that we, as members of parliament, believe there are certain universal standards of human rights that all people and all parliamentarians around the world ought to stand to defend. So, when human rights are violated in Brazil, we, as Australians and as Australian members of parliament, ought to do all we can to defend those universal principles of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times there have been incredible gains and advances in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in the promotion of human rights. Much more needs to be done but, importantly, I truly believe that the concerted, coordinated campaign for human rights in the Soviet Union was a positive and contributing force to the changes that occurred in that country-as it must be for Brazil. We, in Australia, cannot sit back and allow the continual violation of human rights that the honourable member for Dundas referred to in the course of his remarks.

As the honourable member for Dundas said, Amnesty International has investigated very thoroughly the allegations of human rights violations. it has done that by sending a number of missions to Brazil and by its own independent investigations.
