What has been recorded is a frightening legacy of mistreatment of our fellow human beings. The reports of Amnesty have recorded the failings and irregularities in police and judicial investigations; the difficulties in officially registering crime, as the honourable member for Dundas has so ably demonstrated; the failure of open police investigations and their premature and unexplained closure; the failures in conducting post-mortems; the failure to arrest criminal suspects; the repeated escapes from custody, in mysterious circumstances, of gunmen; the death threats that go unchecked; the continually arbitrary arrests; and the allegations of ill-treatment in custody. It has to stop. We as Australian parliamentarians, stand resolutely behind the commitment of Amnesty International to highlight these violations of human rights to the world.

This debate in the Parliament occurs not because of Opposition inspired motions or Government inspired motions; it comes from the parliamentarians themselves. This is an important part of parliamentary business; it is when members of the Parliament can put items on the agenda for discussion in this place. My message today goes beyond that. I believe that not only members of the Parliament but every citizen in this country who cares about what is happening in Brazil can do something about it. To the people who are listening to this parliamentary broadcast today I say: `Go to the phone book, look up Amnesty International in the capital city of your State or Territory, phone Amnesty and join us in doing what we can to make sure that these repressive governments in fact adhere to these international standards that are so vital to life on earth'.

I could say many things in the course of this debate but time does not permit me to continue much longer. The Australian Government has done its bit to raise these violations of human rights with the Brazilian Government. Late last year, Trish Feeney, the Amnesty International researcher for Brazil was a visitor to Australia. She told us what was happening in Brazil and asked us to approach the Australian government-as we had done before-to take up these violations of human rights. We have received formal responses from the Government which detail the repeated high level representations by the Australian Government to the Government of Brazil to answer and act on the concerns that the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International has publicly raised. When Senator Richardson went to Brazil last year on his environmental mission he intended to raise the concerns himself. He found that only three days before strong and formal representations had been made by the Australian diplomatic representatives about the violations of human rights. The Government has gone on record as saying that it will continue to monitor and make further representations to the Brazilian authorities. That is an important stand by Australia. If other countries follow our example it is going to be a far more effective international campaign, not just on the Brazilian issue but in relation to human rights generally.

In conclusion, I believe we ought to be instituting a much more formal reporting back process by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as to what actions it has taken on human rights questions and, in particular, to act on the concerns of Amnesty International. It is a very proud record of that Department. It is doing a good job for Australia and for human rights. It is important that that work, that track record, be publicly recorded in the Parliament. I commend its actions. I have great pleasure in seconding this resolution and strongly believe that it is shared by every member of this House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House rejects the principle of separate development for Aboriginal or any other Australians.

I tend to speak as often as I can on this subject and similar subjects because I am one member of this Parliament-and I know there are many more-who is dedicated to the proposition that all Australians are equal. I believe that any nation which departs from that principle of equality of all of its citizens is going down the wrong track. I expect that because of some of the things that I will say I will be criticised and I will receive some flak. It happens every time I speak about multiculturalism as well, but I have broad shoulders and I do not mind. I want to make the point that we are all Australians, regardless of race, skin colour, creed or politics and that the laws of Australia should be developed and applied on the basis of equality for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great principle.

—It is a great principle and it is one that I think most people in this House would espouse. There is no doubt that there is a great need in some areas of Australia among some people of Australia. Whether it is a question of lack of education or employment or poor health facilities and housing those needs should be satisfied on the basis of the need itself, not on the basis of race or skin colour. I use as an example the Aboriginal community of Burnt Bridge near the town of Kempsey in my electorate of Cowper. Quite frankly, I am appalled and shocked at the conditions in which my fellow Australians are living at Burnt Bridge. There are some 57 people in this community. I know there are difficulties because of the title, but some 57 of my fellow Australians are living in this very small area. There are two decent houses but the great bulk of the people are living in wood and tin humpies with dirt floors and no running water. They have to fill buckets to get water from the decent houses. There is no sewerage and the electricity is supplied in a very dangerous fashion by power leads from the two decent houses. Something definitely needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: My State colleague Wendy Machin, the honourable member for Manning, has been in contact with the State Minister, who the week before last was in touch with the office of our Federal Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). I know that the Minister is a compassionate man and really cares. His policies are frequently, if not always, wrong but I believe he is innately sincere, caring and compassionate. His office will be in touch with me shortly. The point I want to make is that these people who need help should be helped not on the basis that they are Aboriginals. They should be helped on the basis that they are Australians who are housed in absolutely disgraceful conditions. That should apply to anybody else. I find it absolutely amazing that in 1989, after six years of the Hawke Government's supposed care for Aboriginal people and other Australians-to remain true to my theme-I still have people in my electorate who are living in such appalling conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the $3.3 billion.
—As the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs says, $3.3 billion has been spent.
—A very temporary shadow Minister. You will not be there after tomorrow, will you, Chris?

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory will not be here after the next election, that is for sure. A whole range of activities of finance have been given to the Aboriginal communities. I do not debate at this time the validity of what is given as many of the things are open to debate, but I am not concerned about that at the moment. If there is a need for some Australian citizens to be given certain help and assistance, I repeat-and I will go on repeating this forever-that aid and assistance must be given on the basis of need, not of race.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988 the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill was introduced but it did not get too far. It set the path for separate development. It set out to create an Aboriginal Parliament in Australia. `Self-determination' and `self-government' were the words used by the Minister. As I said when debating that Bill, I deplore it; I am totally opposed to it. I believe that Aboriginal people, just the same as any other Australians, should be part of Australian society. This is where we should be going. We now have a mishmash of the ATSIC Bill in the form of the ATSIC Bill 1989 plus another couple of Bills-namely, the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989 and the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989. It is worth recording my approval and support of the fact that most of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs' majority reports' 40 recommendations have been accepted by the Minister. There are still quite a number of outstanding matters, four in particular, which have not been addressed. But the point is that we should not have this Bill. We should not be having a separate black parliament in Australia. We have the Federal Parliament of Australia and the State parliaments. Surely that is enough. All we are going to do if this continues is to further isolate our Aboriginal fellow citizens. That is what is going to happen.

Unfortunately, there is a backlash throughout the white community of Australia. I deplore this. I say again that I believe all Australians are equal. All Australians deserve the same care from government regardless of race or creed. We have a whole range of things in place to alleviate this problem. We have additional expenditure for Aboriginal Australians, in the areas of education, employment, housing and health over and above what is available to every other Australian citizen. As well as that, in 1989 an additional $671m is being provided for our Aboriginal brothers-a total expenditure of just over $2,900 a head over and above what every other Australian is entitled to.

I think it is worth noting that some 227,645 people claim to be Aboriginals. I think it is worth making the point that the definition of what is an Aboriginal person tends to vary very frequently. When the benefits were first made available separately in the Whitlam years, many people who until then had been living as white European Australians suddenly discovered their aboriginality. We have 1.46 per cent of the Australian population claiming to be Aboriginal. I think it is worth noting that the Aboriginal people of Australia control an area of land, in the form of freehold, mission reserves and leasehold, equal to one-seventh of the entire land mass of Australia. A little over 14 per cent of the Australian land mass is controlled by Aboriginal people. This is an area roughly equal to the total area of New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania. An incredible significant amount of Australian land has been given back to the Aboriginal people. I do not object to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Explain yourself.

—The honourable member might just constrain himself for a moment. We know how people like the honourable member perform. He starts bashing up the people in his electorate. We know about the honourable member-so he should settle down and just be quiet for a minute.
—I suggest that the honourable member for Cowper ignore the interjections.

—I will certainly heed your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe that it is appropriate that Aboriginal people should have land in this way. I believe, too, that it is appropriate that we should and must acknowledge the cultural heritage of our Aboriginal people, and they should be free to pursue for themselves what they want to do in creating, respecting and keeping their heritage-just as every other Australian citizen has the right to do. I have said in this place before in other debates that I am proud of my Scottish and Danish forebears; it is my right to enjoy the heritage and culture of my forebears. But I am an Australian, not a Scot or a Dane living in Australia. I believe that, if we boil it down to the crux of what our society must be, we cannot escape the absolutely valid proposition: all Australians are equal, all Australians should be equal before the law, and all Australians should be treated equally.
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to contribute to this debate because this issue does concern me a lot. It is an issue which makes me very angry. I believe that the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is a compassionate man, but like so many people, I do not think he has come to grips with the problem. Until such time as we do that we will never be able to solve it. We really must look at the basis of the problem, and that is the matter that I want to address today. We hear people talk about the Aboriginal problem in Australia: there is no one Aboriginal problem in Australia-there are thousands of different problems, all needing different solutions. Basically, those problems can be broken up into three groups-the communities, the fringe dwellers and the urban Aboriginals. While they overlap at the margins, they are clearly different groups.

SPEECH.PARA: In my electorate I probably have more Aboriginals than any other politician in Australia. The Kalgoorlie electorate is very under-enrolled, whereas the electorate of the Northern Territory is highly enrolled. However, there are many Aboriginal communities in my electorate. I want to put on record the fact that I get a very good vote out of Aboriginal communities. I get that vote because I do not lie to them, I do not make extravagant promises and I endeavour, wherever I can, to fulfil the promises that I make. While it is true that my electorate has so many Aborigines, it is also true that the western suburbs of Sydney have more. The problems that those people have are the hardest to address. Those people are generally disunited, they are broken into family groups, they tend not to vote and they have all the same problems in relation to alcohol that generally affect low income people. The problems are going to need an enormous effort to resolve.

These problems will not be successfully tackled under the umbrella of Aboriginal affairs. It is quite clearly a social security problem. However, I want to make the following point very strongly. It is a great failing of the system that in Australia we are confusing poverty culture with Aboriginal culture. One often hears the comment, `We must acknowledge their culture'. What people refer to as Aboriginal culture is in many cases nothing of the sort. We are merely enshrining a poverty culture because of some misguided belief in a multicultural society. That is the truth and a reality. Nothing can be achieved until this is recognised.

I want to deal for a moment with the question of freedom. What is freedom? If we said to people anywhere in the world that they could have political freedom or economic freedom, I can tell the House now that overwhelmingly they would take economic freedom first. They would always take economic freedom because that, inevitably, buys political freedom. Political freedom, which the Aboriginal people have had bestowed on them, does not, however, buy economic freedom. This might be a lesson to those people in society who seek to impose sanctions on South Africa. What they are doing, of course, is impeding the economic development of black Africa and therefore impeding political freedom. This is something that people should well and truly consider.

Some people seek to undertake measures out of an emotionally based compassion while others act for purely cynical reasons. I would suggest to the House that this occurs in Australia in respect of Aboriginal affairs. What is Aboriginal affairs policy about? Is it about advancing the position of Aboriginal people? Is it about raising their literacy levels and their health and housing standards? Those things have certainly been done, although often at the margins. Is not the question of Aboriginal affairs policy overwhelmingly about placating affluent urban white middle-class guilt? I suggest to the House-and let us not kid ourselves-that much of Aboriginal affairs policy is about exactly that. There has been a great success in this regard-such a success that we are now feeling the backlash. People are starting to talk about how much money has been put into Aboriginal affairs-and the honourable member for Cowper alluded to this. People are saying, `We have given so much help in this area, but nothing is happening'. Nothing is happening because we are going the wrong way.

We should be seeking to engender economic independence in these communities. There are many things that can be done, but I do not see them being done. I see obfuscation at every turn, with people tending to write off the endeavours of the communities. I find this very depressing. Why does this occur? One reason is that we have created an Aboriginal industry and people make a living out of serving this industry. It is a little bit like the position in relation to doctors: if the patient gets better, there is no work for the doctor. I suspect that there are many people in this `industry' who are simply serving their own self-interest by being there.

I have a high regard for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and many of the people in it. But it is a fact of life that the Department is hopelessly understaffed. The staff that it does have is hopelessly undertrained and works under extreme pressure. For those reasons, the Department is totally demoralised. Recently, when I was in western New South Wales an officer of the Department told me that the position was hopeless. He said, `I find myself competing with white people employed by Aboriginal communities who are far better educated than I. He said that they know all the ropes and all the lurks and that it is hard for him to compete. He also said that on top of that he spends all his time answering ministerial questions generated by these people and that he is never able to attend to the people who need his help. That is just so true. I see this sort of thing happening in my electorate every day of my life.

It is easy to criticise the Department when one finds that a community is suddenly $100,000 short in the store or that someone employed by the community has shot through with the funds and that no action has been taken. This is particularly frustrating for a person who has been saying to the Department that it ought to look at the situation. However, the Department cannot do so because it is understaffed, it does not have adequately trained staff and it does not have the necessary resources. Until these problems are addressed we will not get anywhere.

We have to think very carefully about what is happening in Aboriginal affairs, but let us not delude ourselves into thinking that this is a major problem for Australia, because it is not. Aboriginal people represent less than 2 per cent of the entire population. Two hundred years ago events changed irrevocably for Aboriginal people. They were taken over by a more advanced culture. There is no doubt about that. One can argue about whether it was a better or a worse culture, but that is irrelevant; it certainly was more advanced. It was a more warlike culture. By the standards of the day Aboriginals were not treated particularly harshly. I think Aboriginals can be thankful that they were not taken over by many other cultures that existed at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two left wingers do not like this.

—And I do not like the honourable member's interruptions. He ought to listen to this. We have to realise that if the major culture, while being very tolerant, feels pressed hard enough or sufficiently threatened, it will simply do it again. I am frightened that a backlash will be generated in the community. It is there, and it is growing. It is growing in the country towns such as Broome, where an Aboriginal person was murdered. He was interfering with a motor car. He may have been drunk, and he was probably slightly retarded. He was a pleasant chap, a fellow who would harm no one, but he was brutally murdered. There is no other word for it. The jury found the accused guilty of the lesser charge of manslaughter. I am pleased to say that the judge in his wisdom imposed the maximum penalty for manslaughter, and I hope the fellow serves it all. That is the sort of situation that is occurring as this backlash develops. Aboriginal people say to me, `Mr Campbell, we are frightened. Things are worse now than they were 12 months ago. They are a lot worse now than they were two years ago'. Every time the agenda boils this sort of thing happens. The people who will be the losers are the Aboriginal people, the people who had no say in it. The people who generate this backlash-many of the advisers and the professionals often in government departments-simply move on. They leave the people to carry the can-the people who have had no say in what has happened to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is just another mishmash, another rehash. It is not solving the problem, because Aboriginal people are sick to death of consultation. The concept of self-management was brought in as a noble view, but the reality is that self-management is a recipe for doing nothing. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs will say, `Yes, we understand, but until we get the community's agreement we cannot do anything'. Of course we cannot get agreement from the community. We can never get any community's agreement on this basis. I have known communities where there is consultation on where to put power poles. No such consultation takes place in my suburb; the power poles are simply put in. Communities have said to me, `We want police stations. Please give us police stations'. They want police stations for reasons that they understand. We say to them, `No, you have self-management; do it yourself'. We do not say those things to people in a white town. It is something we ought to think about. We spend millions of dollars on the Muirhead Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which will prove nothing and satisfy no-one, but we do not have the money to put police stations in communities where Aboriginal people are asking for them. That would go a long way towards addressing the problem. Certainly in Western Australia, of all government bodies, the police are probably the most respected by the community.

This is definitely an urban situation but, as I said earlier, it is not a uniform problem. Problems must be addressed with solutions that are appropriate. The truth is that the Department is engaged in crisis management but it does not have the ability to do anything else. When a community is in a state of crisis the Department looks good. It can smooth over that particular crisis. It probably sits back and waits for the next one to make sure that its existence is justified. This is an important debate. It is one that I believe deserves far more than 40 minutes. I regret that there is so little time to discuss this matter more fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who spoke so lucidly about this matter. I would like to congratulate also the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). It was refreshing to hear an honourable member on the Government side of the House speak with so much commonsense. It has obviously come from first hand experience of the problem rather than from a textbook. We have been witnessing a most disturbing trend in Australia in recent years towards divisions between ethnic groups. That is to be regretted.
—Promoted by the National Party.
—I see Jeff Fenech has entered the chamber. This division is nowhere more apparent than in the area of Aboriginal affairs.
—And you--

—If the honourable member for the Northern Territory will shut up instead of wanting to challenge everyone to a fight, as he does the Aborigines in his electorate, we might be able to get on with a proper debate. This Government seems to be hell-bent on separating 1 1/2 per cent of the population in this country from the other 98 1/2 per cent. It wants to do it not just by action but by legislation. It wants to justify this on the grounds of race and the colour of a person's skin. I say to Government members who are pursuing this course that it is a dangerous road to go down. It will lead, and is already leading, to unexpected and unfortunate consequences. I acknowledge that much of what those opposite intend to do, or are trying to do, is done with the best of intentions. Nevertheless, in doing so they are constructing a very precarious foundation on which to build a harmonious nation.

SPEECH.PARA: We know of the experiment back in the 1930s in Germany when Hitler tried to exterminate a race simply because they were Jews. That was obviously wrong; it was evil. It is interesting to note that he was a member of the German socialist labour party. There have been many examples around the world since then. There has been the South African experiment of separate development. While I have considerable sympathy for that country, the apartheid policy is both morally and economically wrong. There are worse examples such as that in Burundi where there is racial persecution. The ruling Tutsi tribe brutally persecutes the Hutu tribe solely on racial lines. There is racial discrimination in Malaysia. There is the caste system in India. We are witnessing the non-Amharic persecution in Ethiopia. All these types of discrimination are engaged in, no doubt, with the very best of intentions on the part of those who are ruling-for the overall good they would claim.

I say to Government members that wherever there is discrimination, wherever it is forced such as by a dictatorship or by legislation, even though the intentions may be good, it is always wrong. I would go even further and say that if we discriminate in society along such lines-even though we do so with good intentions-ultimately there will be a bad result. In fact, if we discriminate with good intentions, the suffering, misery and ultimate cruelty can end up being worse because it is more drawn out and more subversive. I know of no exception to this rule in the world. If on the grounds of race people are killed with viciousness, such as those in Burundi, or with kindness, as we see in Australia today, they are still being killed. If honourable members doubt that, they have only to see the tragic, premature shortening of Aboriginal life in my electorate.

There is no better example of discriminating with good intentions with ultimately bad effects than the example of what this Government is doing in Australia today. There are other examples of this around the world. We have seen what has happened to the Eskimos and to the North American Indians. Wherever governments have a patronising, chequebook mentality, we end up creating a race of people apart from the rest of mainstream society. Every other ethnic group in Australia-and there are many-is included in the mainstream society, but for some reason, we are hell-bent on separating 1 1/2 per cent of our population from the rest. The Aboriginal people in Australia today have ended up without dignity, education, jobs or pride. Unfortunately, they are being more and more resented by a large proportion of the remaining 98.5 per cent. So, we have Aborigines in a depressed and totally demoralised position.

On top of what has been done, we in the Parliament are now being presented with legislation for further separation of Aboriginal people. It is absolutely unbelievable. Australia is, or should be, one sovereign nation under one flag, not many nations under a number of flags. But, instead, this Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and this Government want to aggravate the situation with proposals to further and formally divide Australia. I say to the Government that Australians do not want to find themselves in the position of signing treaties with themselves. The concept of signing treaties with groups within a nation is a nonsense and it leads to all sorts of unforeseen consequences.

Back in about 1985 we saw the example of the National Aboriginal Conference, which was then in existence, wanting for people on Aboriginal land the right to be able to form their own foreign policy, for heaven's sake. Nowadays, we have this talk of a treaty and the separate development of a black parliament within Australia. All of this is building up unreal expectations which can never be realised and which will end up disappointing and disillusioning the Aboriginal race more so than it is now. It only feeds the stirrers and the malcontents, the Michael Mansells of this world, and gives them a higher public profile that they otherwise would not have. It causes resentment amongst the rest of the population-the backlash effect-and the Aboriginal people end up feeling cheated. The result is totally negative, and the cheap attempt of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to win votes by trying to instil guilt into the rest of the Australian population by offering compensation for what has been done in the past is totally ludicrous and is a divisive concept.

It is worthwhile recalling that most Aborigines who are alive in Australia today have a considerable proportion of non-Aboriginal blood in them. In other words, they would not be here today were it not for the migration programs that have taken place in this country over the past 200 years. Why should we single out the Aboriginal population for compensation? What about the Chinese, for example? There is no more persecuted ethnic group in Australia than the Chinese, if we look back at the history of what happened to them on the goldfields. If we consider that question, therein lies at least some of the answer to what we see happening to Aborigines in Australia today. In the end, the Chinese were left alone and today they are part of the overall mainstream of Australian society. They have done very well and, although they make up only a small proportion of the Australian society, they have made a great contribution to this country. The average Chinese family has paid a lot of tax since 1983, for instance. In contrast, average Aboriginal families have received, I think, $100,000 in grants since 1983. I put the question: which group is better off? I would say that the Chinese group is much further ahead.

I realise that this is an oversimplification of the situation; nevertheless, it points the way in which we should be going in Australia. This paper that I have in my hand indicates nine or 10 different grants for Aboriginal children to attend school. They will be available to no other colour, whether it be white, red, yellow or whatever. I know that these grants have been given with good intentions, but I refer to the following grants: an allowance for students living at home of $120 a fortnight; an allowance for students living away from home of $182 a fortnight; tuition fees paid up to $3,000 a year for approved boarders; fares between home and school; tutorial assistance to study ballet, art, craft, et cetera; an allowance for school excursions of $280 a year; orientation visits; grants for parents to attend parent meetings; travel for compassionate reasons; educational and vocational guidance, et cetera.

These grants are causing division in our society. We should make no separation between people based on colour. It is a recipe for disaster and will destroy the ethnic group at which it is targeted. By doing this we are treating people differently and then showing surprise when they end up acting differently. We are patronising these people by giving them handouts, something for nothing. This is not the direction in which we should be going. We should be aiming to bring them into the mainstream of Australian society so that ultimately they will have pride and dignity, so that they can get rid of the hand out mentality and start contributing to this great country.

Let us start to reverse the mistakes we have made. Let us reject this patronising behaviour and this Government's grand plan for separate development. As I say, let us restore dignity to this ethnic group and bring them back into the mainstream of Australian society so that they can make that contribution to it and so that we can start to advance this nation more than we are doing, for the ultimate advantage of us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that the speeches made by the National Party members in this debate have been two of the most disappointing speeches that I have heard since entering this House after the last election. They have demonstrated what I believe to be everything evil in terms of the myopic, ethnocentric view which is typical of the National Party, and, indeed, the Opposition parties and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who is sitting in this House. The speeches reflect the historical and cultural arrogance of the Opposition's approach to the issue of Aboriginal affairs and its total lack of compassion, feeling and understanding for Aboriginal perceptions, aspirations and needs as articulated by Aboriginal Australians. It reflects poorly on an Opposition which really has shown the division which exists between the Government and the Opposition on the issue of Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer quickly to a point made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I do so not only on my own behalf but also on behalf of my colleagues on this side of the House, particularly the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). It would do well for those people who do not understand the facts of history in this country, who have no knowledge of this country's present status in the international arenas of the world, if they would think about the matter. The Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal affairs ought to hear and understand this, because Australian history is absolutely littered with examples of genocide of Aboriginal Australians. It is not enough to say, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie said, that we have dealt with our indigenous people, the Aboriginal people, more kindly than if they were settled by another race. What absolute nonsense.

I ask the shadow Minister: What is the position of Aboriginal people in his State? What is the recognition that has been accorded to them by the State Government of Tasmania? What is the history of the genocide of Aboriginal people in his State? Does he understand it? Do these hicks from the bush, from western New South Wales, understand it? Do they support it? In my view, they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: we in the Opposition have been somewhat tolerant of the ravings of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, but I regard the term `hicks from western New South Wales' as unparliamentary and offensive and require a withdrawal.
—The Chair believes that the honourable member should withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it; but I can- not understand-and I reiterate-the Opposition's total ignorance and misapprehension, its lack of knowledge, understanding and compassion, and its uneducated mentality about the issue of Aboriginal affairs or multiculturalism in this country. It is instructional to read through the Notice Paper because the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who moved this motion, has another notice of motion to the effect that this House queries the benefits of multiculturalism to Australian society. That is where the National Party is coming from and that is where the Opposition is coming from.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not hear about this cosy relationship that the Augustus of the Opposition, the new Leader, has brought into this House. Let us not believe that members of the Opposition are talking about a united Australia, because it is clear from the motions moved by this person, who masquerades as a representative of the Australian people, that they are promoting division within the Australian society. The issue is very clear in relation to this motion. It is about giving special recognition to the needs and wishes of Aboriginal people. It is not about giving mainstream service delivery. It is about giving special recognition and regard to Aboriginal needs and it is about taking care to make sure that one gives Aboriginal people a right to articulate their own concerns, desires and wishes.

It is the policy of this Government to do that. It is within the realms of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation that that will happen. The legislation will be supported not only by Aboriginal people, but by the mass of the Australian community, as it has been, I might point out to those people on the Opposition benches who masquerade as churchgoing Christians, by the majority of the Christian churches in this country. It has been supported by all commentators outside this Parliament who have any understanding of Aboriginal affairs or the concerns of Aboriginal people in this nation. However, it is not supported significantly by the Opposition, nor is the issue of multiculturalism supported by the Opposition. That is the point which is significant about this debate, because it demonstrates the division, the chasm, which exists between the Opposition and the Government on policies such as the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country, the administration of immigration policies, and the policies and issues related to multiculturalism. That is what this debate is all about.

The cold, hard facts are that we have people in the Opposition who have views reminiscent of the views which oppressed Aboriginal Australians and Chinese Australians in the nineteenth century. They were the views of assimilation. One only has to look at the documents and read through the policy statements of the then Country Party, articulated by government decree in the 1950s and 1960s. Those statements were all about assimilation. Those views have absolutely nothing to do with the reality of the concerns of Aboriginal Australians. Those views have to do with oppression; with not allowing Aboriginal people the dignity they deserve in their own land.

I would suggest to Opposition members that they come with me around the Northern Territory or around north-west Western Australia and talk to Aboriginal people the way they talk to the community in this House about what they think of Aboriginal people. I know the resounding impact they will make on those people will be one of disdain and horror. Those are the facts. Aboriginal people will not accept the views of the Opposition. They will not vote for the Opposition in a pink fit and the Opposition knows it. Yet, the Opposition masquerades in here as a champion of oppressed people. It does not understand Aboriginal people; it does not care about Aboriginal people and it most certainly does not desire their votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired. The debate will be adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting. The honourable member will receive the opportunity to continue his speech when the debate resumes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep concern that the Tasmanian Government has:
(1) failed to take up significant Commonwealth initiatives which would have benefited the people of Tasmania;
(2) mismanaged the Tasmanian economy with the result that Tasmania has fallen behind every other State in key areas such as employment and growth; and
(3) failed to develop either a coherent economic strategy or a constructive working relationship with the national Government.

It should now be beyond question that Tasmania has failed to keep pace with the growth of the engine of the Australian economy. Under the Australian Labor Party, the national economy has gone through a period of quite significant growth. Unemployment has been falling and some commentators express the view that the national economy has become what they call overheated.

In Tasmania, after many years of Liberal administration, the Tasmanian economy has barely begun to warm up at all. Our economy is suffering. Our unemployment rate stands at 9.7 per cent; 3.1 per cent above the national average. Twenty per cent of our young people cannot find work. Contrary to the national trend, employment continues to fall. Tasmania has the lowest growth of building approvals of all States. During the period 1987-88, it experienced a net loss of 3,434 people. This is a tragedy. It is the reason why I have moved a resolution drawing the attention of this Parliament to those very sad statistics. I do so, not in order simply to say, `Look, Tasmania is in difficulty', but to point to what I believe is a constructive alternative for the people of Tasmania, the program put forward by the Labor Party in Tasmania and which I will turn to shortly.

Let us go through the points I have raised in this notice of motion. The first was Tasmania's failure to take up significant Commonwealth initiatives. One of the first points which drew this to my attention was that, in the course of my election campaign, I sought from the Federal Government a commitment to fund an inquiry into the parlous state of the Tasmanian tourist industry. The national tourist effort was obviously succeeding. Arrivals from overseas had risen dramatically, but in Tasmania we were not able to attract a significant component of those overseas visitors. The Commonwealth Government said it would make available the sum of $50,000, plus the cooperation of Tourism Australia to assist the State Government to look at the reasons why there were difficulties in this regard and to put forward constructive proposals. To this day I am still waiting for the State Government to accept what was surely a constructive proposal and to kick into a study which would have a beneficial effect on our important tourism industry in Tasmania.

It is not only in the areas of those proposals where the State Government has been unwilling to pick up the burden. We also have the problem of youth homelessness and the supported accommodation program; a tragedy, particularly in a State where youth unemployment is at 20 per cent. The State Government dickered, refusing for over 12 months to pick up that money before reluctantly being forced by public opinion to pick up money the Commonwealth had made available. Yesterday we heard in this House that the Commonwealth initiatives regarding proper respect for women in the work force had not been picked up by Tasmania. There are countless instances where the State has failed to respond constructively to initiatives introduced by the Commonwealth, which would have assisted Tasmania.

The second point I made in the notice of motion was that the Tasmanian Government had mismanaged the Tasmanian economy. That is self-evident. The record is there. I have mentioned some of the elements. I do not want to be negative in this approach. All I say is that any State Government which could put its head up and say that it is proud of the economic record it is leaving behind would be laughed out of court anywhere where a reasonable man was making a judgment.

Thirdly, I pointed out that the Tasmanian Government had failed to establish either a coherent economic strategy or a constructive working relationship with the national Government. Let us look at this business of coherent economic strategy. The State Government has relied on what I think is essentially a gambler's instinct. It has no policy that would allow it to go forward in a constructive and well-organised way. Instead, like the gambler who has got himself into hock, it has found itself making more and more desperate bids to somehow make that one big bet that will win back the house. Unfortunately, it is misjudging not only the mood of the Australian people but the mood of the Tasmanian people, because the Tasmanian people were not interested in putting forward a proposal to dam the Franklin River. Even the State Government's own economic and energy advisers of the Hydro Electric Commission now say that that proposal was an economic nonsense. We now have the latest proposal which has been put up as somehow being the economic salvation of Tasmania; that is, a pulp mill. The contortions, the backdowns, the evasions and the shoddiness of the Tasmanian Government's approach towards that proposal shows that it does not have a coherent economic strategy.

This failure to develop any coherent economic policy is reflected also by the State Government's approach to the proposal that Tasmania service some of the Russian fishing fleet, if the Soviet Union is granted approval to use Australian ports. When that proposal was first put forward it got the knee-jerk `reds under the bed' sort of reaction from the Deputy Premier in Tasmania, Ray Groom. Unfortunately, there are still some honourable members opposite-for example, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)-who persist with this knee-jerk `reds under the bed' negative approach to Tasmania's economy. Premier Gray has at least eventually seen wisdom on this point and has made strong representations to the extent of lending to us yesterday a senior official from his Department, the Premier's Department, to come with me to discuss this proposal with the Soviets and the senior Government Ministers involved. But that has happened only after months of agonising and backtracking. As a result, we are way behind the ball and chasing from behind. It is an appalling record.

Finally, I turn to the point about the lack of a constructive working relationship with the national government. When I was first elected, I remember an announcement being made about a road opening for the bypass around the Hobart roundabout. I remember seeing a picture of the smallest Minister in Australia, Minister Braid, and Nick Evers proudly cutting a ribbon announcing the opening of a roadway. But there was a failure to mention that every dollar of that roadway had been provided by the Commonwealth Government. Having milked this event for every piece of publicity they could get, there was then a formal opening some months later after the road was in use. This is just one instance where the Tasmanian Government tried to take credit for funds provided by the Commonwealth Government.

What about its much touted proposal for a forest industry package amounting to $50m. This big election campaign promise is just a rehash of what has already been given by way of funding from the Commonwealth under the Helsham heads of agreement. It has been repackaged. The Tasmanian Government has put its name on it and gives no credit to the Commonwealth. It continues to criticise the Federal Government falsely. It alleges that the Federal Government is responsible for a failure to fund when the reality is that every Tasmanian is funded to the extent of some $500 per capita more than the national average. That is the situation. I do not resile from that at all; it is appropriate. There are particular reasons why we in Tasmania need to have the sympathy and the support of the Commonwealth Government. But the Tasmanian Government criticises us every time. We get no credit when we give the Tasmanian Government money. It blames; it has no responsibility; and it is shameless. I am sure that when I sit down the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) will stand up and begin a tirade about why it is all the Federal Government's fault, refusing to accept that any of this malaise and mishmash of economic incompetence could be sheeted home to its own State colleagues. Tasmania is the only State which is falling behind, which has rising unemployment and which is losing people, who are moving away to find employment in other places.

There is a bright side. The Tasmanian Labor Party will cut away that kind of negativism and carping. Instead, it will work out a constructive program with the Commonwealth Government. More importantly, it will also work out a constructive program that involves all sectors of the Tasmanian community. It will involve the trade unions, the business community and all who have a significant input into the future development and growth of our State economy. The Labor platform calls, firstly, for an employment summit to be held early in the first term of the Labor government to provide a forum for the exchange of ideas for ways of creating more employment for Tasmanians. Apart from that constructive approach, it has specific promises that will do much to overcome the kind of negative knee-jerk nonsense that has been passed up for economic policy for far too long in Tasmania. In a key initiative, the new Labor Government will establish enterprise centres in each of the State's major regions-the first to be established in Launceston, followed by the north-west coast and Hobart-designed to foster and encourage the development of new enterprises and the expansion of existing firms. In addition, there will be a new export orientation which recognises that Tasmania has to market to the world.

One of the problems is that the Tasmanian Government has a loser's mentality. There are always little whingers. We need Tasmania to be an exciting place, looking forward to capturing part of a world market. We are not looking to sell to mainland Australia, which itself only has a limited market. We have to look to overseas markets, niche markets. Austrade has been right behind those few initiatives which are a ray of light for the Tasmanian economy. For example, industry in the Tasmanian agriculture area has shown some real prospect of growth. We need to look to these niche markets where we can sell to the world and not be satisfied with negative carping of the kind that so often passes for State Government policy. We cannot live in Tasmania with a cargo cult mentality where we seek to blame every failure of policy on the Federal Government, where we give no credit where credit is due and where we seek to blame even when a policy has been initiated by the Federal Government to the great benefit of the State. That is the way that we expect less sophisticated people in primitive societies to behave. It is not the way we expect people who govern a State of this country to behave.

It is important that we look forward in a positive way. Tastrade, the Labor Party's proposed new marketing authority, will look to the world. Tastrade will also be responsible for the development of other Labor initiatives designed to create new markets for Tasmanian goods. These will include the development of a new export label, designed to identify Tasmanian goods with quality and craftsmanship and to create a distinct Tasmanian market image; the enterprise of market outlets, shop fronts in other States and then in other countries; and an economic excellence week designed to enhance community awareness of the quality of Tasmania's products and the export opportunities available to the State. That will be underpinned by a project development fund which will specifically assist manufacturers to develop products for export. Linked into this will be payroll tax exemptions, jobs through training and a Tasmanian youth foundation to create job training opportunities for Tasmania's young people.

Contrast that with the negative knocking, blaming failure of the Liberal Government in Tasmania. I think everyone should make a choice based on that contrast. It is a choice between a group of people that has failed and failed and failed, that against the national trends has gone backwards. Tasmanians have an opportunity to make a historic choice, to act decisively and to elect a Labor government committed to a program which is comprehensive, looks to provide a coherent economic strategy and allows for an effective working relationship with the Federal Government. It is crucial to do that.

I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the opportunity to speak on these important issues. All Australia will be watching the results of the Tasmanian election on Saturday. I commend to the House and the people of Australia the very sensible proposals that have been put forward on behalf of the Labor Party. If anyone is left in any doubt, I point out that there is one party which has a program, a policy and an optimistic view of the future. If my fellow Tasmanians make the choice to stay with the failures that have inhabited the House of Assembly in Tasmania for the past half decade, I will be very surprised about the quality of their judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that even the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) would have the temerity to move in this House a motion such as the one before us. I can only conclude that he has been provoked into bringing on a debate such as this today because the Tasmanian election is to be held on Saturday and the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania is in sheer desperation because it knows it cannot win; that Mr Field has prevailed on the honourable member for Denison to bring forward this motion as an act of sheer political desperation. All I can do is admire the honourable member's tenacity in bringing it forward knowing that his Party will lose, and lose conclusively, on Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the accusations made by the honourable member for Denison about the Gray Government in Tasmania is that it has mismanaged the Tasmanian economy. The one thing that is different about the management of the Gray Government is that it is the only government in Australia that has consistently balanced its budget. It is the mentality of the Labor Party to do things on borrowed money. That is the great problem faced by this Federal Government. It borrows money and cannot live within its means. The honourable member for Denison obviously expects the Gray Government in Tasmania to do that as well. The Gray Government is the only responsible government in Australia, the only government that consistently balances its budget, yet the honourable member accuses it of bad economic management.

I will outline for the House some of the so-called initiatives of this Federal Government in respect of Tasmania and let the people make up their minds as to who has been mismanaging the affairs of Tasmania. Firstly, I refer to the sharing of taxes among the States. The State of Tasmania has had its share of Commonwealth taxes cut back by an average of $440m per year. In other words, if the financial arrangements that were in place under the Fraser Government were still in place, the Tasmanian Government would receive an additional $440m from the Commonwealth, which equates to 25 per cent of the State budget. That is how severe the Commonwealth's cut back to the State of Tasmania has been, yet the honourable member says that that is an initiative. I ask the people of Tasmania to be the judge. You talk about sharing on a per capita basis among the States. I point out that the Commonwealth's cutback to Tasmania on a per capita basis has been at the rate of $1,000 per man, woman and child. The average of all the other States has been cut back--

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense!
—Order! The honourable member for Denison has had the opportunity to address the House. The honourable member for Lyons might address the Chair rather than honourable members in the first person.

—I will be happy to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I point out that the average cut back to all the other States, has been $500 per man, woman and child. In Tasmania, the cut back has been double that, at the rate of $1,000 per man, woman and child. Let us look at the capital works program. What has happened in Tasmania? The Commonwealth's own projection for capital works activities in Tasmania for the next two years is the expenditure of $17.3m, which is an average of $38 per man, woman and child. Capital works expenditure in all the States amounts to an average of $145 per man, woman and child. Who in their right mind could claim that that is a fair initiative for the State of Tasmania?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us keep going. The honourable member for Denison in his contribution referred to the very dramatic cutbacks in employment in Tasmania. We are all concerned about the unemployment rate in Tasmania. I remind the honourable member for Denison of the Callaghan Inquiry into the Structure of Industrial and the Employment Situation in Tasmania, which was tabled in 1977. Perhaps the honourable member was not in this place at that time. It was a most exhaustive inquiry into the problems faced by the State of Tasmania. The Callahan report pointed out that if Tasmania had the same average employment opportunities provided by Commonwealth activities in other States-in other words, in armed services, Commonwealth public servants and that type of Commonwealth activity-there would be an additional 5,000 jobs in Tasmania. Yet the honourable member claims that the Commonwealth is taking initiatives on behalf of Tasmania. What absolute rubbish!

If the Commonwealth was being fair to the State of Tasmania, as it is to the other States, particularly those governed by Labor, there would be a considerable increase in economic activity in Tasmania. However, that is not the case. The actions of the Commonwealth are consistently retarding economic growth in Tasmania.

I will press on, because I have not yet finished my remarks on Commonwealth activities and Commonwealth employment in Tasmania. I remind honourable members of another fact: The Commonwealth is also cutting back on those jobs it provides in Tasmania. In fact, since 1984 the Commonwealth has reduced its payroll in Tasmania by 867 Commonwealth jobs. That is, 867 Commonwealth jobs have been withdrawn from Tasmania. The most recent withdrawal was the withdrawal of 72 jobs from the Australian Taxation Office. This is another so-called Commonwealth initiative for Tasmania. The Commonwealth consistently overrides the State of Tasmania in respect of allowing Tasmania to develop its own resources. Perhaps that is the most negative thing that the Commonwealth has done--
Mr Kerr interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—Let me remind the honourable member for Denison of the findings of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests which was set up by the Commonwealth to look into the forest industry in Tasmania. The Helsham Commission recommended certain things, but what did the Commonwealth do? Contrary to the findings of the Helsham Commission, set up by the Commonwealth Government, the Commonwealth locked up 257,000 hectares, nine times the forest area of national parks recommended by the Commission. Again, in the case of the Wesley Vale pulp mill, the Commonwealth has overridden the State of Tasmania. The Commonwealth has prevented that great initiative, which in itself would have created 2,000 jobs and would have allowed investment of $1,000m in Tasmania to develop its resources. For political expediency and to attract support from the conservation movement, the Commonwealth Government has again overridden the State of Tasmania and prevented that great development going ahead, depriving 2,000 people of jobs in Tasmania. Yet the honourable member for Denison has the temerity to come into this House and claim that it is mismanagement on the part of the Tasmanian Government that is holding back the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the House, to those listening to this broadcast and to the people of Tasmania that if there has been mismanagement of the Tasmanian economy, if Tasmania has experienced deprivation under any government, it has come from the Hawke Government and the very negative attitude it has adopted towards the State of Tasmania.

I can only assume that when the election is held on Saturday the response of the people of Tasmania towards the Labor Party will be made well known in the ballot box, and that is where it counts. I can assure the honourable member for Denison and this House that, when the votes are counted on Saturday night, the people of Tasmania will make well known what they think of this Commonwealth Government and the Labor Party. I am quite certain that the people of Tasmania will want their State developed in the way in which the Gray Government has put its program forward, through a balanced budget and proper development of our own natural resources.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grievance debates are a procedure in this Parliament for honourable members to talk about issues that they believe in their judgment are extremely important and ought to be brought to the attention not only of the House but of the nation. Today I want to talk about one of the victims of this Government's activities, one that we do not talk about very often but one that I think many of us on both sides of the House are aware of, and that is the people who live in regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think regional Australia over the last seven years of the Hawke Government, has had a raw deal. There has been a concentration in politics on meeting the needs of those in capital cities. My view, as I represent a regional area, is that there needs to be a balanced approach in the development of policy and government initiatives. In the course of the Hawke Government's time in office I have seen a concentration to support people in areas where the votes are, and therefore an abrogation of responsibility to look after those who live in regional areas.

If we want to quantify it, if we can, the ones who have had the raw end of the deal, the worst treatment, and who live in the regions of Australia which have suffered most at the hands of the Hawke Government, are Tasmanians. We have just heard a debate in this chamber about Tasmania because there is to be an election. If this election were not going to take place, the issue that I raise today-that is, the victims who are living in regional Australia-I think would still be a question for discussion. What has happened is, I think, quite clear. There has been a calculated attempt by the Hawke Government to direct Commonwealth funding to those areas where it believes it can maximise its votes. We have seen a classic example in the environmental debate. We have a self-confessed born again greenie in Senator Richardson. He has sniffed the political wind in the outer suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne and he believes that in addressing their needs he will get more votes, and the best way to do that is to work against the best interests of development in regional Australia.

Allegations have been made that the Tasmanian economy is on the slide. In fact, the economy in Tasmania has been on the up and up. It was quite interesting to hear some of the figures that were cited previously. The Gray Government has in fact boosted business investment in a wide range of industries. In 1982-83 capital expenditure per head was $529 per annum compared with a national average of $1,028 per year. By 1986-87 new business investment had increased to $909 per head against a national average of $1,093. So Tasmania has grown tremendously in terms of business investment. Business believes that there are opportunities in regional Australia, and the Wesley Vale debate is a classic example. One may have views as to whether or not that proposal ought to have proceeded on environmental grounds. Those on this side of the House, and indeed a large number of those in the Cabinet, thought that it ought to proceed. The point I make is that business saw that there were opportunities in regional Australia. That is not the case with the Hawke Government. It has blatantly directed government activity away from regional Australia and particularly away from Tasmania.

The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) in his speech detailed in quite accurate terms the movement of Commonwealth activity right out of Tasmania. There have been dramatic drops. The level of capital works in Tasmania has dropped tremendously as well. It has also been dealt a harsh blow with all the allocations of Commonwealth public servants. I think he quoted the Australian Taxation Office which increased its staff by 4 per cent in Tasmania and by 30 per cent in Western Australia. The Department of Administrative Services is up 2 per cent in Tasmania but up 15 per cent in New South Wales. Tasmania, being part of regional Australia, has been the testing ground for this Government's political strategy, and we are suffering because of it. There have been a whole range of other things that this Government has taken away from Tasmania, and a whole range of issues that it has not addressed. Some $6m in airline assistance was taken away. The Helsham Inquiry into the forestry package has been minimal. There are not nearly sufficient funds there for one of Australia's greatest and growing industries that needs to be developed on a sustainable yield basis and to have proper forestry practices.

. Let us look at the wheat issue. One of the unsung issues with regard to the wheat debate has been the effects that issue will have on Tasmania. The effects of this Government's policy may well mean that Tasmania, for the first time in some 40 years, will have an increase in the price of bread above that of anywhere else in Australia. The equalisation of basic commodity bread prices in the shops to ordinary consumers right around the nation was an instrument of policy supported by both sides of this chamber for many years. But because of this Government's neglect and its inability to address the issues, it has decided to walk away from supporting Tasmania, and in a calculated way-I admit that negotiations are still proceeding-it has left Tasmanian consumers facing higher bread prices.

We have talked about tourism. Tasmania is a gem of an island. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been there. Many of us have been there. Some of us live there. We love the place. It is a wonderful place to visit. To hear the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), a Tasmanian, earlier decry the efforts of the Tasmanian tourism industry, saddens me and my colleagues on this side of the House. We have been trying for many years to develop that industry, but what help have we got? This Government was asked to take one initiative, and that was the initiative to set up the centre for tourism studies in Australia, and where did it go? We suggested that it should go to Launceston in northern Tasmania, but it came to Canberra. Where is the policy about making sure that the rest of Australia shares in Government activity? Tasmania is certainly not considered.

There is lots of rhetoric from the other side of the House, but once we look at the record we find that it shows a completely different intention. What is to happen to the national fish laboratory, the laboratory that determines fish export licensing and the quality of fish? We heard the honourable member for Denison talk about the growth of aquaculture, the new multi-million dollar industry in Tasmania, which has great potential. We are the greatest exporters of live fish and new and exotic fishes in the nation. We need that national fish health reference laboratory in Tasmania, but it is proposed that it go to Geelong.

When is regional Australia going to get an opportunity to be involved in some of these activities? That was a classic example of where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) could have made a positive decision in favour of Tasmania. But again we were the victims, as we have been for some seven years. There is no doubt about it, Tasmania's economy has been growing, perhaps not at the rate that we would all hope that it would, but we have to remember that there are 450,000 people in Tasmania. Let me make this point about exports and new industries: the value that Tasmania adds to the export values that accrue to this nation has been in the positive ledger since Federation. We have been exporting minerals and agricultural products in a positive way since Federation. There has not been one year when the exports from Tasmania have been in the deficit. We have been positive contributors. It is all right to look for new industries, but the important point-and this is the point I make consistently during science debates-is that we must support our comparative advantages. Our comparative advantages are enhancing those areas in which we do well now-our minerals, forestry, fishing and agriculture. They are the areas we need to be enhancing. We need to be adding value to those.

There was an attempt to do that with Wesley Vale. This Government, through its ineptitude, stopped that proposal dead in its tracks. The economic decisions were made to proceed. Other proposals will come forward. We do not want the regional areas in Australia that rely on these industries, and have done since Federation, to employ their communities, to add value to their communities and to make sure that their communities continue; we do not want those types of activities that took place regarding Wesley Vale, to be in any way a detriment to future development. Development must be balanced and must take into account environmental issues. There is no doubt about that. There is universal support for that. At the same time, we want a government that recognises regional Australia, that does not see regional Australia as being expendable and that does not treat it as a victim and its people as though they do not deserve proper consideration.

The role of government is to govern for all Australians in a fair and equitable manner. Tasmania has not been treated fairly and equitably, and the figures show it. The Tasmanian people know it and if those people, wherever they sit in this chamber, look objectively at the issue, they will know it as well. A calculated political campaign to win votes in capital cities will not reap the Government a reward at the end of the day, because regional Australia will vote against it. That is what is going to happen in Tasmania this weekend. Honourable members opposite hope that there will be a real swing towards the Australian Labor Party. This will not occur because the people of Tasmania know that they are not being treated well, that they are being treated as victims and as second class citizens by Labor. This Government will rue the day that it did not look after Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today my grievance relates to the renewed interest in Queensland of the State Government's confrontationist voluntary employment agreements legislation. Honourable members who take an interest in Queensland affairs will remember that the concept of voluntary employment agreements was first raised some years ago by the former Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Many in Queensland believed that voluntary employment agreements, otherwise known as VEAs, had disappeared along with the political fortunes of that former Premier. Regrettably, the National Party of Australia in Queensland, under its new leader-I use the term very loosely-has seen fit to breathe life into the VEA legislation again and in fact provide financial encouragement to business to opt out of the tried and true conciliation and arbitration process. His motives for doing so must be questioned.

SPEECH.PARA: For more than a year of his leadership of the National Party, Mr Ahern was quite happy to have VEAs languish on the industrial relations agenda and do absolutely nothing about them. His Government is now under siege, due to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and due also, in no small part, to his dithering style of leadership. These things will culminate this weekend in an inevitable loss for the Nationals in the Merthyr by-election caused by the resignation of that former National and former Liberal, Don Lane. Queensland and Tasmania are holding very important elections this Saturday. There is no doubt in my mind that both conservative governments will receive quite a jolt.

I want people in Queensland who are listening to this broadcast not to forget the fact that Don Lane, the disgraced Minister who was forced out of the Party and out of the Parliament, was a Liberal member before he became a National. People should not forget this. With all of this going on around him, it is obvious that Mr Ahern very badly needs an issue which he perceives will restore the community's confidence in him as a leader. The issue which he has chosen, I believe very unwisely, is the issue of forcing voluntary employment agreements onto the work force. The problem Mr Ahern has is that things are not working quite his way. For a whole range of very good reasons, the community at large and, importantly, the business community are rejecting voluntary employment agreements in that State. The union movement is united in its opposition to VEAs and is acting with utmost responsibility to discredit the concept. The unions have not, as Mr Ahern would have liked, reacted by taking to the streets picketing and striking.

The experience in Queensland on voluntary employment agreements is one of which the Federal Opposition should take very careful notice. The Liberal Party of Australia, and certainly the National Party, would wish to introduce workers' contracts as an alternative to the conciliation and arbitration process. This is still the case notwithstanding the recent change in the leadership of both parties. Nobody should be fooled into believing otherwise. The fact is that VEAs in Queensland have been a complete disaster.

I would like to go through the dangers and issues behind voluntary employment agreements in the hope that anyone who currently thinks that there might be some good in VEAs will be convinced otherwise. The Ahern Government's actions have been highly irresponsible in the current climate of restraint by the union movement and its participation in a wage system which is bringing about very real benefits for this country. Mr Ahern is, essentially, inviting workers to opt out of the centralised wage fixing system of which this Federal Government has striven to convince unions to remain a part. Unions have responded magnificently to that call and have stayed within the national wage system.

For example, in the Power Brewing issue in Queensland, the workers and their unions could quite easily go outside the wage fixation guidelines and organise a better deal with the company. But no, the unions are hamstrung by the very fact that they want to do what the Federal Government has asked the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the whole of the union movement in this country to do; that is, to try to keep wages at a manageable level. The union is hamstrung because it is trying to do the right thing but the Government is trying to prod business into causing confrontationist attitudes between unions and employers.

The most important thing that Queensland workers should recognise is that by accepting voluntary employment agreements they could be denying themselves the opportunity to cash in on the benefits of the award restructuring which is presently going on throughout the country. VEAs mean that the Queensland industrial relations system is on an entirely different track to that of the rest of the country. The restructuring of awards which is going on in the rest of the country to the benefit of both employers and employees will not occur in Queensland as a result of that legislation.

The Queensland media in recent times has been full of stories about how workers are embracing voluntary employment agreements. The two latest examples are employees of the Metway Bank Ltd and, as I previously mentioned, the Power Brewing Co. Ltd. In both of these cases it is true that employees have voted in favour of VEAs. What the union movement has noticed, however, is that employees in these organisations who are supporting voluntary employment agreements are those who have been with these firms for a very long time-or at least for a considerable amount of time. This has meant that management of the companies has had the opportunity to persuade many of the employees over a long period, at close quarters, to support the agreements. There is very little support among those who have joined the organisations in recent times. Those who have not been got at by management can see right through those voluntary employment agreements.

Some of the evils of the typical voluntary employment agreement include the abolition of penalty rates, no commitment to minimum retrenchment payments, no protection against unfair dismissals, no provision for consultation before any major changes to employment, and the fact that the agreement can be changed at any time. Workers in Queensland should be warned about what they are trading in exchange for, in some cases, only slightly higher pay.

One of the dangerous features of the VEAs is that they need to be renewed between employers and employees every so often. Despite the fact that employees may be better remunerated during the period of the first voluntary employment agreement which they sign, there is nothing to suggest that the next voluntary employment agreement which they sign will contain the same remuneration. In other words, in many respects it is a bit of a con job. It is my belief that the aims of those employers who are supporting voluntary employment agreements is to do away with all the benefits by conning workers into accepting a temporarily higher wage and then, in the second VEA, doing away with that higher wage.

In speaking on the topic of voluntary employment agreements, I do not want to give too much credence to the concept. After all, only 15 voluntary employment agreements have been registered with the Commission in the 15 months since the idea was first mooted. The overwhelming majority of Queensland employers have been responsible and have not rushed to take up the State Government's offer of backing to introduce voluntary employment agreements. In fact, the Queensland Confederation of Industry has expressed severe reservations about the system. The reality is the majority of employers are quite happy in the knowledge that the currently existing industrial relations system is working very well despite a massive public relations effort by the Government to convince employers to take up voluntary employment agreements. The Queensland industrial relations Minister, Mr Lester, has admitted that the National Party Government financially assisted a test case by a company called Mini Movers. How would the Opposition in this place feel if this Government decided financially to assist a trade union in a test case? It would not like it at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you have done it.

—The shadow Minister would not like it at all. The situation is in no way different and in both cases it is completely inappropriate. As well as this completely inappropriate expenditure the Government has also wasted public funds by producing a letter and brochure on voluntary employment agreements to seek assistance from employer organisations, lawyers and specialist industrial consultants about VEAs. It is refusing employees the right to any such professional assistance through their unions.
