So we have the ridiculous situation of hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' funds being spent by the Queensland State Government to send out colourful brochures in order to try to convince what one would expect to be its own supporters to try to convince their workers to support these VEA contracts.
—It is a waste of money.

—It is a complete waste of money, but in Queensland, as we all know, as the honourable member for Fisher says, when it comes to wasting taxpayers' money on advertisements and promotional material to prop up that ailing government, it is always able to find the money, but it cannot find the money for important things.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I refer to a Courier-Mail article which appeared on Tuesday, 28 February this year. The article was headed, `VEA cuts pay-Power workers'. In the article a Power brewery worker said that he had been conned by accepting the VEA agreement. He explained that he had earned $135 less in the week ending 14 February than he would have if he had worked for the Castlemaine brewery under award conditions. His conclusion was that he had been conned-and he had been, of course. I warn all Queensland workers not to be so gullible as to believe that the State National Party Government, which has never in the past supported workers' rights, will help them on this occasion. This whole campaign and issue is a complete fabrication to try to get the community on side before a crucial by-election and a State election at the end of the year. The sad thing for the National Party is that its tactic will not work. The union movement, the Labor Party, business and community generally are one step ahead of it, and will remain one step ahead of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) talked about some of our prisoners of war. Any person who heard his speech could only feel very much in debt to those people who were prepared to serve their country and also a certain sense of shame that the honourable member had to bring up their case in the way in which he did.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I would like to talk about something else that is being done to our returned servicemen; in particular, what is being done to those who wish to apply for a pension. A returned serviceman is someone who has served his country and who has been prepared to go overseas to do so. Many of them left school when they were young and, in any case, have probably had no formal education since that time-well over 40 years ago. Those people, in good faith, because they are eligible, seek a pension. Imagine their reaction when they are told not only that they will have to undergo a medical examination-that is probably fair enough; everyone would expect that-but also that they are expected to fill in a lifestyle report which is a bit like a school examination. I will give more details of that. This report has to be filled out by the servicemen; they have to answer questions which in some cases are clearly trick questions and in many cases are extremely intrusive into what should be private matters. In fact, so embarrassed are many members of the Veterans Affairs' Department that they ask the veterans not to talk about the forms and not to show them to anyone else.

It is clear that these forms were designed, approved and promoted by this Labor Government. I think that if all Government members knew what they had authorised they would be horrified. The form represents a gross intrusion of privacy. We have been through the saga of the ID card. Everyone realised what would occur-that records of people's private financial affairs would be kept on a computer; and that it would invade the privacy of all Australians. In this case, something similar is occurring, but it is applying only to veterans.

No doubt some people have thought, `This little examination form is very good; it will certainly create some extra jobs, because think of all the people who are going to have to mark the exam'. But it is much more serious than that. I think people ought to look very closely at this invasion of privacy and, more importantly, they should ask whether this form is actually necessary. It should be remembered that, as well as the assets test and the income test, the Government now wants veterans to bare their souls for the sake of a government requirement as to pension eligibility. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table a copy of this report, about which I will now give more details.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This report which the veteran is asked to fill in begins, fairly predictably, by asking for a few personal details such as name, date of birth, et cetera, and then asks for a few details about the veteran's potential problems. It asks: `Do you have any problems walking? Do you need something to help you move around-for example, crutches or a wheelchair? If yes, what do you use? Do you use the device all of the time or only sometimes?'. Okay, maybe that is fair enough. It asks: `Do you need someone to help you move around or to go with you?'. That is okay. It then asks: `Do you drive a car?'. Well, maybe that is all right. It asks: `Are there any restrictions on your ability to sit in, or to drive a car? If yes, please describe the restrictions. Are there any forms of transport which you normally use, but have difficulty using?'. If the answer is `yes', the veteran must give details. One might say that so far the form is reasonably straightforward. But it ensures that nothing is missed out by asking: `Are there any forms of transport you cannot use?'. So it makes sure that the veteran really cannot get it wrong.
—Many people can't get onto trams. That is a reasonable question. Try getting on a tram when your're that age.

—The Minister should wait until he hears a few more. I agree with him, but some of the questions are an invasion of privacy. The form asks: `Are there any things that affect your ability to get around?'. That is okay; I agree that it is reasonable to that point. But a doctor can find that out without the veteran having to fill in a little examination form. It then asks about personal relationships. This is where people really start to bare their souls. The form asks: `Which of the following statements apply to you? Mark all of the boxes which apply to you'. The statements beside the boxes include these: `I am going through a bad spell at the moment'; `I am able to cope with my life with the help of a few drinks'; `I feel contented with my life'; `My life is completely ruined'; `I am usually relaxed and get on well with most people'; `I often get cranky'. These questions are asked by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, authorised by this Government.
—It is worse than the ABS.

—It is. The honourable member should have another look at this form. Other `personal relationships' questions include: `I am sometimes tense and a little anxious'-it could apply to some people here occasionally-`but I still get on well with most people most of the time'; `I am often tense and irritable'; `I have to depend on other people a lot'; `I do not sleep well'. Veterans are asked to tick the appropriate box. The questions continue: `How would you describe your life with your family? Very full, active and satisfying? Good most of the time? Good only some of the time? Unsatisfactory? Very poor with little or no enjoyment?'. Those who have no family can mark the appropriate box. The next question is: `Does your disability affect your life with your family? If yes, please describe'. This is the next question: `How would you describe your social life? Very full, active and satisfying? Unsatisfactory and not enjoyable? Very poor with little or no enjoyment?'. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) may like to listen to these questions: `Does your disability affect your social life? If yes, please describe. Has there been a change in the way you get on with other people since the disability occurred or got worse? Do you have any problems with your hearing?'. The doctor would ask a person that, anyway.
—These are doctors' questions, not government departments' questions.

—Of course they are doctors' questions but these have to be answered in this examination form and corrected by someone in the Department. I am sure honourable members will agree that question No. 16 is an extraordinary invasion of privacy. I will read it out carefully: `Does your disability or disabilities affect your sexual feelings or abilities?'.
—What?

—I will repeat it: `Does your disability or disabilities affect your sexual feelings or abilities?'. The veteran must mark one of these boxes: `Yes'. `No', `Sometimes', or `Affected by medication'. I think there should be another box marked `None of your business'. There is provision for the veteran, if he wishes, to elaborate on his answer to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: There are questions about employment and domestic activities. One of the questions is: `How well can you do the following things?'. The veteran then has a choice of six different options which are described as follows: `Easily', `With difficulty', `With help', `If I take my time', `I can't do it', or `I don't need to'. The list of activities includes grocery shopping, house cleaning, washing up, and minor house repairs, although what the hell that has to do with it, I do not know. If one rents a house, I am not sure whether one would be expected to do that sort of thing. Other activities listed are light gardening, such as weeding or watering, or heavy gardening, such as digging and pruning trees. I do not know what happens if one does not have a garden, and one is not asked whether it is a large or small garden. Lawn mowing is also listed. One is not asked what sort of lawnmower one has, but it does ask if one can mow the lawn. The final activity listed is washing the car.

The next section asks: `Are there any domestic activities you have stopped because of your disabilities? Are there any domestic activities which take you longer to do than they used to? Are there any activities which you need help with?'. The next question is interesting as it might relate to another matter: `Do you have to pay someone else to do things that you used to do?'. In other words, it is asking, `Have you got the money? Maybe you can afford to go without the pension, anyway'. It is a bit of a trick question. No doubt some people would be a little nervous about that. The next question is, `Are there any home duties that you have recently started to do? If yes, do these duties have an effect on your disability? Are you presently employed?'. Those who are still working must give details about their occupation. These questions are asked: `Have you changed jobs in the last five years? Are there things you can't do at work that you used to do? Have you changed your workplace?'. Those who have stopped working-just to make sure no-one misses out-have to outline when they stopped working, why they stopped working, whether it was due to age, ill health, or other reason; if there are reasons, they must give details. It then asks: `Do you intend to seek employment?'.

Section 4 relates to recreation and community activities. Veterans are asked: `How often do you do the following activities?'. The choices are, `everyday', `a little', `weekly', `monthly', `rarely', and `never'. The activities listed include visiting or having visitors-I am not sure what that has to do with it; anyway, someone wants to find out-going out, such as to church, to watch sport or for entertainment; and playing a sport. Veterans should be careful, as that is a trick question: it could be golf, tennis, bowls or fishing, but the sport cannot actually be categorised. Other activities include doing a hobby, relaxing-everyone does that, I would have thought-and doing voluntary work, such as with Meals on Wheels or Legacy. People can describe the activities in one line. Then we see these questions, `Are there any other activities that you do? Are there any activities you have given up because of your disabilities? Question No. 32 reads, `Do you have difficulties doing, or taking up, any recreation activities?'. Clearly, these are trick questions to make sure that if one contradicts what one wrote in the earlier part of one's examination, one will fail the examination. I believe that this is a gross invasion of privacy and the Government should rethink what it has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In an unconvincing attempt to explain away his ministerial incompetence in the administration of drought relief, the Queensland Primary Industries Minister, Mr Harper, misled State Parliament on 4 April 1989. In a ministerial statement Mr Harper said he had not been aware of any irregularities in the scheme up to two years ago. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I did act promptly when the concerns of the officers in charge of the drought secretariat became known to me not two years ago but at the end of last year.
Yet on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Rod Henshaw program Mr Harper said:
As I say, I have been counselling these matters for the best part of two and a half years.

Which of Mr Harper's statements can we believe-his statement in Parliament or his confession on morning radio? In fact, what Mr Harper deliberately suppressed in his ministerial statement was a Cabinet minute of 24 August 1987. The then Acting Premier and Treasurer, Mr Gunn, passed on a warning to Mr Harper after Mr Harper recommended several ineligible shires to be declared drought stricken in 1987. The Treasury warning said there was little doubt the drought-declared areas were experiencing difficult conditions but none qualified for assistance in terms of the guidelines. the Cabinet submission said:

Any absence of clear guidelines for area drought declarations on aberrations from the established guidelines could well provoke Commonwealth intervention into the State's administration of drought relief.
Mr Harper's ministerial statement is misleading. He knew it was, and in a radio interview on 17 April Mr Ahern appeared to know quite well the circumstances surrounding the 1987 incident.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shonky.
—It is terrible. As the member for Bowman says, it is shonky. Mr Harper knowingly misled the Parliament and Mr Ahern should demand his resignation for that alone.
—He should resign.

—As the member for Fisher says, he should resign. Mr Harper has never shown any prior concern about the rorts in the guidelines for national drought relief assistance. My own electorate has experienced drought conditions in some areas for a number of years. The National Party has embarked on a misinformation campaign to confuse my electorate. In one case, one National Party stooge actually used the issue as a basis for his preselection campaign in Hinkler. I am well aware of the way the Nationals have looked after their mates, to the exclusion of the overwhelming majority of primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several other aspects of this scam which I wish to bring to the House's attention. All honourable members will recall the lousy loans affair involving a National Party organiser who incorrectly received money after the intervention of a former National Party primary industry Minister. In 1986 Senator Walsh wanted an investigation of Queensland's actions. The then Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, said he had no intention of investigating, or cooperating with a Federal investigation. Indeed, in an article in the Brisbane Telegraph of 24 September 1986 Mr Bjelke-Petersen said, `Why should we cooperate? I know what he is after'.

In April last year I called for an investigation into the scheme on behalf of my constituents in Burnett and Isis. My call was answered in my local newspaper, the Bundaberg News Mail. The article said:

The State Finance Minister, Mr Austin, denied Mr Courtice's claim that the administration of relief funding should be investigated to restore confidence in the scheme. The State Auditor-General had reviewed and certified the scheme.

Mr Austin was quoted as saying, `How could Mr Courtice then fault the State Government's efforts?'. This is a total contradiction and undermines Mr Harper's sham and concern about the scheme. Mr Harper said in Parliament that he was pleading to change the system, while his Cabinet colleague said there is nothing wrong with it. The truth is that Mr Harper cannot be trusted. His actions, since an internal departmental memo became public, do not promote public trust and confidence.

Let us look at his reaction. When first pressed on the allegations contained in the departmental memo on drought irregularities he dismissed the memo as the work of a junior officer. In fact, the public servant was head of Queensland's drought secretariat. He was a long-standing, well-respected beef husbandry officer who was seconded to the position. For his trouble in writing the memo, the public servant was transferred by Mr Harper. This heavy-handedness was followed by the sending in of the police to terrorise public servants, to scare them out of testifying before the Public Accounts Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Branch.

—As the honourable member for Fisher says, the Special Branch-it is something that happens in South America and it is tragic that it is happening in Queensland. The issue was referred to the Committee. Again, Mr Harper refused to act in a responsible manner. The Public Accounts Committee's preliminary report found that the Primary Industries Minister's response to the memo was cursory and did not address the specific issues raised by Daly.

SPEECH.PARA: The preliminary report stated that Mr Harper issued a press release which said that the State's 1988-89 Budget announced a revitalisation of local drought committees. The report stated that this revitalisation was to involve the drought secretariat, but by 13 December 1988-the date of the drought memo-the drought declaration problems referred to by Daly had not been addressed by the revitalisation. So Mr Harper was caught out in the preliminary report by the Public Accounts Committee.

Mr Harper has a penchant for dishonesty and maladministration. His ministerial incompetence is legendary. As Justice Minister he turned a blind eye to the Sturgess report's warning of possible corruption in the licensing branch of the Queensland police force, and of course we are fully aware of the subsequent matters that have flowed from the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. A former public servant in the Department of Primary Industries (DPI), Mr Clive Sellwood, passed this commentary on the system Mr Harper has presided over in his administration of drought relief:
You could drive a truck through some of the holes in the scheme and some owners have been getting away with hundreds of thousands of dollars for years.
An officer with over 30 years experience phoned my office to say that DPI officers were under tremendous pressure over declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is criminal.

—As the member for Bowman says, it is criminal. The problem is that they feared that if they knocked back prominent National Party members in some areas, senior officers would tell them not to rock the boat. If they are paying off a home and have a young family, the last thing they want to do is to be sent to Birdsville or somewhere like that for making trouble. What do they do? They accept the pressure that is brought to bear on them; they have no other choice. It is a sad indication of the way in which the Department of Primary Industries has been run in Queensland for many years. The officer said there was a constant threat of a punitive transfer hanging over any officer's head.

SPEECH.PARA: These are serious allegations. I hope that the Public Accounts Committee inquiry will be able to bring all this out into the open. What we need in Queensland is decent, open, accountable and honest government. Mr Harper's sending in of the secret police shows the desperate lengths to which he is prepared to go to prevent the truth coming out. Even in Daly's memo, there are no names mentioned-possibly because he feared his Minister's reaction. If the Special Branch has been sent in, as I said, it is no wonder that he was fearful.

There are many grounds on which Mr Ahern should sack Mr Harper. Mr Ahern has failed to provide effective leadership and has not demanded the resignation of someone who has so pathetically failed the overwhelming majority of primary producers in Queensland. Politically, Mr Harper is a walking disaster and it is about time Mr Ahern gave him a political burial for misleading Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has to go.

—As the member for Bowman said, he has to go. On that note, I think it is timely that on Saturday, in the Merthyr by-election in Queensland, the public will have an opportunity to show what it thinks of the way in which the National Party has run Queensland for the last 30 years. I am very confident-and I am sure my colleagues the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) and the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) are, too-that we will see an overwhelming rejection of the National Party on Saturday. This week we have already seen the Speaker take the unprecedented action of challenging the Premier, Mr Ahern. I think Mr Ahern will lose his position after Saturday. Cooper is already getting the numbers. It is only a matter of time before the National Party crumbles from within.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing in Queensland is a return to the days of Rome. We are seeing that total power corrupts. That corrupt power, which has been maintained by gerrymandered boundaries, is wielded by those in the high echelons of the ministry in Queensland. I believe that on Saturday the people will speak loudly and will be heard across the State. Yesterday, in this House the deposed Federal Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), made it quite clear that he will undermine the new Leader of the National Party. It will not be long before the Nationals are forced to become a part of the Liberal Party. They are no longer relevant to Australian politics. One can make a sad and sorry comparison with the days of the great National Party men such as Page and McEwen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly appreciate the opportunity of speaking in this grievance debate. While I had no intention of starting on this tack, I have a most definite and specific grievance about the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). He is totally out of touch with reality, as is the entire Hawke-Keating Government. Everybody on the other side of the House is totally out of touch with the reality of what is going on in middle Australia in regard to ordinary Australian citizens. I acknowledge the correctness of what he said when he praised great National Party leaders like Page, McEwen--
—Ian Sinclair?
—Ian Sinclair and Charles Blunt. For him to assert that the strength of the National Party has dissipated, as you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, is totally irrelevant and totally incorrect.

SPEECH.PARA: Seeing that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) is at the table, I take this opportunity to mention two areas of aviation which are of great concern to me at present. I know the Minister will recall that she recently wrote to me about the aspirations of Kempsey Shire Council in my electorate to have some form of night navigation beacon. It is absolutely wrong that a vibrant community such as Kempsey, and the whole MacLeay valley, should be hamstrung and hampered by the fact that regular scheduled aircraft are able to land only in daylight hours. I think it is quite amazing. An argument has been going on for some time. Deputations have approached previous Ministers about this matter. While we have always had a good and sympathetic hearing, sympathetic hearings are not worth the paper they are not written on. I seize this opportunity to again say to the Minister that we are not talking about a great deal of money. Kempsey Shire Council is prepared to cooperate with the Government in every way. I appeal to her to look at this matter again to see whether there is some way that the Government can assist in providing something which is not remarkable-a night navigation beacon so that Kempsey airport can be used by commercial aircraft in the hours of darkness. This problem greatly inhibits the area's commercial growth and tourism potential.

I foreshadow to the Minister that I will be approaching her fairly soon, in the next month or two, on behalf of Hastings Municipal Council, the local government body which serves Port Macquarie and the Hastings area. As the Minister knows, Port Macquarie is one of the jewels of the north coast of New South Wales, and one of the great growth areas in terms of development and tourism. It is also an area in which elderly people choose to retire. Again, the airport situation is not adequate. There is a need for upgrading to jet standard. I acknowledge the Minister's sincerity and the way she feels about these matters. I know she would agree that as the Government says it is interested in tourism, it should acknowledge the great potential for growth in this area. I know that the Minister will give every possible sympathetic consideration to my request for Hastings Municipal Council to be able to upgrade its airport so that it can play its part in the great growth of the tourist industry in Australia. I will be making that approach to the Minister in the next several months. I know we will get a sympathetic hearing.

The other point I wish to raise again-and I am sure it will come as no surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, or any other member of this House-is the need to upgrade the Pacific Highway. It is a pity that the Minister's colleague the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) is not in the chamber because I could again issue to him an invitation to travel with me along the highway. I have suggested to him on a number of occasions that what he should do is travel by car with me from Hexham in the Hunter region adjoining his own electorate, to the Queensland border so that he can see at first hand what is necessary. The Pacific Highway serves the fastest growing areas in Australia. It is the busiest highway in Australia. I will be consistent: I applaud what the Minister has done in specifying it as a national arterial road. It was the right thing to do, but it requires special funding on two counts: one is the volume of traffic and the other is the climate.

I will deal first with the climatic factor. Mr Deputy Speaker, a cyclone is possibly approaching your electorate at the moment. We know there have been three cyclones in the north-east of Australia in the last few weeks. The Pacific Highway on the north coast of New South Wales is adversely affected by the spin-off-the flooding and the devastating heavy rain. Therefore, there needs to be an acceptance and an acknowledgment that the climatic factor means that the highway requires additional funding. It is vastly different from, say, the Newell Highway in the west of New South Wales. Regrettably, rain does not fall with such regularity in that area. Along the Pacific Highway there is not flooding but constant heavy rain and the impact on the road surface is such that road crews are out virtually night and day for months at a time, trying to repair potholes. I make the plea to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support that he consider looking at appropriate funding to compensate for the climatic effects on the Pacific Highway. Of course, those of us who are lucky enough to live in that area do not suffer a climatic disadvantage, because the climate is absolutely superb.

The other point is the safety factor. I have with me the accident statistics for 1987-the latest figures I have-produced in a paper entitled, `Road Traffic Accidents in New South Wales 1987'. There are five local government areas in Cowper: the Hastings Municipal Shire, which I have mentioned already in terms of its airport-Kempsey Shire Council, Nambucca Shire Council, Bellingen Shire Council and the City of Coffs Harbour. It is interesting to note that all five of those local government bodies share my dedication to improving the Pacific Highway. They are on the spot; they have first-hand information. They realise the need for additional funding. The north coast of New South Wales is, as I have said, the fastest growing area of Australia and the Pacific Highway has the greatest volume of traffic. There is a crying need for it to be upgraded to a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway. I am delighted to report to this House that in recent months the very first section, comprising two kilometres south of Kempsey, has been transformed into a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided highway.

We all know that where there are divided highways, the accident level drops amazingly. We are looking at the saving of human lives, and matters of enormous significance to Australian society. I do not expect the highway from Hexham to the Queensland border to be transformed overnight; it is a 20-year job. What I have been saying since I was elected to this Parliament is that we must starting planning now and taking the steps which will permit that marvellous transformation to occur over time. The first section has been completed. I have told the House that there is an incredible need for such a project to be completed as soon as possible. I urge the current Minister to look at the matter carefully, to look at the provision of special funding so that the Pacific Highway between Hexham and the Queensland border can be turned into Highway No. 1, which is what it is called, and which is what it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about the United Nations Conference on Disarmament Issues, but before I do so it is important to note that today is the day on which members of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly are being sworn in. It is a nice coincidence that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) is in the chamber. Both of us, I am quite sure, would want to give our warmest congratulations to Rosemary Follett who has just been elected the first Chief Minister for the ACT and to give our wholehearted best wishes to the new ACT Government. We also welcome that swearing in, of course, because today is liberation day for us. We cease to be responsible for State and local government type matters in the ACT and that will give us the time and opportunity to concentrate much more closely on national issues, which is what every other member of the Federal Parliament has had to deal with. We have been trying to do the work of a number of people and we are very glad to be relieved of that responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Between 19 and 22 April the United Nations held a conference on disarmament in Kyoto, Japan. The Japanese Government paid for the Conference and the 90 or so participants included disarmament and UN ambassadors from the North, South, East and West, scientists leading the national seismological monitoring agencies, plus a few parliamentarians, journalists and non-government organisation leaders. Australian participants were Mrs Stella Cornelius, head of the Conflict Resolution Centre in Sydney, Dr Ken Muirhead, head of the Australian Seismological Centre, and me. Five plenary sessions were held addressing the issue of a nuclear non-proliferation treaty; issues surrounding a comprehensive test ban treaty; confidence building measures; bilateral and multilateral approaches to disarmament; and global security, which concentrated mainly on superpower relations. The Conference was brilliantly chaired by Mr Akashi, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Disarmament. The Conference received enormous publicity in Japan and was important as a means of increasing open, rigorous discussion among senior diplomats, scientists, parliamentarians, journalists and community leaders. The quality of discussions was high and tinged with cautious hope. The debate was predominantly about practical issues in negotiating nuclear, chemical and conventional weapons agreements rather than generalities.

The topics discussed by this Conference are profoundly important. Certainly, in the international community hope has been increased by the Intermediate Nuclear Forces Treaty signed by Mr Gorbachev and Mr Reagan a couple of years ago. Obviously, cooperation between the superpowers is increasing. Also, in 1988 there were major steps toward the resolution of conflict in several areas of brutal violence around the world. There was the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan; there was a ceasefire between Iran and Iraq; there were signs of independence for Namibia, and the ending of the internal war in Angola; and there was the start of some contact between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organisation, which gives us hope of greater dialogue about the Middle East.

Those achievements certainly generate hope, but we should not become complacent, for potential conflict remains a high possibility. Distrust between the superpowers remains intense. Violent conflict is still a daily occurrence in many countries, as we all know from watching television programs. Military expenditure is still increasing in many countries and is now at a level of about $US1,000 billion a year-a massive waste of resources. Military expenditure is concentrated with the superpowers but many other industrialised countries have large outlays on weapons and forces and even in the Third World there is a high level of military expenditure. Approximately 20 per cent of global military expenditure occurs in developing countries. That represents about $US200 billion a year. It is a tragedy because those funds could be used for much more economically and socially useful activities, let alone for repaying debts.

The central idea behind the continuing arms race, of course, is that deterrence is the best defence. At this Conference at Kyoto both the United States and, to a lesser extent, the Soviet Union, attempted to justify the continuing arms race on the basis of deterrence. They would argue that deterrence has been successful because there has not been a war between the United States and the Soviet Union during the last 40 years. As Mr Akashi said in his closing statement, that is like the story of the man who goes around the village beating a stick on the ground and, when asked why he is doing it, says, `To keep the elephants away'. People say to him, `But there aren't any elephants' and he says, `Yes, aren't I successful?'. I thought that proper note of scepticism was quite daring on the part of the Under-Secretary-General for Disarmament when both representatives of the United States and the Soviet Union were present. I think there is a very appropriate moral to the story.

As I say, deterrence has a high cost and we need to be sceptical about that argument because of the cost. The deterrence cost is due partly to the increased danger of a conflict through intensification of the arms race and partly to the increasing technological sophistication of weapons. Also, it ties up enormous funds. Those funds could be better spent on more economically and socially useful government programs.

A reduction in military expenditure by both the Soviet Union and the United States in the 1990s could lead to a decade of higher investment and therefore more sustained economic development both in those countries and in the rest of the world. It is impressive to see that both the United States and the Soviet Union are beginning a process of reducing their military expenditure. That process has been included in the Bush Administration's first budget and in announcements by Mr Gorbachev quite recently. The Soviet Union has announced a 19 per cent reduction in its military expenditure next year.

The United Nations Conference on Disarmament Issues concentrated on practical policies for arms reduction. Those policies should include the strengthening of the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT). There was agreement that it is important, when the Treaty comes up for renewal next year, that it should be continued for another five years and that it would be strengthened. That strengthening requires the stopping of vertical as well as horizontal proliferation. Vertical proliferation involves an increase in the technical sophistication of weapons by the nuclear states. It is important that they do their part in stopping proliferation if the countries which are not parties to the NPT are going to be persuaded to join. A number of countries-China, France, India, Pakistan, Brazil, Argentina, Israel and South Africa-either have such weapons or are on the verge of having such weapons. It is important that they be persuaded to be parties to the Treaty so that they do not extend the nuclear arms race any further.

An important part of that is a second policy which was discussed in detail-a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. Both party groups in this Parliament support a comprehensive test ban treaty. It has been a policy of all Australian governments for a long time. It is important that we encourage the superpowers to be willing to accept a comprehensive test ban treaty. Each year at the UN General Assembly motions supporting such a treaty are passed, but so far they have not had much effect. Therefore, there would be value in the proposal for an amendment conference regarding the partial test ban treaty so as to force existing nuclear powers to the negotiating table.

A third set of proposals discussed at the Kyoto Conference covered confidence-building measures-measures for greater openness, transparency and trust in military relations between countries. The best example of confidence-building measures is the conference on security and cooperation in Europe, which has agreed to prior notification of manoeuvres, sending observers to two large manoeuvres, and the right to inspect military activities of other countries. A fourth set of proposals involved permanent peace keeping forces for the United Nations and the strengthening of dispute settling procedures through the United Nations. I conclude by quoting from the final statement of Mr Akashi, the Chairman of the Conference, because it sums up at least part of the agreement. He said:

Despite the differences of opinion, however, there seemed to be agreement that existing levels of nuclear weapons are far more than needed. There will continue to be differences of views on how the objectives of greater international security can be achieved. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to recent events involving an incident that occurred in the city of Brisbane. In many ways one should not even have to raise such a matter in this place, but one must do so. I commence by acknowledging the attention given to the issue by a former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, former Senator Arthur Gietzelt. Honourable members may recall that in April or May of 1986 I raised in this place concerns as to the proposed treatment by crematoria throughout Australia of the remains of former Australian servicemen. It transpired that some crematoria had no intention of keeping remains beyond a certain period unless a new fee was paid. I protested about this. Senator Gietzelt stepped in and said that this should not be so. All Australian crematoria were asked to give an assurance that remains would never be removed and `ditched' at the end of a period of tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter arose because at the time Brisbane Crematorium Ltd, the owners of the Albany Creek crematorium and the Mount Thompson crematorium, had had a change of ownership. The new directors and owners had decided to strip its assets and to sell land adjoining the area currently being used by the crematorium. Until that time that land had been zoned for crematorium use. There was tremendous local opposition in Brisbane, based on a number of grounds. Some 5,000 people protested in writing about the events of that time. I became a respondent in the courts after the Brisbane City Council had-and correctly so-refused the application for rezoning of the land. I even put up money. I put my money where my mouth is, so to speak.

One of the objections to the rezoning was that it was claimed by people that the area to be rezoned for housing at Mount Thompson had been used by Brisbane Crematorium Ltd as a disposal area for the ashes of those persons whose remains were unclaimed or unwanted. There was considerable argument about that subject. The Brisbane Courier-Mail even saw fit to report on 21 April 1989, in an article by Tess Livingstone, that a spokesman for the Brisbane Crematorium had denied that ashes had ever been sprinkled or buried on the land in question. It was very difficult for those of us who opposed the rezoning to prove that ashes were located there. A month beforehand human bones had been found in the area, but that was not proof that the area had been used as an ash disposal area.

At the moment that land is being developed and 39 houses will be built. I have no argument with the developer because he has been made the fall guy. He has been caught as a result of the lies that were told in 1986. Industrial Equity Ltd, Mr Brierley's company, has owned 50 per cent of the company since 1985. A number of other people were involved in a takeover just prior to that time. They are the guilty people.

Recently, during development of the property, the excavators had cause to dig up the ground. A nearby resident who was taking his dog for a walk that evening looked in the trenches that had been dug and saw 40 or 50 name plaques from coffins, as well as seams of ash. He rang me and I went out there. Fortunately, I had the brains to take a reporter with me. As it was night-time I used a torch to look down the trench. I could see seams of ash, which caused me to call for forensic tests to determine exactly what they were. That night I suspected that I should be smart enough to hide my evidence, so I gathered a lot of name plaques, hid them under a tree and covered them with branches and leaves-just in case something happened. Coincidentally, next morning the bulldozers filled in all the trenches. Suddenly this question was raised: `Well, there are no ashes there, so what is he talking about?' I thank the media for sticking by me. It was agreed that tests be carried out. The crematorium did its own digging, saw what was uncovered and admitted that they were human remains. It is proposed that drainpipes and other pipes be laid in those trenches. I am not prepared to see that happen. Next Saturday, in my presence, the excavating company will dig up the trenches. Crematorium staff will be present to remove those ashes and reinter them in the grounds of what is now the contracted crematorium.

I conclude on this note: If ever there has been an example of people deliberately lying, misleading the public and misleading the Brisbane City Council, this is it. The denials at the time were so strong that there were doubts as to the legitimacy of the claims that there were ashes there, yet the Brisbane Crematorium has now admitted that the area was last used for the disposal of ashes in 1985. That was at the beginning of the administration of the people who applied for rezoning of the land. Employees, including the person who drove the tractor into this area every morning, must have known that ashes were being buried there. I cannot understand how fellow human beings could remain silent when they knew that the company that employed them was virtually lying through its teeth in a bid to cause land to be rezoned so that it could make a fast buck. I do not believe, nor do I accept, that the then directors would not have known of the presence of the ashes. Indeed, a director from Sydney was brought in to take over the administration in Brisbane because the issue was getting too hot.

I ask all former directors of Brisbane Crematorium Ltd, including people such as Sir Edward Williams from Brisbane, Michael Evans from Brisbane, and four or five others, to attend the site on Saturday and, when the bulldozers uncover the ashes, to be involved in carefully placing them in receptacles so that they can be reinterred in the grounds of the Brisbane Crematorium. It was a most dishonourable performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to take the extraordinary step of reading into the House's record part of the normally confidential record of proceedings of our Caucus. I read from a paragraph on page 6 of the record of our Caucus meeting on Tuesday:

SPEECH.PARA: The Whip in the House of Representatives reported on arrangements for tomorrow, Question Time, and arrangements for leave.

He also extended congratulations to Duncan Kerr on the birth of his son. Duncan replied giving Caucus some details of arrangements he had made for the smooth running of the household at the time of the important event.

Surprisingly, some of the details of the `smooth running' of our household were reported in the Press. In today's Sydney Morning Herald there is an article written by Mike Seccombe. Because it is so delightful I take the opportunity of mentioning it. Mike Seccombe wrote:
Moves to deregulate the wheat market played their part in losing John Howard and Ian Sinclair their jobs but others, too, have suffered.

Like Duncan Kerr, Labor member for Denison. On Anzac Day, Duncan's wife, Celia, gave birth to a son, Hamish. It was a difficult labour, so for the next four days, husband spent most of his time at the hospital.
As a result, he neglected to walk their two large dogs, and when he finally did, late on the fourth day, one of the dogs bolted right under the wheels of a passing car.
With the car driver and his wife, also about to have a baby, for company, Mr Kerr began frantically ringing late-night vets.

Eventually one told him that if the dog had survived the first five minutes, it would probably be allright. Just monitor its breathing, and the colour of its gums for the next couple of hours, the vet said. So Mr Kerr curled up on the floor beside the dog.

The time came when Mrs Kerr came home from hospital, still substantially below par. She told him, understandably, that she could not cope with the baby and the sick dog, while her husband was busy attending to Parliamentary duties. So her mother, Mrs Joyce Taylor, move in to help.
Night one, and the mother-in-law trips over the black dog in the dark on her way to the bathroom and breaks her wrist.
You might think with a new baby and a house full of walking wounded, Duncan might have a case for getting leave of absence. But no.

The Government Whip, Mr Barry Cunningham, cancelled all leave because the Government's legislation deregulating the domestic wheat market was coming up in the House, and all hands would be needed in case the Opposition became fractious.
So Mr Kerr dutifully attended in Canberra, only to see the bill go through the House by 124 to 4.
To make matters just slightly worse, he decided to exercise away some of his tensions with a game of squash. An encounter with a flying squash racquet left him with a black eye.
All of this was aired at length in the Labor Caucus on Monday. When the laughter stopped, Mr Cunningham apologised. But he left no doubt he would do it all again if necessary.
If you're the relative of an MP or, indeed Kerr's cur, you have to learn to fend for yourself.

It is a delightful story, and beautifully put by Mike Seccombe. It is also true. I place on record the fact that everyone is well. I now have a very healthy, happy boy, Hamish, aged nearly two weeks. He was born on Anzac Day. My wife has almost fully recovered. My mother-in-law, despite the fact that she now wears a cast, is well and has returned to her home. My dog, although it was run over by a car and suffered bruising has also fully recovered. All is well that ends well. I echo the remarks of the Whip, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). He indicated that he would do it all again if necessary. The birth of a child is such a happy event that I am sure all of us would go through it again. I thank all honourable members who have been kind enough to congratulate my wife Celia and me, on the birth of our baby.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme-Merthyr By-Election-Tasmanian State Election-Queensland: Labour Day-Sydney Morning Herald Article-ME and Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Sufferers-Research and Development: Taxation Deduction-Western Australian Potato Marketing Board-Australian Wheat Industry-Sheryl Garbutt-Rural Health Services-Human Rights

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory, concerned pharmacists will close their doors for two hours to protest about the Government's irresponsible and increasingly penny pinching attitude to a vital element of our nation's health care arrangements-the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). If it was genuinely concerned with delivering quality health care to the nation, the Government would realise that a dollar spent now on medication could well save many times that amount by averting the need for expensive hospitalisation and surgery. Its blinkered approach is simply not good enough. Instead of throwing money around on a never-ending promotional merry-go-round, the Government should look at putting those dollars to work in the interests of community pharmacists and the people who rely upon their services.

SPEECH.PARA: The $1.1m set aside to pay the extra staff needed to process authority-only forms, the $2m earmarked for educating doctors on prescribing practices, and the many thousands of dollars thrown away on totally unnecessary, large, red and white plastic capsules recently sent to medical practitioners and pharmacists, are just the tip of the iceberg in terms of waste and inefficiency. The PBS must be rebuilt. If the Government is not willing to tackle the task now, it is a further indicator of its moral bankruptcy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This weekend in Brisbane a by-election is being held for the State seat of Merthyr. The by-election was caused by the resignation of a former Minister, Don Lane, after admissions of corruption and misuse of his ministerial expenses. Today I want to remind the people of Merthyr about a few things. I want to remind them that only the Labor Opposition opposed Lane's $500,000 superannuation payout, arguing that he should have to pay back the money that he ripped off the public. The Liberal and National parties supported his payout. The only really credible explanation as to why they handed Lane this huge golden handshake is that he has considerably more to tell the people of Queensland than he has already told the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. That is a frightening prospect but one which, when looked at logically, is entirely probable. The 30 pieces of silver he could get for dobbing in his mates is chicken feed compared to $500,000. The people of Merthyr should keep a few things in mind this weekend. The first and most important is that corruption has flourished in Queensland under both the Nationals in power in their own right and a coalition between the Nationals and the Liberals. Don Lane's admissions about his own corruption date back to the time when he was a Liberal.

SPEECH.PARA: This by-election to be held on Saturday is really a referendum. The people of Merthyr will decide whether the Nationals and Liberals should be taught a lesson for the way they have handled Don Lane and the corruption issue. The by-election gives the people of Merthyr the opportunity to signal to the Liberals and Nationals that playtime is over. The Liberals and Nationals are saying in the by-election that they have the result sewn up and that the people of Merthyr will never vote for Labor. I hope that voters will see through their facade and prove them entirely wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I urge the people of Tasmania not to vote for the green independents on Saturday in the State election. A vote for the green independents is without doubt a vote for political instability in Tasmania because it would be impossible for those green independents to be able to form a stable government with either the Liberal Party or the Labor Party. So any person who votes for the green independents, albeit that it may be a populist movement, will be, without doubt, voting for political instability in that State. The green independents make up a single issue group, which has caught on to a populist bandwagon of conservation. But beyond their common belief in conservation issues, there is no common policy amongst those candidates. It is simply a single issue group which has caught on to a populist bandwagon. If they manage, by some misfortune, to get the balance of power in Saturday's election, it will without doubt lead to political instability and unstable government in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this month the Labour Day weekend was celebrated in Queensland. It was highlighted by an extremely well attended Labour Day march in Brisbane on 1 May. Labour Day is a very important day in the trade union calendar. It is the day on which trade unions get together to remember the achievements of the trade union movement in improving and maintaining the conditions of workers. It is also a time for workers to look to the future to ensure that those hard fought conditions are not eroded. The concept of May Day came from a struggle by workers for an eight-hour working day.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian workers were amongst the first in the world to win these conditions with the famous slogan, `Eight hours to work, eight hours to play, eight hours to sleep, and eight bob a day'. The celebrations were held over the weekend not only in Brisbane but also in many provincial centres throughout Queensland. In my own electorate of Oxley, which is based in the city of Ipswich, a very successful Labour Day dinner was held on the Friday night, followed by a well attended march through the streets of Ipswich on the Saturday morning and then a family sports day in the afternoon. In fact, the first May Day march was held in Queensland in Ipswich in 1891, commencing at 9 a.m. It was always believed that Barcaldine held the first May Day march in Queensland, but in fact Ipswich holds that record, as Barcaldine did not hold its march until the afternoon. I offer my congratulations to the organisers of the Labour Day celebrations throughout Queensland-in particular the organisers of the Ipswich celebrations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of this House for 14 years. During that time I have not got to hear about much personal stuff. Even if these sorts of rumours start, they are usually stopped quick smart. I read an article in the Sydney Morning Herald today-it appears in many other newspapers, too-which states:

SPEECH.PARA: HOBART: Writing these campaign notebooks is a breeze, so long as you're willing to let the scorpion out of the jar. Or to put the philosophy more bluntly: if you are to be fair to politicians, you must also be willing to be cruel.

This journalist was certainly very cruel. He was cruel to the Premier of Tasmania on the eve of an election; he was very unfair to him. He also was most unfair to the wife of the Premier of Tasmania. The poor woman was injured in a car smash and yet he wrote this sort of stuff.

The Sydney Morning Herald does not own me; the Australian does not own me; the Mercury does not own me. If we are going to put up with this sort of stuff and allow a journalist to ask the Premier such personal questions on the eve of an election when his poor wife is still recuperating, we all ought to be ashamed of ourselves. None of us would do it; but the journalists do it. We ought to start fighting back a bit. If we have got some personal stuff, we keep it to ourselves. There are many skeletons in the cupboard. We are not the ones to bring them out. If we have to put up with this sort of stuff, surely to God we ought to give the game away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make this statement today to advise Western Australian ME and chronic fatigue syndrome sufferers and their families that a public meeting will be held on Saturday, 20 May at the Dorchester Hall in Warwick, commencing at 2 p.m. The purpose of the meeting is to give sufferers an opportunity to have a say on what they want from such a support group. Many people have contacted me regarding the need for such a group and I am pleased to be able to assist in organising this meeting. Whilst I will be writing to people who have already expressed an interest in the subject, as well as placing an advertisement in the local newspaper, I thought that this avenue of making the meeting known to a broader section of the public could not be ignored. I urge as many people as possible to attend so that any propositions put forward represent the needs of sufferers.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested at a recent discussion of interested people who are willing to assist such a group that a multifaceted approach would be most helpful, for instance, by providing constructive support for sufferers and their families; by providing information on the diagnosis of the disease; by providing links with other groups, such as the allergy association and pesticide group and by raising the public profile of the disease in the media and in any other way we can. Naturally, doctors and other people who are prepared to treat the disease sympathetically would be very welcome also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made a great play of its supposedly profound science statement delivered here on Monday, but already the statement is beginning to fall down around its ears. Yesterday the report by the Auditor-General was released. It questions both the administration and the effectiveness of the highly valued 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development. The Auditor-General found that it was 2 1/2 years after the commencement of that scheme before the Australian Taxation Office clarified eligibility by issuing a ruling. So how much abuse of the 150 per cent tax deduction occurred in that intervening period?

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, this Government relied on the Tax Office to conduct audits to determine whether eligibility criteria were being satisfied. The audits are only about 2 per cent of the claimants of that tax deduction. It is an abrogation of responsibility of the very worst kind for the Government to have allowed what undoubtedly occurred. Moreover, we now find that the Auditor-General questions whether that tax deduction is really assisting private sector investment in research and development. So there is a whole cloud over this 150 per cent tax deduction. It is foolish for the Government to say that it is the one thing that will bring about increased investment by the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently this Parliament saw the passage of the wheat marketing legislation which, in essence, deregulates the wheat industry. In Western Australia the Potato Marketing Board looks after the marketing of potatoes and regulates the industry. The problem with the Potato Marketing Board is that the result of its marketing activities and its restraints upon the supply of potatoes is that the range of quality potatoes on offer to the public is severely restricted and the quality is inferior. That has meant that potatoes are losing market share to alternatives such as pasta and rice. However, in defence of the growers, very good potatoes are grown in Western Australia. Yet when one goes to the marketing end of things, that is the greengrocers, it is very difficult to find quality potatoes consistently throughout the year. However, if one shops in Canberra, Sydney or Melbourne one has a wide range of potatoes. They are marketed according to grade, brand and species.
—None of them are as good as Tasmanian potatoes.

—There are Tasmanian potatoes as well. A much better job is done of marketing. That is certainly not the case in Western Australia. The Western Australian Government should seriously consider deregulating the potato marketing to allow the growers to get better quality potatoes on to the market. I am sure that the consumers will benefit. They will certainly get better quality potatoes-much more price variation, but certainly better quality.

—I must take issue with the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). He should have known better than to open his 90-second statement as he did: He began by saying that the wheat legislation was designed to deregulate the wheat industry. Far from deregulating the entire industry, the legislation passed in this House was designed solely to deregulate the domestic market for Australian wheat. That point needs to be reinforced. Too many people, including Senator McGauran, have insisted that the legislation has the potential to dismantle the Australian Wheat Board. There is no such potential. The Wheat Board remains the sole exporter of Australian Wheat and, by my calculations, the prominent seller of wheat on the domestic market. There needs to be an increasing appreciation of the fact that the legislation does nothing more than provide opportunity for the sale of wheat within the Australian domestic market. It does not, as the honourable member for Stirling erroneously has alleged, deregulate the Australian wheat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the comments of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) concerning the journalist Robert Haupt and the way Robert Haupt put those questions to the Premier of Tasmania. It is disgraceful. It should not be accepted in civilised society. But that is not my purpose in rising to speak today. My purpose is to remind the House that sometime after 2 p.m. today in the Victorian House of Assembly, Sheryl Garbutt, the new member for Greensborough, will make her inaugural address to that august chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Only a fortnight ago, Sheryl Garbutt resoundingly won the State seat of Greensborough for the Labor Party in the by-election. It was a resounding success because the local branches, the local Labor Party members and Sheryl Garbutt put up the best performance, the best candidate and the best campaign. I regret not being able to be there to see my colleague and long-time friend Sheryl make her inaugural address to that House. I congratulate her on that speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a tragedy that in these modern times, with our great economic strength and sophisticated technology, many of our health services in rural areas are under threat. This particularly applies in Victoria and South Australia, to the bush nursing hospital system and the many small nursing homes attached to them. I urge the Minister responsible for issuing the recent guidelines to review the guidelines and ensure that any action he takes will not be responsible for closing down these hospitals and homes that have been established by the generosity of the community, in particular, under the former Government's programs.

—The matter I raise today concerns the need for reporting to the Parliament on the activities of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in taking up human rights concerns, not just on behalf of the Government, but on behalf of the Parliament. The Department consistently takes up the urgent action appeals of Amnesty International and its diplomatic representatives go around the world, knocking on the doors of repressive governments seeking the release of prisoners of conscience. This activity is something in which the entire Parliament can take great pride. My concern is that a reporting mechanism needs to be instituted whereby the Parliament can get comprehensive information about the details of those representations. It is a very proud record that the Department has instituted. I stress that it is not just important to the Government but one which the Opposition, I hope, would also endorse. I commend this idea to the House and to the Government.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted. The time for members' statements has concluded.

—I inform the House as a matter of courtesy that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is in Tasmania on Government business, making yet another State safe for democracy. In his absence, any questions should be directed to my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his answer in the House last Tuesday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . in the period since 1983, average living standards per capita have risen by about 8 per cent per annum.
Does the Prime Minister still stand by the accuracy of this statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Will the Minister for Housing and Aged Care inform the House whether claims currently being made by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia concerning pharmacy closures and a 14 per cent reduction in pharmacy remuneration are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As part of an ongoing campaign against the Government, pharmacists in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory have threatened to undertake a token two-hour stoppage during a relatively quiet part of the business day. This campaign is based simply and solely on demands for more money. It has nothing to do with patient care or the delivery of drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Pharmacists and some other people are attempting to make the patients the scapegoats of this fearmongering which has taken the form of misleading information about pay cuts and pharmacy closures.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government certainly acknowledges the problems with pharmacy remuneration caused by the impact of the 25 per cent mark-up on the escalating drug prices. We also acknowledge that pharmacies in some areas, particularly those single pharmacies in country towns, may be facing difficulties in some circumstances. I want to assure the House that this Government has a total commitment to ensure that essential pharmacy services and health care throughout Australia continues.

The Government is not in a position, nor should it be in a position, to prop up any businesses which, for normal commercial reasons common to any other retailer, are no longer viable. It has been claimed by some pharmacists in recent days that up to 70 per cent of the 5,622 pharmacies operating in Australia will be forced to close. This is just absolute nonsense, as some of the more responsible members of the Pharmacy Guild will say. Just as unrealistic are claims of a 14 per cent cut in remuneration in pharmacies in the last 12 months. The calculations that the Pharmacy Guild has put forward are a hotchpotch of wrong assumptions, statistically biased, periods and simple mathematical miscalculations.

The fact of the matter is that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is alive and well. Well over $1,000m will be spent on it in this year alone. In the next three or four years the amount will rise to about $2,000m. A look at the number of pharmacies that operate in Australia along with the rate of growth in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme over the next few years shows that claim of such drastic closures and unprofitability are patently ridiculous.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I address to the Prime Minister, flows from his answer to my previous question. Is it not a fact that household disposable income per capita is estimated to have risen by only about 8 per cent over the whole period of the Hawke Government, not per annum as he claimed? Is it not a fact that almost all of the estimated growth in household disposable income is due to the increase in income from property and other investments rather than from wages and salaries? Is it not a fact, therefore, that the average Australian wage and salary earner has been substantially out of pocket since Labor came to office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement I made the other day, and which I assumed the Leader of the Opposition repeated, was that there had been an 8 per cent increase, not per annum--
—That is what you said.
—I have at no stage said that there has been an 8 per cent increase per annum.
—Yes, you did; it is in the Hansard.

—It is quite incorrect. Mr Acting Speaker, all I can say-and I feel no embarrassment about this at all-is that to my knowledge I have never said this. I would love to hear the tape. If the tape shows me as saying `8 per cent per annum real increase' then it was a slip.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition should not carry on with their silly noise. No-one has ever heard me make the claim that there has been an 8 per cent per annum real increase in living standards. I hope this is an indication of what we are going to get from the Opposition under this new leader. If it really believes that I have been saying or intending to convey that there has been an 8 per cent per annum increase in living standards in real disposable income then that is a measure of just how fatuous it has become.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. It would appear that the Prime Minister is calling into question the accuracy of the Hansard record.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Peacock

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a further point of order: what flows from what the Prime Minister has said is that he is therefore impugning my integrity in respect of the question that I asked. I shall simply refer to page 2200 of the Hansard of 9 May 1989 where the Prime Minister said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . average living standards per capita have risen by about 8 per cent per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

—I am very pleased with this development. We will be getting very close to the little crook syndrome in a minute. We know what happened when the Opposition got on to that issue; it got done like a dinner. It will get done like a dinner.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The little crook syndrome has emerged already. I am now accused of impugning the integrity, the honesty-or whatever commodity he wants to seize upon-of the Leader of the Opposition, just so that this recycled dunderhead can get it straight.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. I ask that the Prime Minister withdraw that derogatory remark and that he does not do it again.
—Order! The Prime Minister's remark might not have been the most complimentary but it is not unparliamentary.
—So that there can be no doubt on the part of my recycled friend--
—Order! The Prime Minister might refer to honourable members by their title.

—In order that he not be upset in any way, I point out that I am not accusing the Leader of the Opposition of being dishonest. I am not accusing Hansard in any way. If there needs to be any accusation it concerns the fact that I am not a reader of the greens. I know that many people do not have much else to do than to read the greens. I do not read the greens. Obviously, I should have, or someone should have on my behalf, and picked up an obvious mistake. If that is the best that the honourable member can do with his first question to me, I say: Bung on, boyo, bung on.

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the Government's determination to deregulate the wheat industry. I ask: Can the Minister advise the House of progress in getting the States to pass the necessary complementary legislation on the domestic wheat market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my second reading speech on the wheat legislation, I referred to the need for the States to pass complementary legislation, because without it the Australian Wheat Board cannot operate intrastate. The National Party has indicated support for the Government on this. It has even moved amendments that purport to allow the Board to ignore the Australian Constitution. However, just last week the then Leader of the National Party said that I:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . must go to the State Ministers and attempt to get some complementary legislation.

I did that ages ago. As a result, the Victorian and Western Australian governments have decided to take the necessary action to enable the Wheat Board to operate within those States. So that is about 30 per cent of the domestic market fixed up. But it is the National Party States of New South Wales and Queensland that will not pass the necessary legislation. The New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mr Armstrong, has said that his Government:
. . . has no reason to pass such legislation, and we will not do so.

This is an outrageous political stunt at the expense of New South Wales wheatgrowers. I can give Mr Armstrong the reason why he should pass legislation. If he does not do so the Wheat Board will be effectively excluded from up to 45 per cent of the domestic wheat market. A man who does not want private traders in the market will have no-one in the market but the private traders.

Queensland has passed amendments to its wheat pool Acts to use its State Wheat Board to regulate its domestic market. I recently referred to that Government's agrarian Stalinism. Commenting on these amendments, the Primary Industry Newsletter said of my observation:

. . . observation is not entirely without merit . . . the Stalinist NKVD would have salivated at the opportunity to exercise powers similar . . . Needless to say, murderers, paedophiles and rapists are entitled to much greater protection against search and seizure of incriminating evidence than a grower who does not keep the evidence in question in his dwelling house.

That is the Queensland National Party for us. The new Leader of the National Party faces a test-a test to stop his colleagues from blaming me for stupid decisions made by State National Party Ministers and a test to get those Ministers to pass the necessary legislation on behalf of the wheatgrowers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. As Minister responsible for the disposal of government assets, I refer him to the announcement made by the Minister for Defence that Aerospace Technologies of Australia will be privatised. I ask the Minister whether he still stands by his statement reported in the Age of 24 May last year that it is:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . perfectly clear that privatisation in full or part is just not on.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the status of the agency referred to and what the Government might have in mind for it, that is entirely up to the Government and the Minister responsible for this matter, the Minister for Defence. As far as the general issue of privatisation is concerned, I told the honourable member in the House quite recently that this matter is before a committee of our national Party organisation, and that is where the matter stands.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the repeated unsubstantiated attacks on this Government by the Opposition regarding our employment growth policies. In view of this distortion of the facts, can the Minister inform the House as to the continuing success of the Hawke Government's employment policies, with specific reference to the latest figures on employment and unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that this Government has had an extremely proud record in job creation in this country ever since we came to office. The figures released by the Australian Statistician today, which reveal an unemployment rate of 6.1 per cent, confirm what we have been saying; that is, that the unemployment rate is now the lowest since January 1982, the lowest for seven years-a symmetry which I am sure the Prime Minister will find fascinating. The fact is that there are now fewer than half a million people out of work. The figure is just over 497,000. That means that, in the period we have been in office, over 200,000 people have come off the unemployment queues and into the labour market. Of course, the figure would be much higher than that in terms of the number of people in families who have benefited from this labour growth. However, in net aggregate terms, that is the situation.

ANSWER.PARA: I noticed yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition was sneering somewhat at the Government's record in relation to alleviating poverty, and particularly child poverty. There has been no better contribution to the improvement in living standards of ordinary Australian families, particularly those who were in the poorest of circumstances when we came into office, than the growth in the labour market. People who were totally reliant on social security payments are now in the labour market, in the work force, and earning a decent living. That is a record of which the Government is justly proud, and a record that we intend to continue.

In the period we have been in office we have created some 1.4 million jobs. That has not been confined to any particular area, although I might point out that female employment has grown particularly strongly, with an increase of 33.4 per cent, and female participation rates continue at record levels. When we came to office youth unemployment was nothing short of a national scandal, but we have now seen a drop of something like 50 per cent in the number of unemployed young people. Never has there been a more important issue than how we can help young people to make that very important transition from education to the work force. Young people now have better prospects of doing that than they have had for a very long time. I might observe casually that there have been some differences across the country. It is a lamentable fact that in Tasmania the unemployment rate is some 50 per cent higher than it is for the nation as a whole. I suppose that that is a reflection on the regional policies being pursued in that area.

I now turn for a moment to some other considerations of this issue, particularly as I am today wearing my hat as Minister representing the Treasurer. There has been some suggestion that this growth in the labour market which the Australian Statistician has revealed today is some indication of excessive demand.
