It is important to remember that what the Statistician is here measuring is the supply of goods and services. This relates to the number of people who are in the labour force who are actually producing goods and services. It is not a measure of demand; it is a measure of the supply of the economy. That needs to be borne in mind. It is also worth recognising where this growth has been. Some people have made the point that this has not been contributing to the easing of our balance of payments situation. Of course, some of the strongest growth in the labour market has been in the area of tourism and hospitality, which is quite clearly an area which makes a very direct contribution to our current account situation.

There is a tendency for people to concentrate on the export of merchandised goods when what we have to look at first is the question of net exports, that is the extent to which not only merchandise is being exported, but also the extent to which locally produced merchandise is satisfying local demand. There is a very important growth in the export of services in Australia, an area in which I think we have an optimistic future, whether it is in relation to the areas of finance, tourism, hospitality, or even in the provision of education services. So there is no need for this Government to be remotely apologetic about the improvement in the labour market. We are justly proud of it, and we hope it continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have knowledge that the part time consultant to whom I referred in my question on Tuesday had in fact received a payment of $215,000 in relation to the transfer of the defence service home loan scheme from his portfolio to the Westpac Banking Corporation? Notwithstanding that payment was made by the Minister for Finance, why did he refuse to advise the House of Representatives of his knowledge of this matter?
—Once again the shadow Minister--
—Did you know?
—Answer the question.

—Opposition members never want to hear the answer. The question that was asked was: Did my Department pay? I said, `No. Why don't you ask the right Minister?' That was the correct answer. I did know that it was Mr Uhrig, but why did not the honourable member have the intestinal fortitude to name the man? Now the honourable member is trying to slur Mr Uhrig. Let me tell the honourable member that Mr Uhrig was a great consultant and that he was employed by the Department of Finance. The honourable member should have asked the question in relation to Mr Uhrig.
—I did, yesterday.

—I am glad that he did. I was well aware that it was Mr Uhrig, but the honourable member did not have the intestinal fortitude to name him. The amount that the honourable member refers to was an amount that was paid by the Department of Finance and not by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If the honourable member wants to take the charges in relation to that $1.4 billion to the commercial people-and they are the free enterprise people whom the honourable member is supposed to represent-the bill would have been $1.4m. We got Mr Uhrig very cheaply indeed. He is an honourable Australian and I cannot say the same for the honourable member.
—Order! I think the Minister should withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industry and Energy. I remind him of the importance of the scallop industry in my electorate and the rest of the Mornington Peninsula, and other areas of Australia. Will the Minister inform the House why there are no scallops on Melbourne's restaurant tables or in my local fish and chip shop?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker--
—They are bigger in Tasmania.

—No, there are none there either. They have been wiped out. Scallop fishing traditionally has been a boom and bust industry. It all depends on the spat fall. In the late 1970s and the early 1980s, Victoria and Tasmania increased their scallop fishing efforts, including some bogus investments. I was never able to say much about that at the time. The Commonwealth restricted entry to the fishery in 1984, despite opposition from Tasmania. There was continual opposition and obstruction from the Tasmanian Minister at the time. He was claiming that even a piece of wood in the dirt was a boat to be used in order to increase the fishery's effort. By 1986 the seriousness of the level of the stock was apparent. Major scallop fishing is an area of State jurisdiction, not of Commonwealth. We are responsible for the central zone but, by arrangement, there is a 20-mile Tasmanian zone and a 20-mile Victorian zone.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the failure of the Tasmanian Government to take hard decisions over the last five years, the scallops were overfished and the State scalloping areas have been closed for almost all of the last three years. A two-week season is being contemplated in Victoria. I am currently experiencing precisely the same difficulties with Tasmania over shark. As Victorian members will know, shark provides the basis for fish in the Victorian fish and chip market. I am sure that the honourable member for Dunkley is worried about that too. The Commonwealth instituted a shark management plan with the understanding that Tasmania would introduce complementary shark legislation. It failed to do this with the result that I am again faced with the prospect of the Commonwealth Government having to make more difficult and tougher decisions on shark. It will be obvious to honourable members that it is for these reasons that I look forward to the prospect of an Australian Labor Party government in Tasmania. With David Llewellyn as Minister for Sea Fisheries, I am confident that we will not get this constant lack of intestinal fortitude on any conservation issue in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. In view of the strong demand for breast cancer screening by mammography and its established clear-cut benefit, when will the Minister allow this to become a Medicare rebate item?

—Let me answer the first part of the question about mammography screening. We have embarked with the States on a planned development of mammography screening in this country. On all the advice we can get from overseas, this is the best way to go about such a screening program. That has been supported by most of the experts involved in this in this country. As regards mammography screening under Medicare, at the moment, if there is a diagnostic reason, mammography is provided and paid for under Medicare. Last year 200,000 mammograms were conducted under Medicare and paid for at the cost of some $10m.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. I remind him that this month heralds the first anniversary of his announcement of the national social justice strategy of our Government. In the light of recent and new calls for more compassionate government, will the Prime Minister inform the House of any significant achievements of the Government in the last 12 months in bringing about a more compassionate and just Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the social justice strategy which I launched a year ago, I pointed to the progress that had been made in our period in government. I also laid down an agenda for the future. In launching our social justice strategy, I said that we would ensure that the benefits of a growing economy were distributed equitably in our society and that we would improve the equality of opportunity in Australia.
—No child will live in poverty!
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor that I drew his attention to interjecting a few moments ago.

—I said that we would enhance the rights of people, especially the underprivileged. Under this Government social justice means the creation of 1,400,000 jobs. In that respect, everyone in this country and overseas who has watched this spectacular employment growth with awe knows that the central ingredient has been an effective wages policy. In that respect, it is very interesting to note what the new Leader of the Opposition had to say when he was in government last about wages policy under that crowd. His actual words on 4 April 1982 were, `We have no wages policy'. That was his description. That was a statement about his own Party in Government. He went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: So, it is no good talking about wage restraint if your have a vacuum there.
He referred to the vacuum that that Government had in regard to wages policy-and nothing has changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is on relevance. The question was quite simply directed towards the Government's social justice policy. The Prime Minister is not answering that question and he is, therefore, not relevant. I ask you to request him to answer the question.
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—What is being promised now-when those opposite are in exactly the same position, with no wages policy-is a return to that situation in 1982 when, I remind the honourable member for Hughes, a quarter of a million Australians lost their jobs. So, social justice has been and is about creating jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, social justice is about stable, fair and universal health care. As the honourable member would know, this Government has brought two million Australians out of the cold, the cold in which they suffered under the compassionate policy of those people when they were in government. Social justice and compassion are not about targeting Medicare, which the new Leader of the Opposition promised this morning. This was just a replay of his predecessor--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: when the Prime Minister insists on turning away we lose the joy of his pearls of wisdom--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Bradfield will resume his seat.

—I say to the honourable member for Hughes that social justice is about creating jobs and having a fair and equitable system of medical insurance. I remind the House also that social justice is about providing welfare based on need and not on greed. What was compassionate about the Opposition Leader's declaration when he last held the position? I remind the House of what he said at that time. In June of 1984 he said:

ANSWER.PARA: We found no need-
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We will find out whether those opposite have changed, because the words of the now Leader of the Opposition were:

ANSWER.PARA: Why did they find no need to introduce an assets test-
this was the assertion then-
Because the assets test is contrary to every element of Liberal philosophy.
We cannot be quite sure what we are getting, because that was in 1984. In 1981 he had this to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1981? You are going back even further.
—Yes, because we want to know where he stands.
—Do you want a copy of my maiden speech?
—No. At that time he said:

ANSWER.PARA: By ``socially productive'' I mean a Budget which caters for carefully identified areas of genuine human need and avoids a situation in which those who do not need government assistance are given help at the expense of those who do.
Where are we? It is no wonder the other Andrew-Andrew Hay-had this to say on Tuesday morning of this week--
Mr Beale interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Deakin.

—When you recycle you have a past; you have a past that you have to live with. The only trouble with this Leader is that he has several pasts and we are trying to work out which one he is operating under.
—Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: I think it is improper for the pot to call the kettle black.
—If the honourable member for O'Connor takes another point of order which is not a point of order, I will name him.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker, I refer to your comment. It is your job to rule on points of order. Honourable members like the honourable member for O'Connor are not expected to know what is really a point of order. If you are going to name people for bringing up legitimate concerns, you are outstretching your powers.

—Order! All I will say to the honourable member for Moreton is that continuous points of order which are not points of order obstruct the business of the House and honourable members should be aware of what is a point of order or they will pay the penalty.
—When we have these different positions of the past, it is no wonder that Mr Andrew Hay said on Tuesday morning of this week:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Peacock is not certain in which direction he wants to go.
Mr Cadman interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—The plain fact is that there is a clear choice today in this place and in this country. The real consequence of the events of Tuesday of this week and last weekend is that there is an unimaginably wide chasm between and within the conservative parties in this country. Between the two sides of that chasm there is nothing; there is an emptiness, a philosophical vacuum represented by this recycled Leader of the Opposition. Against that emptiness and vacillation, there is one position in 1981 and another position in 1984. Against that, there is a government which has delivered on social justice and will continue to give to the people social justice and equality of opportunity.

—Does the Prime Minister support all Federal Government grants to the trade union movement-to the tune of some $17m since March 1983-to fund activities such as art and working life projects, of $3.5m, and the migrant `workers' rights' scheme, of nearly $2m? Does the Government intend to continue this level of support to the already wealthy trade union movement and, if so, why? Finally, can the Prime Minister assure the House that none of the grant funds has at any time been channelled into the Australian Labor Party election fund-raising activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether that will get you back onto the back bench, sonno. You need to do better than that. This figure of $17m which has been raised by the honourable member in his question may seem, to the uninitiated, to be a very large amount of money which is typified by the sorts of examples which he has given. What the honourable member refuses to disclose-or perhaps, charitably, is unaware of-is that a very substantial proportion of that $17m is accounted for by the financial assistance provided to the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA).

ANSWER.PARA: Let me remind the honourable member and the House of the history of TUTA. It is very straightforward. During the period of the Whitlam Labor Government it was agreed that it would make sense not merely for the trade union movement but for employers and the community generally-to put it simply-to have a better educated trade union movement. Does the honourable member suggest that that is a nonsensical thing to do-to provide, with the assistance of public funds, the opportunities for trade unionists to become better trained in their craft so that not only can they better represent their members, but in terms of serving the community as a whole we will have a better informed and better equipped body of trade union officials.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order, I point out that TUTA is funded by a separate allocation of $7m. It is not included in this figure of $17m.

—Order! It is with considerable sorrow that I do what I do; but I warned honourable members that points of order needed to be points of order. the honourable member for Bass really did not take a point of order. I am willing to let it go this time; but honourable members on my left and on my right should ensure, if they wish to take a point of order, that it is a point of order and not a mechanism to interrupt the debate and obstruct the work of the House.
—On the point of order: quite clearly the honourable member was raising a question of relevance. He asked a question about $17m and the Prime Minister--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has no point of order. The honourable member for Bass did not raise a point about relevance.
—I raise a further point of order. The point is this, Sir: the Prime Minister is answering a question about TUTA which is separately funded and was not included in the honourable member's question.
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—With regard to this $17m, I understand that there is a very significant element of that which is also provided in regard to health and safety. Is the Opposition again suggesting that that is irrelevant use of public money? I am not aware of every single item and the amount involved in the $17m. With a Budget of the dimension we have, if one were to think that I was acquainted with every line of expenditure, that is an expectation which will not be matched. I am simply saying that I have no reason at all to believe that any of the grants contained in the amount to which the honourable gentleman refers have been either improperly conceived or improperly applied. It seems to me that it is perfectly appropriate that when one has a trade union movement in this country which has delivered, as this trade union movement has under this Government, one should not be seeking, either explicitly or implicitly, to question its integrity.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, it is impossible to talk in this sort of situation.
—Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The House will come to order.

—I suggest that on the very day when there has been another 90,000-plus increase in employment, which has brought to 1,400,000 the increase in employment, where every commentator in this country and overseas knows that that has been made possible by the restraint and responsibility of the trade union movement-which has given this country under this Government a rate of employment increase four times faster than was the case when the Opposition was in government and twice as fast as the rest of the world-it ill behoves the honourable member or anyone else on his side of the House to impugn the integrity of the Australian trade union movement. Without the restraint--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Parkes will cease interjecting.

—Without the restraint and the commitment of the Australian trade union movement, this country would have been an infinitely less prosperous and an infinitely less fair society than it is today. It is perfectly appropriate, in those circumstances, that in the period of this Government the amount of money mentioned in the question should have been allocated to the trade union movement. It is just as entitled-in fact, in terms of the commitment it has made and what it has produced in this country, some could argue that its entitlement is second to none-to have disposed to it public funding for the undertaking of processes which will be to the benefit, not merely of their members but of the whole community.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me finally say this in regard to the honourable gentleman's question: there is no suggestion at all, as far as I am concerned, that any of this money would have been diverted from the appropriate purposes for which it was allocated for use for electoral purposes, as implied by the honourable gentleman's question. In my judgment, his question was a thoroughly improper, thoroughly indecent reflection upon a great body of Australian working men and women.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What are the implications for the national wages policy of demands for total labour market deregulation, including the development of voluntary employment agreements in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question highlights what is an effective clear choice between the stable effective industrial relations and wages policy of this Government and what can only be described as the irresponsible deregulation policy that is proposed by those opposite and some people in the private sector, which effectively constitutes a no wages policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the past six years, as a result of the consensus approach through the evolutionary accord process, we have seen the creation of some 1.4 million new jobs. We have seen inflation cut from 11 1/2 per cent to 6.9 per cent. We have seen a 12.2 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs and we have seen almost a 60 per cent reduction in the rate of industrial disputation. That is all highlighted by today's figures which reveal the lowest unemployment rate in over seven years; 6.1 per cent.

I ask the honourable member, because of his deep concern about this issue and the role that he has played with the trade union movement, which is the area he represents, to compare that record with the decentralised approach of the Opposition which relies on the mythical forces of the market to keep wage cost growth in check. A decentralised approach provides for a freedom for sweetheart deals. History shows that when one has that kind of policy, there is one inevitable result: a breakout in wages, a breakout in wages costs and a flow-on to the rest of the community. Even the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia acknowledges a willingness to concede that wage increases of that nature flow through in boom conditions. It also leaves the way open for the weak to be exploited, be they employers or employees. We saw the fallacy of that policy in 1981-82. As the Prime Minister said earlier, we saw in a period of just over 12 months a quarter of a million Australians lose their jobs, we saw the worst downturn in the economy in 50 years and we saw a rapid escalation in the inflation rate. At this time, when there is very strong demand across the trades for labour-specialised tasks, there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that were we to go to a deregulated policy, or an enterprise-by-enterprise environment, as suggested by the Opposition, a massive wage explosion would result.

The honourable member referred to the Queensland Government. That Government's voluntary employment agreement arrangement is facilitating the risk of that happening. There is no role, under the recent amendments to the Queensland legislation, for the Queensland Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There is no safeguard against exploitation of workers and their families, nor is there a safeguard against exploitation of employers. There is no way to prevent sweetheart deals.

Contrast that situation with the orderly, stable, responsible approach we have through our industrial relations policy and legislation for certified agreements. Within the stability of the Industrial Relations Act of this Government there is room and opportunity for special circumstances of employees to be taken into account through certified agreements. The Industrial Relations Commission has a role in that process to protect the public interest and to prevent an automatic flow-on. That is the responsible approach of this Government to wages policy. It is only this Government that has a practical wages policy. Flowing from that policy, through the award restructuring process, employers and employees now have the opportunity to lift productivity in this country, to lift efficiency and competitiveness, to overcome demarcation problems, to develop multiskilling and to develop career paths and more satisfying and better paid jobs. All of that can be done in the context of more effective training systems with national standards of accreditation. Voluntary employment agreements and labour deregulation would result in one inevitable massive wages explosion.

As to small business in this country, for those 581,000 businesses with less than 20 employees, deregulation represents a nightmare. It can only spell for them a recipe for disaster. They want the stability and reliability of the assistance this Government provides. This Government will continue to provide that responsibility, stability and uniformity in the administration of wages and industrial relations policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: In view of the assessment by the Australian Wool Corporation, published on the front page of this morning's Australian Financial Review, that the value of wool exports next financial year could be as much as $1 billion down on recent official forecasts, the prob- able increase in consumer imports following 1 July tax cuts and the likelihood that the share of investment in tradeables-that is, in mining, manufacturing and other non-manufacturing as defined by Treasury-will be below 50 per cent this financial year compared with 57 per cent in mid-1987, what new steps does he propose to take to contain further deterioration in Australia's chronic balance of payments deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just get the comments about the wool export figure into some sort of perspective. I do note, as the right honourable gentleman has said, that the Australian Wool Corporation has forecast most recently that wool exports for 1989-90 will be about $5.5 billion. As I think the right honourable gentleman knows, this is lower than the most recent forecast of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, which was a figure of $6.48 billion. It is lower because it takes into account the fall in wool prices over recent weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think it should be remembered that $5.5 billion still represents a very high level of wool exports, and not significantly lower than the 1987-88 peak of $5.8 billion. So let me not in any sense say to the right honourable gentleman that we would be disappointed if this most recent figure turns out to be the figure. Of course, we would be disappointed if it was $1 billion lower than the earlier forecast of the Bureau, but it should be put into the perspective that it is still in just about the same ball park as that peak figure of 1987-88.

The question was asked as to what we are doing in regard to the total balance of payments situation. The sorts of things that we have been doing cover a range of areas. Let me quickly go to them. Firstly, from the point of view of the constituency with which the right honourable gentleman is most particularly concerned, I think he has been generous enough in the past to acknowledge, with approval, that we have been doing the best we can, with like-minded countries, and particularly through the Cairns Group, to ensure that the Uruguay Round leads to a successful conclusion. If one looks at the whole world spectrum, there is no doubt that amongst the greatest sufferers of an international trading system which has become corrupted are our great, efficient Australian rural producers. They deserve better. They are efficient; they are among the most efficient in the world. We have sought through our endeavours, not just using our own resources but aligning ourselves with the members of the Cairns Group, to bring every possible pressure to bear to create a situation where out of the Uruguay round we will get a less corrupted international trading system. It is a matter of public and international acknowledgment that Australia's leadership has been significantly successful in helping to break the impasse which had developed at the end of the mid-term review in December in Canada.

I suggest that we can do nothing more important than that. Without trying to score basic political points, I believe that the way that we have not just gone to Belgium and bellowed, as used to happen before, but aligned ourselves with other like-minded nations, has been much more productive in the international sphere than anything that has ever come out of this country before. That is the first thing I say.

The second thing I say is that, by trying to create a more competitive Australian economy, we are gradually broadening the base of our exports. In the last two years there has been a very substantial increase in the exports of manufactured goods. I say subject to correction that I think in the last two years there has been an increase of 18 per cent, and then about 9 per cent, in the exports of manufactured goods. Also, by giving the enormous boost to tourism that we have by the range of measures we have undertaken in this country, we have made tourism the fastest growing industry in Australia. That is making a significant contribution to the balance of payments situation.

Having said all those things, we are not in any sense able to rest on our laurels because we are going to continue to make the Australian economy more competitive. We will proceed with the processes of micro-economic reform. I do not want to go through the whole list of things that we have done. That has been done here before in the House recently, and I want to save the House's time. But that list is very significant, as the right honourable gentleman knows. In the near future, the Minister for Transport and Communications will be announcing significant reforms on the waterfront and in the maritime industry-reforms which will have been unmatched by anything that any government before this one has ever done.

Looking internally at the way in which we are trying to diversify the Australian economy and broaden the export base so that we will not be as vulnerable to swings in commodity prices as we have been in the past, and looking at what we are doing in the international field by trying to create a more level and equitable playing field, I can say to the right honourable gentleman that no government has done more or is doing more than we are doing in that respect.

Having said all those things, I would readily concede that there is no reason why the Government or the Australian community can or should be complacent about the external accounts situation. That is why-and this is the paradox of the Opposition's position-we have fiscal policy as tight as it can possibly be. We have had three years of real reductions in Commonwealth outlays, we have got the public sector borrowing requirement down to zero, and we have reduced Commonwealth outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product from 29.1 per cent to 25.6 per cent. So fiscal policy could not in any sense be tighter than it is. It is impossible for wages policy to be tighter than it is. That leaves only the arm of monetary policy.

The question is about the current account situation. The simple fact is that if we allow the Australian economy to continue at its current high level of activity and suck in the level of imports associated with that high level of activity, the current account situation is going to get worse. Those on the opposite side of the House rant and rave about interest rate policy when it is quite clear that that interest rate policy is necessary if we are going to attack directly the question of current account policy.

I say to the right honourable gentleman, therefore, that what we have done in the international negotiating field, in restructuring the Australian economy and in the conduct of macro-economic policy is directed successfully towards gradually, through time, achieving a reduction in what is admittedly a very difficult external situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of recent reports in the press in Western Australia concerning claims by the West Australian Hotels Association that the Federal Government's attitude to aviation is responsible for a loss of millions of dollars of tourist revenue? Can the Minister comment on these claims and advise the House of recent aviation initiatives to bring more international flights to Perth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims made by the West Australian Hotels Association of the kind mentioned by the honourable member for Perth. I think those statements are totally unsupportable. The fact is that the Federal Government, which, rather than Qantas Airways Ltd, has the responsibility of negotiating with foreign governments in relation to bilateral aviation agreements, has been ensuring that there is increasing capacity for other airlines and Qantas to bring traffic into Perth. It is not a lack of capacity which is the cause of any problem with regard to the hotels losing out on tourist revenue in Perth. I do not know the details of the degree of occupancy of hotels in Western Australia, but I can say that as far as international aviation capacity goes there is no problem.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent months, a number of initiatives have been taken to ensure that there is an even greater increase in capacity. As mentioned in the House the other day, recent negotiations have been completed with Singapore and Thailand to increase aviation capacity between Australia and those countries. That includes the capacity for the airlines of those countries to fly to Perth if they so wish. Recently Qantas approved additional services between Sydney and Perth which will facilitate travel to New Zealand and North America, and also extra connections from Perth to London, Frankfurt, Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. I also understand that Qantas and the Western Australian Tourism Commission meet regularly to review air services issues in respect of Western Australia.

The Government can, and does, encourage foreign airlines to take up their entitlements to serve Perth. The fact is that at the present time 15 international carriers have been granted rights to serve Perth, but only eight have taken up that right. So the problem is not a lack of negotiating capacity but rather the fact that seven airlines which have a right to service Perth do not take up that right. In the end, airlines will make their own commercial decisions about whether or not they wish to fly to particular ports. If the Western Australian Hotels Association believes that more should be done to get foreign tourists to Western Australia, I suggest that the problem is not one of getting increased capacity but rather increasing the relative attractiveness of Western Australia to foreign tourists, and it should be working harder in that regard.
