There are a substantial number of recommendations. The purpose of recommendation 47 was to avoid the very thing that the Minister has done in his response to this report. I have not added them up but, a significant number of recommendations Nos 20 to 46 are not costed. Why not? Was it too hard for the Department? Was it too much trouble? Does it make the argument a little more difficult to sustain when the Minister responds to the Cross report? Is it a bit embarrassing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Hopeless.

—The Minister says, `Hopeless'. The fact of the matter is that this report, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force and its recommendations are the most damning indictment of a Defence Force situation that this country has had, certainly in my memory and certainly in the memory of the Minister who has the responsibility for it. He must be ashamed of the situation over which he is presiding. We are witnessing the greatest difficulties in securing and maintaining people in the defence forces of his nation that has ever come before this Parliament. What do we find? An inadequate, complacent, self-satisfied response, not dealing with so many of the fundamental issues which have been exposed in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the Ministers at the table that it is not a joking matter. Security is one of the major responsibilities, if not the major responsibility, of government. This report, which is the result of extraordinarily detailed submissions--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bipartisan.

—And which pays great attention to the questioning of witnesses from the full range of people within the ADF of all ranks, with spouses, with civilians concerned with aspects of Defence Force matters, is the most detailed, exhaustive and extensive inquiry into a problem which has been demonstrated to be significantly affecting the capacity of the defence forces to do their job. Let me quote again:

SPEECH.PARA: In sum the effects of wastage adumbrated above amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF. Wastage is undermining the experience and competence levels of personnel.
It goes on:

It is impacting on the capacity of the training and personnel management systems to maintain the Force's integrity. The financial cost arising from the abnormal loss of skilled staff and the increased training effort is enormous.

That is some of the toughest language about a situation in the Australian defence forces ever put down. As my colleague has remarked, it is a bipartisan, all-party two-House report. The Minister has come in here with a lengthy statement of 40 minutes duration, has not addressed the basic underlying reasons which have been clearly set out in the report, has dealt with a few of the recommendations and has given us a response-a pretty weak response-in a supplementary document which has been issued. He has talked about one of the most fundamental areas, that is, the review of ADF pay in a way which is clearly misleading, totally wrong, hiding behind a spurious excuse. Yet he expects this Opposition and this House to respond positively to a most disappointing, a most complacement, a most self-satisfied reaction from a government which, it can be seen from that response, does not take seriously one of the most fundamentally worrying aspects of modern Australian life; that is, a situation within the defence forces which calls for the most serious concern on behalf of the Minister and the Government. Unfortunately, it does not have it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I do not think we are going to find that the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), in his prepared responses, largely read, will make as much use of the 30 to 40 minutes he is allowed as senior Opposition spokesman in participation in debates such as this as did his predecessor as defence spokesman, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who will speak later in the debate. I think he completely misunderstands the nature of the response document which has been put down. Basically, most of the hard matters addressed by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade concerning the question of defence service pay and conditions and the way members of the Defence Force live were addressed in the response of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons). Unaddressed were many of the vagaries contained in the quotes that the honourable member himself used: general expressions of concern about the way in which the defence forces are managed and led which may or may not accord with the facts. They are simply perceptions and many of the recommendations of the Committee are offered up just as perceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is to take note of those, then basically it is a question of how Ministers and leaders in the defence forces choose to conduct themselves in public and the points they intend to make to service personnel who may have those general impressions of overall management. But quite clearly, they are not matters that can be sensibly addressed in the sort of response which the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel was obliged to make today. They may or may not be accurate perceptions, and in a considerable number of those cases they simply have to be addressed by reference to the facts.

For example, one particular quote that was headed off as fact by the honourable member for Warringah was the suggestion that the previous Government had imposed a wage freeze and that had been sustained. That is absolute nonsense. We are supposed to take that particular statement seriously. It may be true that that is a perception, but it is a perception not based on reality. So, indeed, there is a problem for the Minister if that perception is widely held, because I am obliged therefore, by the lesson I draw from the report, to convince Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel of the facts as opposed to an erroneous perception which may be held. But I am not sure that that perception is as widely held as the Committee considers.

There has been one wage freeze in the history of the last decade of Australian politics. That was instituted for a 12-month period by the previous Government. The Defence Minister of the day made absolutely certain that the wages and conditions issues that were to be considered by the committee of reference, which in those days was totally dependent on ministerial direction as opposed to our remuneration tribunal which is not at all, was totally dependent on defence direction. He made absolutely certain that what was to be a reference for a pay increase did not get before it before the decision of the Government overall to legislate to prevent pay rises generally in the community. So the defence forces missed out whereas others went through. Since that time, of course, there have been regular wage adjustments obtained through the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal and substantial increases in service allowances and other aspects of pay and conditions.

So that we can get this debate in perspective, I quote a few statistics in the short time available to me so that when this is debated in a fortnight or so honourable members can base their comments on them. The situation in terms of wastage is now materially different from the time when the Committee sat to consider the matter. On the basis of actual separations to the end of March and known separations for the remaining three months of 1988-89, the following statistics can be offered: Total ADF trained force officer separations in 1988-89 are anticipated to be 15.3 per cent lower than for the previous year. This result is evident in each of the Services, and the detailed comparison is: Royal Australian Navy, down by 8.7 per cent; Army, down 24.9 per cent; Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF), down 9.5 per cent. While ADF trained force officer separations are lower than last year, they are still higher than the long term average. However, Army officers are below the long term average by 9.5 per cent. As is well known, RAAF experienced pilot losses are higher. Projected losses for Air Force other ranks and trained forces are 2.4 per cent lower than for the previous year. Navy projected separations are slightly higher due to two one-off factors. These are separation increases due to an extra apprentice intake which occurred in 1980 and the three intakes of general duties recruits in mid-1987. All of these personnel have completed their contracts. While Army other ranks separations are significantly higher, this is a consequence of the introduction of the open ended enlistment scheme. This increase is a one-time effect with no negative long term implications.

So the situation is now materially different, due to a large number of factors. Some of those factors are entailed in the way in which the Government has chosen over the last few years to address the issue of service pay and conditions. Other of those factors are a product of a generational process through the defence forces. The fact is that we are now coming to the conclusion of a 20-year period after the very substantial intake into the armed services that occurred during the Vietnam war. Those who came in at that point in time-and there was a certain inflation of ranks to cater for that-are now largely moving out of the process. There are still another few years worth of that, but we are getting pretty close to the end of that 20-year period. That no longer impacts upon us.

There will be adjustments from time to time in loss rates in the Services that relate to the performance of the economy generally. I would have thought that it was obvious that if there are skills entailed in the defence forces, and the training services are being provided uniquely in the community, we are going to be the object of depredations from the civilian sector when those skills are in high demand. There has been a sad neglect until recently by the airlines, for example, as regards their obligations to provide training opportunities for pilots.

In terms of the adequacy of the response to this report, whatever the view of the Opposition which is one group that has been notably critical of the Government's response to personnel wastage issues, the Returned Services League of Australia has a totally different response. I quote from Brigadier Alf Garland who today congratulated the Government on accepting 41 of the 48 recommendations made. He said:

These recommendations can be expected to have a significant effect upon the conditions of service for the men and women of the Navy, Army and Air Force. The response shows that the Government has recognised the unique nature of service in the ADF with special conditions to compensate for some of the special disadvantages under which members of the ADF work. I congratulate Minister for Defence Beazley for his actions in bringing about acceptance of the recommendations and past Minister for Defence Personnel Kelly, for the work she did. Minister for Defence Personnel Simmons now has to ensure implementation and allocation of sufficient funds to keep these new programs going.

In fact, most of the things which people have wished us to address on the question of pay and conditions in the armed services that are raised in the report have been addressed by the Government. Many were being addressed before the Cross Committee on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force sat. Whilst there is some recognition in the Cross Committee report of the activities undertaken by the Government, I would be somewhat critical of it in the sense that it did not thoroughly deal with these and analyse their potential impact in the long haul.

One area where I think this Government has reason to be very proud is in the defence service housing area. When I became Minister for Defence there were two essential points of criticism on service pay and conditions. Subsequently, there have been many others, and they have been addressed particularly by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), the former Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, when she came in to take that portfolio. The first issue was that of pay. The Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal began to systematically address that. There have been dramatic increases in service allowances in some areas and substantial increases in service pay. The other area was housing. We hear no more of housing these days. And well we might not, because the performance of the Opposition in this regard makes no comparison whatsoever with the achievement of the Government as far as defence housing is concerned.

We have already provided funding and are committed to a $750m program. In six years we will have authorised nearly 3,500 new houses and completed the same number. This is over 33 per cent more houses than the previous Government achieved in seven years. There have been similar improvements in the area of accommodation for singles in the defence forces. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, in response to the Cross Committee report, has been announcing new flexibility in the housing area to make very substantial improvements in that utterly critical service condition even more effective; that is, widening the range of choice, opening up new opportunities to Defence Force personnel to choose the nature of their accommodation so that they can perhaps have opportunities to save more and acquire their own housing for the long term and in terms of a benefit to enable them to acquire houses. So what the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel was talking about was addressing the serious issues as far as our defence forces are concerned.

I take some comparisons on wages. I take a comparable position from 1 January 1980 to 30 June 1988. In this period a private has had an increase in income of 102 per cent, while an Australian Public Service (APS) equivalent fitter has had an increase of 84.3 per cent; a warrant officer, class 1,109.6 per cent and an APS equivalent, 90.5 per cent; a lieutenant, 101 per cent and an APS equivalent, 83.1 per cent; a lieutenant-colonel, 93.5 per cent and, the APS equivalent, 86.7 per cent; a major-general, 95.1 per cent and the APS equivalent, which is Senior Executive 4, 87.5 per cent.

The point that needs to be made here is that one of the disabilities we have suffered in the Defence Force is that, in any circumstances, it is difficult to maintain morale in peacetime. One has only to ask the fellows going to Namibia what their morale is like. If one then compares that with the morale of the rest of the Defence Force, one will get a pretty good idea of the extent to which peacetime soldiering and peacetime participation in the service is difficult.

One of the problems we have confronted is a persistent misleading of service personnel in respect of the relevant conditions of staying in the service compared with what is available outside. Sometimes it is possible to secure better employment outside but, in many cases, it is not. In fact, after travelling around the bases and talking to service personnel I have found that they have not comprehended the fact that in the community generally people have had considerable difficulty, because of the economic problems faced by the community as a whole, in securing the pay rise that they would like and, in that regard, they are not unique.

One of the lessons from the Cross Committee report that I take seriously-and this goes to those many, I am afraid, very vague sections-relates to the question of leadership. When inaccurate information is conveyed, when there is an impression that there is a unique singling out of the defence forces for unfair activity and when there is criticism of their capacity, capability or whatever-all of which impact on morale-instead of sitting back and taking that as part of the argy-bargy of politics, the chiefs of the various defence forces and I must exercise leadership, get up and counter false propaganda, whether that false propaganda has a basis of misunderstanding or is deliberate in order to secure a political effect. However, one of the things that is certain in respect of the more extravagant claims in the area of pay and conditions, is that there will be well considered cynicism-and the Cross Committee mentions this, too-about whether or not the other side of politics will deliver all that is demanded. Bearing in mind that cynicism, I would say that commonsense ought to suggest that members on both sides of the House should be very careful about inducing it.

The fact of the matter is that the Government has respect for the profession of arms. We have respect for the excellent job they do for this country. We are prepared to call on them in time of need and honour the commitment they make to us. We have respect for them as individuals in our society, for their families and for their pay and conditions. We have exercised that respect in detail in the seven years that we have been in office, and the many improvements in benefits to service personnel in that period are ample testimony to that. Our response in this instance is just one further example-not a new start-of the way in which we have been prepared flexibly and generously to address the needs of our serving personnel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This response is nearly the last that I will make as a shadow Minister, and it seems appropriate that I speak to the report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force-the Cross report. I, with the support of my colleagues, initiated this inquiry by asking the Senate last year to direct the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to examine the wastage which was crippling the Australian Defence Force (ADF). We had to do it that way because the Government would not act, despite the fact that it was told time and again of the problems that were emerging within the Defence Force and the serious implications of a reduction of defence force capabilities. The Government would not act so we took the matter out of its hands and put it into the hands of Parliament through a parliamentary committee. I congratulate the Committee and its chairman, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross), who is in the chamber. The people of Australia thank him and the Committee for the job they did.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I have sat here and listened to the Government's response. Certainly, the report contains things that will be welcomed. I have already heard the Government's response described as evasive, insubstantial, self-congratulatory, inconsistent, bureaucratic, rhetorical and disappointing. In some respects, I agree with all those criticisms. The average soldier, sailor, or airman who picks up this report, which undoubtedly they will do from this afternoon onwards, and reads it will, generally speaking, look in vain for a substantial improvement in his pay and conditions of service. So, generally speaking, I believe that the Government's response has been ineffective basically because of the approach of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I do not know whether that response is still based on ignorance or just academic arrogance. In an interview given by the Minister for Defence in March of this year he said:
The Government does not owe anybody really an explanation on how it is dealing with defence.

That implies that the Government owns the Defence Force instead of its being a very temporary administrator. I believe that there is a reason for this arrogance. The Minister has an academic approach. He has read some books on defence and simply thinks that he knows it all.

I regret to say that in later years, when people look at the period in which the Government was in charge of the Defence Force of this country, the Minister will be judged as a failure, as the man who presided over the destruction of the Australian Defence Force as a viable, effective fighting machine. The Minister has promised much but given little. His first major failure was his continual promise leading up to, and during, the presentation of the White Paper of a real 3 per cent increase per year in defence funding. That has never eventuated and year by year the defence budget has been whittled away. The equipment program, above all else, has been retained and that has meant a continual cut in operations and in personnel programs.

The second failure stems from the continual cuts in the budget. Because the planning proceeded on the basis of a 3 per cent real increase, the equipment programs were maintained. However, anyone who has any understanding of the ADF knows that the essential balance between equipment, personnel and operations has been destroyed. As the experience levels drop, more training-not less-is required and we simply cannot afford to cut back on the operational budget. The Minister has created a disaster in respect of this imbalance which will take years to put right.

The Minister's third failure has been his inability to grasp a proper strategic concept for the Australian Defence Force. Although the Government denies it, it has created a fortress Australia mentality which is simply not appropriate for 1989. It is a `come and get us' mentality which will lead to great problems. Our strategic concept should be based on a strong deterrent, which has been allowed to diminish, based on submarines and F111 aircraft. The F111 group is under threat of disbandment, there is no aerial refuelling and no airborne warning control. The Government has neglected its responsibilities in regard to regional involvement. The regional assistance program is of a minor nature. The regional deployment capability has continued to run down since the Minister took stewardship of the ADF. We still have no helicopter lift ship and no real offshore capability. The Minister is now talking about our deployment capability-I have not heard him deny this but I wish he would-being dependent upon paratroopers. Imagine, as a first response that this country undertakes, dropping paratroopers into some country that is experiencing problems.

The fourth failure, and the one we are really addressing here today, has been the shameful neglect of the Australian Defence Force personnel. The Minister keeps saying that all is well. The fact is that, of the 70,000 men and women who have been looking to this Government for leadership, support and guidance, 50,000 have left in the last six years. It is not just 50,000 over a base of 70,000; it is 50,000 over a base of 62,000, because the other 7,000-odd are under training. In another year or so the Minister will have turned over the equivalent of the entire Australian Defence Force, yet Government Ministers stand up here day after day saying that all is well. Today I hear Ministers saying that the rate is declining. It is declining for one very good reason-that there are not enough people left in the Services who have served sufficient time to get out. That is the exact point that the Royal Australian Air Force made at a recent meeting. Of course the rate is declining, because the base is declining. For years the government has ignored this problem. It was passed on to Minister Kelly, who started off by saying in August 1987:
And frankly I think the whole issue is being incredibly exaggerated.

I must say that following that she improved her performance. She did try, but with a lack of resources there was not much she could do. It is no wonder she ran for cover at the first opportunity, knowing that this response to the Cross report was coming down. Now we have a new Minister, Minister Simmons, who has been sold a dump. He started off by saying the other day, when talking about the RAAF problems:
I specifically reject the suggestion that the RAAF lacks sufficient aircrew to deal with anything more than the most benign contingency.

That was the very thing the RAAF was telling him. The new Minister comes in here and says that he rejects it. I do not know on what basis he rejected it. Minister Beazley continues to deny that there is a problem. Again today he said that everything is going well and that the problem was caused by the Vietnam hump. Most of the people who served in Vietnam have long since gone. That has nothing to do with the current wastage problem. The Minister says that one of the reasons for the wastage is that people are coming to the end of a 20-year service period. If he looks at the figures he will see that most people are going well before they have done 20 years. I do not know whether he is speaking from gross ignorance or just bad advice.

There is some credit to be given to Minister Beazley, and that is for the restructuring of the Australian defence support industries, and we spoke about those here yesterday. But in all other aspects he has failed. He does not yet understand what he has done to the Australian Defence Force. The best summary of the Minister's performance, I believe, was in a recent article by a very experienced defence correspondent called Peter Young, who said:

. . . the reality is a politician who was rolled in Cabinet in his first major funding fight and who is now desperately trying to stretch out the lowest allocation of GDP to defence in nearly forty years. A strategist who has been proven disastrously wrong in his assessment of our regional environment . . . A leader who has turned his back on the special demands of the men and women under his command and seen more than half of them vote with their feet. A Minister who has seen his White Paper fall apart in tatters as his brave new plans for reform have been stretched from five to twenty-five years.

The fact is that the state of our Defence Force is abysmal. I have spoken about the lack of balance between equipment and operations and personnel. A lack of a proper strategic concept and a lack of attention to personnel have resulted in a sadly debilitated state. We think back to our disastrous reaction to the Fiji coup in 1987, not because of any lack of effort on the part of the personnel who took part, but simply because they did not have the resources to do the job. Since then, the situation has gone backwards.
Let us look at what the Services say about themselves. There are cries from the heart for someone to help them. The RAAF. in a recent report, said:

It is unarguable that the current aircrew to aircraft ratio is so low that the RAAF would be incapable of fully utilizing its assets in any situation except for the most benign contingency, and then only if this was transitory in nature.
What more damning report can we get than that? The Royal Australian Navy said in its report:

Greater emphasis on unit training is required to compensate for this low level of operator and maintainer experience . . . generally, ships have achieved most annual continuation training targets, but have maintained a less than optimum level of proficiency in some areas.
So it goes on. The Army reports similarly. And the Minister for Defence has the hide to get up in here and say that there has been no loss in Defence Force capabilities.

In conclusion, I want to address some remarks to people in the Department of Defence and the Australian Defence Force. As far as the Department is concerned, it is true that it has been heavily politicised. Anyone in the Department will tell us that, and it is a much poorer department for it. It is not offering frank advice to the Minister; it is not saying what should be done; it is trying to anticipate what the Minister and the Government want. It is certainly offering the advice that the Minister wants to hear. Either the public servants who are doing that are frightened or they simply do not understand. If they are frightened, there is no hope for them. If they do not understand, they should take the advice of experienced service men and women who, to many public servants, are simply becoming irrelevant as the Public Service gets its grip on the Department of Defence. I remind those public servants that they are there to serve the nation and the military forces of this country and not to impose their own standards, disciplines and ideas on those military forces.

To the leaders of the ADF, who have been criticised here today by other speakers, I say this: You have a great responsibility to the men and women you command. I urge you to put them before your own personal ambitions or the whims and obsessions of politicians. Not all the leaders in the ADF have done so. I urge you to give your advice strongly and fearlessly to politicians and to public servants, most of whom simply do not understand what is happening in the defence forces in this country. I remind you that your soldiers, sailors and airmen are depending on you. They have nobody else to turn to because the Government has let them down. Lastly, I thank the men and women in the Defence Force for their contribution under difficult conditions in recent years. The Australian nation owes them a great debt of gratitude, and I want to put that on the record from the people of Australia.

Finally, to the Government and the Ministers I say this: Stop posturing and prancing where the ADF is concerned. Take a look at what is happening in the forces and move to fix it before it is too late. You have been dragged screaming to confront the problems by the Parliament and the Cross Committee giving you the evidence of what is happening in the Australian Defence Force. Regrettably today you have made a wimpish response and even in this simple test you have failed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The hardship suffered by veterans, ex-prisoners of war and war widows under the federal Government's cut-backs and complex changes since May 1985.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is, in many ways, defence and veterans' affairs day in the House of Representatives. There are Bills for debate tonight on Namibia and Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. There has been the response to the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade about personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force-the Cross report. At the instigation of the Opposition, reflecting its priorities for veterans and war widows, there is, on this broadcast day, this very important matter of public importance for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment to veterans is a debt owned by a nation as a whole to those who fought for their country in time of war. The whole matter of repatriation should, to the maximum extent possible, be dealt with on a bipartisan basis as an obligation to those who served. Indeed, let me quote two former Prime Ministers-one from each side. Ben Chifley, speaking about those who served their country in time of war, once told this House:
On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done . . .
Sir Arthur Fadden told this House:
A grateful nation must see that those who are privileged to return from battle areas shall be properly cared for.

What have we had since the mini-Budget of May 1985? What has impacted on the half a million veterans of World War I, World War II, Korea, Malaya, Vietnam and other conflicts, on their dependants and on ex-service personnel generally? According to the Bureau of Statistics the veterans community is quite large-some one million people. We have had a series of cutbacks and a series of very complex changes. The situation reached the stage where, on the day after Anzac Day, some 2,000 veterans rolled up to a rally in the Sydney Town Hall. It was not even an official rally for veterans' organisations, but it was one which enjoyed the support of the State President of the Returned Services League (RSL) Sir Colin Hines. In attendance was a very determined group of veterans and war widows. The apology of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) was recorded.

At that rally a statement was made which should have shaken this Government to the core. The statement was that the veterans had not had a fair go under this Government. They did not want excessive entitlements or indulgent government expenditure; they wanted the right to a proper and dignified latter-day life for the service they had given to their country.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs was not there. I acknowledge the reason for that. It was that he was the Minister officially escorting the Vice-President of the United States of America, Dan Quayle. But I do not accept the fact that no other Minister was sent to that rally in his place. There was not even a senator or a lower House member from the Government to represent the Minister. Who was sent? The Deputy Commissioner of the Repatriation Commission in Sydney was sent. He did a workmanlike job; but it was not his job. It was a rally dealing with policy. Notice was given of that rally and no Minister turned up on the occasion to represent the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

I regret to say that this afternoon we saw, for the first time, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs cross the Rubicon and cast personal reflections upon me at Question Time. That is particularly regrettable. I have always conducted the veterans' affairs debate on a bipartisan basis as much as possible. I have spoken of policy matters and decisions and not cast any personal reflections.

It is the Minister's decisions which rankle the veterans and war widows that we are addressing today. Let us look at some of those decisions. Let us go back to just prior to the 1985 mini-Budget. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) will remember that at that time the assets test was ripping the heart out of veterans through cutbacks in service pensions. Some 13,000 veterans lost their service pensions or had their service pensions reduced. Poverty traps were created in particular areas, especially on the north coast of New South Wales and in northern Victoria, because of the flawed design of the assets test introduced by the Hawke Labor Government. It was only after campaigning by the coalition and the RSL that the Government brought in the hardship provisions and made some adjustments. But that was too late for many veterans, who saw it as a bitter pill in recognition of their service to this country. We then had the 1985 mini-Budget and the travel allowance was halved. That affected veterans travelling from Gippsland to Heidelberg for specialist treatment and from suburbs all round Melbourne to specialists in Glen Waverley. At the same time, the related subsistence allowance was also halved. There has been very little adjustment since that time.

What did the Government do then about dental treatment for veterans? It placed a limit of $300 on four categories of dental treatment. Mark my words, this was four years ago-the 1985 mini-Budget. Has there been an adjustment of that $300 limit since May 1985-four years ago? No, there has been no adjustment. So the real value of that limit has come down with the increase in dental costs. The Minister should be ashamed of his approach to that issue. Last week in Question Time we gave him a chance to explain that, but he passed it up.

Honourable members might well ask: Who squibbed what? Finally, in the May 1985 mini-Budget we had the tightening up of the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) criteria. It was brought into the Parliament late one night and subsequently affirmed in the Veterans Entitlements' Bill which came in later in that month of May 1985. An official report of the Government says that it is saving more than $100m a year in respect of the cutbacks in the TPI criteria. In conjunction with the RSL, the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association, the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council and others, we had to battle to get the Government to take on board the anomaly which that provision created. Time does not allow me to detail it, other than to say that our policy came out earlier last year before that report came out-as it happened, by a matter of weeks-and in it we declared our support for the introduction of an extreme disability adjustment. Subsequently, the report recommended that. I will give credit where credit is due. For once, the Government moved rather quickly. In the subsequent Budget, the Government adopted the extreme disability adjustment, but adopted it on criteria which are so stringent that only a handful of veterans in relative terms have qualified in the first four months of its operation. Again, those criteria must be reviewed. It is a commitment of the coalition's fair go policy for veterans that it will review the criteria for the granting of the extreme disability adjustment.

I roll forward to the Federal Budget of 1986. What happened in that Budget? War widows were eliminated from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. On this day across the nation chemists have closed for two hours. For the first time in the history of this nation they have closed down as a reflection of their protest at what the Government has been doing to pharmaceutical benefits not only in the broader national health sphere but also in the repatriation sphere. That cutback was introduced and it has been in existence ever since. The war widows' social security component was frozen at $60.05. It had no consumer price index loading on it and has remained frozen ever since.

The Government also took that opportunity to break its contract with former service personnel and impose a further 2 per cent cutback, which we campaigned against. To give credit where credit is due, I am pleased to say that that was reversed in the economic statement of two weeks ago. It is a matter of record that that economic statement merely began to address and rectify the raft of cutbacks and complex changes imposed by this Government. If it was otherwise, a crowd of 2,000 would not have been attracted to the Sydney Town Hall two weeks after the economic statement.

I move on to list a number of other areas of cutbacks but I will not go through them all because I know my colleagues supporting me will concentrate on ex-prisoners of war. I acknowledge that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has spoken very well on that subject in recent weeks. He has been forced to because of a lack of action. Let us turn to what happened with regard to Defence service homes. I remember a headline in a Townsville newspaper which read `Minister Vague about Changes on Defence Service Homes'. It refers to this Minister in his portfolio.

Let us deal with this matter of the consultant. It goes to the heart of the matter. I now know why no Government representative turned up at the Town Hall. It is because he or she would not have been game enough to face the music if I revealed that the Government paid a part-time consultant $215,000 to assist with the transfer of the Defence Service Home Loans Corporation from the Minister's portfolio to the Westpac Banking Corporation. How would that have gone down? I would not have been safe because they would have been so upset about the situation that they would have rocked the floor and the roof would have come down. That is the score. An amount of $215,000 was paid. There were no complaints about the Minister employing a consultant. There were no complaints about the consultant he employed. He is a man of recognised ability. I acknowledge that but that is not the issue. The issues are, firstly, that the Minister knew about it last Tuesday and, secondly, the amount of $215,000. In the official documents we turned up late yesterday, after our prodding in Senate Estimates and the eventual response, we found that the consultant undertook preliminary negotiations. He interceded on major points of issue and he provided general oversight to the project. More particularly, his period of consultancy was officially for six months from January to June 1988, with a five month informal extension on the basis of a diminishing work-load.

We should tell the war veterans and war widows that this Government found $215,000 and agreed to that payment whilst at the same time maintaining a $300 limit on four categories of dental treatment and, more recently, imposing a $5,000 statutory patient contribution on veterans in nursing homes for war related conditions, including World War I veterans and TPI veterans. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), who has taken a deep interest in the plight of World War I veterans, has highlighted the real hardship that has caused. I am proud to be able to tell the House that, in accordance with the coalition policy in respect of veterans' affairs, on gaining government there is a black and white absolute commitment that we will abolish that statutory patient contribution on World War I veterans, TPI veterans and those in that category who are ex-prisoners of war. That is in our policy. It is a clear cut reversal of the Minister's and the Government's decision to impose a statutory patient contribution.

The Minister will no doubt say, `What did we do when we were in Government?'. He will say that it has boosted overall expenditure from $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion. That masks the real situation. He knows that half of that amount-$2 billion-relates to service pensions. The majority of that $2 billion is the equivalent of the aged pension and will be paid for by the Government in that category anyway. If we take that away we get down to the nitty gritty of what this Government is spending on veterans' affairs. Of course there is not an unlimited chest of Government money to spend on veterans' affairs. But we have to maximise that dollar, bring compassion to the administration of veterans' affairs, boost the payments as is appropriate where responsible Government can afford to do so, because we are aware of the decline in their standard of living under this Government, and provide above all a fair go for those who served their country in time of war. One war widow said:

Mr Hawke won his seat in Parliament on the promises that he would help the poor including pensioners but to me he failed woefully . . . I would like to know how the men in power would like to be a pensioner-
or war widows, or veterans-
and then be asked to pay everything when all concessions are taken away. It leaves us well below the bread and dripping line.

That sums up the plight of veterans and war widows under the six years of this Government and, more particularly, since May 1985. I say of this Minister, good chap as he may well be regarded and no doubt is, that I proffer no personal reflections but I do object strongly to his decisions in respect of gold embossed calling cards and gold embossed consultants. Where is the gold, silver and bronze for those who served their country in time of war?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) has misrepresented the facts, as he always does. Once again he used the typical old Liberal-National Party scaremongering tactics against those poor and infirmed veterans and aged persons whom we look after. That is his trait all the time-scaremongering, running around the country and misrepresenting me. I will put a few facts straight. He was talking about the cutbacks in the Department of Veterans' Affairs but spent most of his time denigrating Mr Uhrig and saying why I was not at this so-called veterans' rally in Sydney, where there were supposedly 2,000 veterans. When Sir Colin Hines asked for a show of hands of how many people were from rent-a-crowd, they were not game to put their hands up. The honourable member knows that. He also knows that Sir Colin Hines only turned up; he was not invited. He decided to go because the whole thing was set up to try to get Sir Colin to come. The honourable member knows that. He took part in that. I am sure Sir Colin will be interested in the fact that the honourable member took part in a rally that was not even organised by any veterans' organisation. I will put him on notice here now and the rest of those people--
—He was on the stage.
—He had to be; he turned up. It was not organised by any veterans' organisation or any organisation affiliated with the Returned Services League.
—Two thousand veterans were there.

—There were not 2,000 veterans there. The honourable member is once again misrepresenting the facts. I ask the honourable member to get up and say that Sir Colin did not ask how many veterans were there. He did and they all booed Sir Colin because they were not game. It was one of the honourable member's rent-a-crowds again. Nevertheless, he knew full well that I sent a letter on 3 March refusing-
—I have acknowledged that.
—The honourable member said that I squibbed and did not turn up. I do not squib anything. Why does he not tell the truth for once in his life?
—You were escorting Dan Quayle.

—I was asked to be the Minister in attendance with Dan Quayle. Why was Dan Quayle over here? He was here because of the Coral Sea remembrance. The honourable member does not even appreciate that. He does not say that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs was there because of that. He just wants to say that I squibbed. I did not squib anything. I will not turn up to any rally that is not organised by a legitimate veterans' organisation. The honourable member would turn up to any show or fun fair to misrepresent the facts, as he has always done.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member is saying that there should be a fair go for the veterans and that the Liberal and National parties are all about a fair go for veterans. What happened when the Business Council of Australia made its recommendations that there were not enough cuts by this Government and the first thing that we should do was to do away with the Department of Veterans' Affairs? Who does the honourable member think agreed with that and said that the Business Council of Australia did not go far enough? It was the new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). He said it did not go far enough and that it was right in what it said. He said we should do away with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. What about the acting shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)? Do honourable members want me to remind them of what he said in an interview? He said that he lived in fear of being the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. We have two senior shadow Ministers in the Opposition, one saying that we should do away with the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the other one saying that he lives in fear. That is what the Opposition thinks of the veterans' community. The honourable member knows that as well as I do. I know he has had a tough job and he is going to have a tougher job staying on the front bench with this new team. I know he cares for veterans but he is misrepresenting the facts again.

The honourable member for Farrer says that there have been cutbacks. Let me tell him about a couple of those cutbacks. He said that we have a $300 limit on certain types of dental treatment. There are no financial limits on any dental treatment required for war caused disabilities or on treatment required for cancer. This includes approved specialist dental treatment and the provision of full and partial acrylic dentures. The honourable member for Farrer knows all this, but he again misrepresents the facts and refers to the $300 limit. The $300 limit applies only to certain special dental treatments-gold fillings and other special treatments. But any veteran who is in need of treatment is entitled to get it, as long as he gets approval. The honourable member knows that that is the case, but once again he wants to scare the veterans and those in need, the people that the honourable member is supposed to be representing in this place.

I now want to refer to total and permanent incapacity (TPI) eligibility. Once again, the honourable member for Farrer knows full well what the TPI eligibility is. He knows that originally it was for totally and permanently incapacitated veterans who came back from the war with bad injuries. The TPI was introduced some 60 years ago. The honourable member knows that the legislation was changed to provide that the TPI payment would not be made once a person reached the age of 65 years unless that person could show a loss of earnings or income. The honourable member knows all this, and his policy does not indicate that a government of which he would be a part would reintro- duce it. I will refer to the Opposition's policy and the flaws that are in it. Would the honourable member advocate the reintro- duction of TPI for people over 65 years of age? He would not be prepared to do that at all, but he is in here again misrepresenting the facts, saying that we have cut out the TPI. The honourable member is absolutely unbelievable in the way he misrepresents the facts. He and I both know what the TPI eligibility criteria are.

The honourable member for Farrer talked about the extreme disability allowance. He said that he was the one who introduced it. However, it was introduced as a result of a recommendation by the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. The honourable member knew what it was all about but he jumped on the bandwagon and said that that was part of his policy. He knew that the recommendation was going to be made. Who provided this allowance for veterans? It was not honourable members opposite. What did the honourable member's colleagues do in all of the years that they were in power? I think the honourable member for Farrer's best effort in this Parliament was to hand the ex-Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), a question in relation to veterans. He will not take any more questions from the honourable member because we know where he finished up. What a question that was!

The honourable member for Farrer wanted to know what we were going to do about ex-prisoners of war. The honourable member knew full well the answer to a question asked by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren). The honourable member for Reid speaks in here from the heart about ex-prisoners of war. `Tough Tim' was up here thinking that this was his chance to hop on Tommy's coat-tails. However, for nearly two years the honourable member has paid no attention to veterans whatsoever.

It has been two years since a matter of public importance on veterans was last debated in this place. It is on now because honourable members opposite are all in disarray. They said `We'll give poor old Tim a go today', and he is scaremongering in the veterans' community again. I find the honourable member unbelievable. I honestly thought I could talk to the honourable member and that I could trust him, but after today I know that I cannot trust him. However, I will still talk to the honourable member and try to help him whenever I can, because he is in trouble. He knows that as well as I do.

The honourable member for Farrer talked about the nursing home contribution regarding veterans. He knows that the purpose of this scheme is to bring all veterans into line with one another. There could be one veteran in a nursing home who was not paying the contribution and another TPI veteran who was paying the contribution. Every veteran is treated equally in a nursing home. The honourable member knows that. The honourable member talks about some people being required to pay the nursing home fees. How many people are involved? Why does the honourable member not tell the truth? The honourable member for Farrer may be able to tell the Parliament and the veterans' community how many people he is going to look after. I ask the honourable member to get up and tell the truth about how many there are. The honourable member knows full well that that payment is the contribution that veterans make for their board and lodgings. The Government and the taxpayers of Australia contribute another $18,000 on top of that. The honourable member is misrepresenting the facts again in relation to those poor veterans, those deserving people who need special treatment. They need support and should not be subject to the scaremongering tactics that the honourable member goes on with all the time.

The honourable member gets up and says that the war widows were taken off the repatriation and pharmaceutical benefits scheme. He knows as well as I do that the repatriation and pharmaceutical benefits scheme was introduced to help veterans who came back with war caused injuries. That was the reason for the scheme. In addition, 82 per cent of the drugs that are covered by the repatriation scheme are on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-and that is what the war widows are entitled to. The extra drugs that are covered by the repatriation scheme-and the honourable member knows this-are for use by service men and women with special war caused injuries.

The honourable member also misrepresented the facts about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. He referred to the drugs that have been taken off the list. But the honourable member knows that it is the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee-not the Government-which decides what drugs go on the list and what drugs come off in relation to the repatriation and pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is made up of eminent pharmacologists and pharmacists who determine what drugs will be affected. God help us if ever politicians and bureaucrats decide what drugs will be allowed. Some drugs are taken off the list because they have side effects or they are addictive. The honourable member tries to make out they are taken off for a special reason and that they are being taken away from the veterans.

The Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee contains a nominee of the Returned Services League (RSL) and nominees from other veterans organisations. None other than Major-General Digger Jones, a famous Vietnam and Korea veteran, is on the Committee. He is the representative of the veterans' community. The honourable member for Farrer will say that he is not denigrating people on the Committee, that he is not accusing them but that he is accusing me. The honourable member knows full well who is on the Committee and who determines which drugs will be on the list. Once again, the honourable member has been caught out misrepresenting the facts. All he can come up with are some incorrect facts about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, war widows and dental treatment.

I now want to refer to the famous policy of the Liberal and National parties. They say that they would have a separate modern Department of Veterans' Affairs. Once again, the honourable member has pinched the Australian Labor Party's policy. His policy is almost identical to ours. He could not write his own policy so he copied ours. He says that we must have a good look at a so-called modern new department.

Also as part of his policy, the honourable member says that a Liberal-National Party government would further improve the repatriation hospital system throughout Australia. How much do members opposite think that taxpayers and the Department of Veterans' Affairs had to pay to tidy up the mess that they left in the rehabilitation hospitals? We have spent over $100m on refurbishing and putting new equipment into those repatriation hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Over $100m. Yet, here is the honourable member saying that the coalition would look after the hospitals. When members opposite were in government they certainly did a great job! All honourable members opposite should ask themselves what they did on behalf of veterans when they were in government. What did they do for the ex-prisoners of war? What did they do for the Vietnam veterans? Which government sent the Vietnam veterans overseas to war? What did it do for them when they came back. The honourable member for Farrer is an ex-Vietnam veteran, and I am proud of him for that. But what did the previous government do when, for example, the Vietnam veterans asked the Government for a royal commission into Agent Orange?
—We said no.
—And which government gave them one? It was the present Government.
—It was a great help to them!

—Yes, it is a great help to them. The honourable member is again misrepresenting another lot of decent people. Today the honourable member again misrepresented Mr Uhrig. Let me just read to the House what the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) said in respect of consultants. At the time of the sale, the honourable member for Ryan said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government had relied on naive officials of the Attorney-General's Department to negotiate with specialists in private enterprise who had far greater commercial nous. The government should have followed the practice in other countries and hired outside consultants to sell the loans.

So there we have the National Party saying one thing and the honourable member for Ryan saying another, saying that we should have hired some expert outside consultants. Mr Uhrig has done a great job. The honourable member denigrated Sir William Keys today. Sir William Keys was on the Committee also. It is a great policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments already made in this chamber today by my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I assure listeners in this House and in the outside world that I have seen him in action at my own Returned Services League (RSL) club at Ringwood in Victoria. I emphatically assert that he sticks to the facts and represents only National or Liberal Party policy. I am happy to have him in my RSL club at any time.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking here today about repaying a debt so enormous that perhaps it can never be sufficiently repaid. Sadly, we are talking about the fact that this Government has stepped back from its responsibilities and obligations to people to whom we all owe so much, the men and women who have served in our defence forces during times of conflict, and their dependants who were called upon to share the sacrifices made by their loved ones.

In this regard, there are past and present members on both sides of both Houses of this Parliament who have first hand experience of what I am talking about. Two who come immediately to mind are my geographically, if not ideologically, close colleague, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) whose father died as a prisoner of war working on the construction of the notorious Burma railway, and my South Australian colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), whose father-a former member of this House and Minister during the Menzies years and then High Commissioner in London-was also taken prisoner by the Japanese. I understand that he was a prisoner in Changi at the same time as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and that they were good friends. I use these two examples to illustrate that the effects and legacies of war cross all political boundaries, as should our attitudes towards the treatment and compensation of war veterans and their dependants. If ever their was an issue calling for bipartisan consideration and action, this is one.

At this point I want to pay a very sincere if inadequate tribute to a man who throughout his 30 years in this Parliament has continued to campaign for fair and adequate compensation for former prisoners of war, in particular those who suffered imprisonment by the Japanese Imperial Army during the Second World War. I mentioned his name just a few moments ago. I refer, of course, to the honourable member for Reid. Yesterday in this House the honourable member for Reid delivered one of the most moving, graphic, compassionate and convincing speeches I have ever heard, and I would urge members of the Parliament and of the community generally who did not hear the honourable member's speech to make sure they obtain a copy of Hansard and read it for themselves-read it and think about it. I ask the House to consider the almost indescribable hardships, the horrifying deprivations and the extent of the courage shown and sacrifices made by these men and women, and then to consider the manner in which a supposedly grateful nation is compensating them for the way in which they suffered and endured, and in many cases are still suffering and enduring.

This Government has its priorities all wrong. It can and definitely does find money to fund all sorts of ineffective and inefficient projects. The list is far too long to quote here, but many examples will readily spring to the minds of all honourable members, but the Government cannot find sufficient funds to properly compensate and care for our veterans, our former prisoners of war, and our war widows. What a disgraceful and unacceptable state of affairs. The cutbacks and complex changes introduced by successive Ministers of Veterans' Affairs during the Hawke administration have created disbelief, hurt and confusion amongst the veteran community, and those depending on the Department of Veterans' Affairs for assistance and support. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in this House during Question Time last week said:
The Government looks after the veterans of this nation more than anybody else in this country.

That statement is a most questionable one. It is also insulting to those groups and organisations such as Legacy and the RSL, which are dedicated to and actively involved in serving and caring for veterans and their dependants and families, often providing far more in the way of practical assistance and moral support than this Government could or would ever do.

The Minister went on to say that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) were obliged to give consideration to the important and urgent matters regarding former prisoners of war of the Japanese, that were raised the day before in a question from the honourable member for Reid. Again I quote the Minister's words:
. . . all the consideration for which the honourable member for Reid has asked.

Surely, after 44 years, the time for consideration is over and the time for action has arrived. As the honourable member for Reid said in his speech yesterday, `Action not taken immediately will prove too late for the ever dwindling survivors of the Japanese prison camps of the Second World War'. The same is true of all veterans, prisoners of war and their dependants. If the Government waits long enough before taking the action it is morally obliged to take there will not be many left to receive the benefits and entitlements which are unarguably their due.

A case in point was a veteran I was proud to number amongst my constituents. I refer to the late Bill Elliott, a First World War veteran who served in the Gallipoli campaign and later in the muddy trenches in France. Bill Elliott was badly gassed whilst serving in France. He suffered from the physical effects of this dreadful experience for the rest of his life. When he returned from the war, he worked as a coal miner. Nothing could be worse.

He fought a continuing battle against the Department of Veterans' Affairs in a vain endeavour to gain recognition for the fact that his serious respiratory problems were attributable, at least in part, to his war service. He took his case to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and then to court. He died before his claim could be finalised. He believed the Department was playing a waiting game, and I am afraid that I agree with him. The amount of compensation being sought was relatively small, but to Bill Elliott it was the principle that was most important. He was a fine old man-a proud and honest man-and until the day he died he believed he was being unfairly deprived of something that was rightfully his, and he could not understand why.

Although he kept fighting for proper recognition and compensation, the odds were against him because of his health and his age. The Turks and the Germans could not beat him or break his spirit, but the Department of Veterans' Affairs could, and did.

I think Bill Elliott's experience sums up the saddest aspect of this whole issue. Men and women put their lives on the line for freedom and democracy and for the protection and preservation of the Australian way of life we hold so dear. Their loved ones kept the home fires burning and took on all the other responsibilities and challenges of the home front. They simply cannot comprehend why they have to fight so hard to achieve fair, just and reasonable recognition of, and compensation for, their efforts and sacrifices.

They do not understand the reasoning behind, or justification for, the fact that they are increasingly the targets for penny-pinching, pettifogging, cost-saving measures introduced by an uncaring and unsympathetic Government. Such measures-and these are just a few examples-the halving of assistance for country veterans who must travel long distances to obtain necessary health care; the exclusion of war widows from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme; a $300 per year limit on the cost of dental treatment; and the imposition of a yearly $5,000 statutory patient contribution on veterans in nursing homes, particularly when they require this level of care because of war related conditions.

I reiterate here that the coalition is committed to abolishing the statutory patient contribution for World War I and totally and permanently incapacitated veterans immediately we are returned to government.

Some of these measures are only saving a few hundred thousand dollars, but they are causing untold hardship and heartbreak. I ask the Minister and the Government: What price the life of a husband and father who died in the service of his country? What price the sadness and suffering of the widow and children he left behind? What price the horrifying physical and emotional experiences of those who served as prisoners of war, particularly in Japan? What price the lives of young men and women which have been ruined forever because of the terrible experiences of war? I refer to people who left our shores as confident, fit 17- and 18-year-olds, and who returned broken in health and sometimes even in spirit, those who have had to cope on a daily basis for years and years with the ghastly legacy of permanent physical or mental damage.

I believe that no price is too great-and I am confident that this belief is shared by the vast majority of Australians. I am confident that most people are appalled when they discover that our veterans are not receiving the same level of government care and consideration as are their counterparts in, for example, Canada or the United States. I share the sentiments of the honourable member for Reid when he said, as only he can, is his Grievance Debate speech of 20 October 1988:
It is about time that all the penny-pinching, miser- able and narrow-minded people with cash register hearts had some compassion for some of the conditions of these ex-servicemen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). I have great pleasure in doing so, as I too have had personal experience of this matter through my father, who was a celebrated Australian Rat of Tobruk. I have childhood memories of those people who served in the Second World War and later wars. The Minister dealt with many of the misrepresentations by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), which were reiterated by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). It is worth noting that since 1983 allocations to Veterans' Affairs have increased.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for Farrer laughs at this, but this is a fact which is indisputable. In fact, that is an acknowledgment of our financial commitment to veterans in the community. The rate of service pension has increased from 22 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to its current level of 24.9 per cent. These facts are indisputable and acknowledge the fact that veterans within our community need financial support. This Government is prepared to make that kind of financial commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member for Farrer of the 23 years in which the Opposition was in government and the kinds of financial outlays which were made to veterans in our community. We have expanded the financial commitment of government to our veteran community. In the last April statement the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that indexation would be brought forward and put into play for our service pensioners. Earlier, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs outlined the need for $114m worth of expenditure to upgrade, expand, modernise and improve the repatriation facilities system and our hospital system, which will ensure the delivery of quality health care to the veteran community. As the Minister outlined-and I reiterate-the fact is that those services had been allowed to run down.

What we see now is a government committed to the health care of our veterans and prepared to spend money on them. We have replaced the operating theatre and support facilities at the Concord Repatriation Hospital. We have replaced six wards in the outpatients department of the Heidelberg Hospital. In my own State of Queensland the support facilities and operating theatres at the Greenslopes Hospital have been replaced and modernised. Operating theatres have been replaced and refurbished at the Daw Park Hospital and at the repatriation hospital in Western Australia. In fact, in every State of Australia we have seen an upgrading of operating facilities for our veterans.

This surely shows care and concern for our veterans and their health, to ensure that they get the very best of medical treatment and hospital care. The Government has spent a further $58m on buying specialised equipment to put into the repatriation health care system. Why? Because we acknowledge that those veterans have very special health needs. It is only through acknowledging this fact and acting upon it by the purchase of specialised equipment that these needs can be met.

In August 1988 the Commonwealth announced that it would negotiate with State Governments for the integration of the repatriation general hospitals into the State health systems. Why would it do this? It did this to provide the ageing population with care closer to home, family and friends; to ensure that our veterans can go to the hospital closest to them and be treated in the best possible way; and to enable us to attract the very best of staff to look after our veterans because hospitals which have a mix of patients and illnesses attract staff and retain them. It meant also that repatriation hospitals are part of our regional health networks in each State, forcing States to acknowledge that repatriation hospitals and the care of our veterans must be central and an integral part of any health program and of any health system in the community.

The honourable member for Farrer says that none of this counts and that this shows an uncaring and ungenerous government. That is simply nonsense. We have the unambiguous guarantees given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that integration will not proceed until such time as veterans can be guaranteed priority of access. That priority is essentially what we are about. It is important to acknowledge that what we want and what we must ensure always is first class attention for our veterans.

One of the programs of which I am particularly proud is the Joint Venture Scheme. It has received a total of $2m from the Government since its introduction in October 1985-not in 1965 or 1955, when the Opposition was in Government and supposedly caring for our veterans, but in 1985, when we were in Government. The objective of this scheme is to provide services to veterans within their own homes and to ensure that they get good home care. The two schemes of which I have intimate knowledge provide lawn mowing and companionship services to veterans to enable them to live in their own homes and in their own community, to maintain their friends and also to attend their local Returned Services League club, where they can reminisce and feel part of the veteran community.

The Joint Venture Scheme stands as one of the things of which our veterans are very proud and, in fact, proud to participate in. Let me say as a member of this Government that I am very proud to be associated with a scheme which acknowledges that people have different needs and treats people as individuals, caring for them not just on a simpering level but in a very real and caring way.

We have heard a lot of discussion today about totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pensions. Of course, nobody has acknowledged that this Government has amended the Veteran's Entitlements Act to ensure that TPI pensions are paid for life, clarifying an adverse Federal Court judgment concerning that eligibility. There has been no acknowledgment of that fact by members of the Opposition. The reforms that have been inculcated with the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1987 give an overall perspective of the care and concern for veterans in this country.

As part of the 1987-88 Budget, prisoners of war (POWs) in Nazi camps became entitled to a one-off grant of $10,000. There has been no acknowledgment of that. We have heard lots of discussions about prisoners of war and the trials and hardships they endured-and nobody in the community would not acknowledge that-but it was not until 1987 that that was acknowledged in a visible and practical way by a payment to veterans. It is easy to have rhetoric, but this Government has made the rhetoric reality. It has ensured that veterans in the community will get quality health care, that POWs in Nazi camps are acknowledged and that their service pensions are expanded and are at a higher proportion of average weekly earnings now than they were during the whole period the Opposition was in Government.

The Government has also set up a monitoring committee to examine the operation of veterans' entitlements, to ensure that those entitlements continue to meet the needs of the veterans in our community. Also, this Government acknowledges that it is very important to make sure always that the contribution of veterans to our community is maintained and acknowledged. In fact, we do this in a number of ways, such as the Gardens of Remembrance and the Australian War Memorial, which was allocated $4.5m in the 1988-89 Budget for the improvement of its collections, research and ceremonial functions. We have also expanded the Memorial's exhibition area. All of these things acknowledge the role played by veterans and the important contribution they have made to this great country. It is simply not true to say that we are not concerned with veterans. In fact, the changes which this Government has brought in, in a mere six years, have ensured that the veteran community acknowledges it is cared for. The Department of Veterans' Affairs, in this, its seventieth anniversary year, will continue to fulfil the Government's commitment to care for our war-injured and those who have suffered the effects of war. I am very proud to be part of a government whose commitment to the veteran community is such that it is unequivocal. We are prepared to acknowledge the very generous contribution of those veterans to our community.
