DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF THE RADIO AND ORCHESTRA PROJECT FOR THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION, SOUTHBANK, MELBOURNE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of the radio and orchestra project, Southbank, Melbourne, for the ABC.

This proposed public work for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is to be on a site at Southbank Boulevarde in South Melbourne. My colleague Senator Gareth Evans, as the then Minister for Transport and Communications, approved the purchase of this Southbank site in August 1988. Currently, the ABC operates from eight separate premises around Melbourne. Of these, only one was purpose-designed, the remainder having been adapted from commercial offices, factories and a cinema. Three of the properties, Broadcast House, Waverley Theatre, and East Burwood, are owned by the ABC. The ABC has advised that rental and operational savings likely to be achieved by this project will be approximately $2.4m per year. Funding will be achieved from the sale of the three ABC owned properties, plus borrowings of approximately $25m to be paid back with interest over 15 years. The borrowing obligations will be met by way of identified savings of $2.4m in operation of the ABC in Melbourne and of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra, as well as from rental income of approximately $1m a year. Budget funding is not envisaged.

This proposal is for the construction of approximately 16,800 square metres of accommodation over six levels plus a basement. It will comprise offices, studios, production suites and recording studios plus public and support facilities. The feature of the building will be the incorporation of studio-capable zones on two levels to accommodate current studios and provide for future needs. On-air studios will have views over the city and Southbank cultural areas. The building will include all normal engineering services. It will also incorporate features to ensure an appropriate acoustic environment in all studio production recording and rehearsal areas and to maintain essential power supplies in the event of mains failure. Because of the importance of radio services in times of emergency, special attention will be given to building security without compromising public access. ABC radio and the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra will occupy three and one half levels initially, with the remaining levels generating rental income and providing for future growth. The forecast annual revenue of $1m is based on current rentals being achieved in the area. Design is being undertaken by consultants and further design documentation and construction will be undertaken on a project management basis with construction packages to be tendered publicly.

It is planned that demolition and site works will take place over May-June this year. The building construction is scheduled to be completed by December 1990. The estimated capital cost of this project is $39.418m at November 1988 prices. This is a significant public work and one which will materially improve the economies of operation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra. I believe it is expedient that this major work be carried out. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words on behalf of the Opposition on the proposal for the construction of a radio and orchestra project at Southbank in Melbourne. On the face of it, this project sounds very impressive: 16,800 square metres; lovely views over the city of Melbourne and the river; and some internal financing, including some borrowings which do not require any additional budgetary outlays. Prima facie, this sounds like a very sensible project as well as being very extensive and attractive. However, when one looks more deeply into the project, as I have done today, one realises that it turns out to be extraordinarily controversial. I will take a little time this afternoon to draw the attention of the House to some of the controversy and some of the problems associated with this project. First of all, it is worth remembering that between three and four years ago, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) planned to move altogether to East Burwood, which was the reason land was originally obtained by the ABC at Burwood: land which is now being sold in order to help pay for the Southbank project. The Burwood site was, by all accounts, a very good site: a site well-served by public transport so that employees of the ABC could easily get there. It was a site which could house all of the three ABC mediums; that is, television, radio and, if necessary, the orchestra and it was a site where a greater degree of rationalisation would have been possible than will be possible with this particular Southbank operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) in his statement argues that there is a degree of rationalisation because all of the radio facilities would be put together-radio studios and so on with the orchestra-and would be operating out of the one site. But the question is: Is this degree of rationalisation anything like as cost-efficient as the original proposal to move to Burwood? The answer is that it is definitely not.

Let me use one little example. The ABC in Melbourne has a helicopter in order that it can compete with the commercial television stations in the filming of television news from all over the city. The trouble is that the ABC helicopter is based at Port Melbourne from where it takes off and lands. It takes the ABC staff about three-quarters of an hour to get from the current television studios at Ripponlea to the helicopter. That presents substantial problems. If the Government had ensured the ABC move to the Burwood site, then there would not have been a problem with the helicopter, because the helicopter simply could have been based at Burwood, along with the rest of the ABC facilities, including television. But the fact is that apparently the ABC has decided to forgo that particular advantage and abandon the Burwood site altogether.

It is also worth remembering that many employees of the ABC anticipated that they would be moving to the Burwood site and consequently bought or rented residences down in that area. Now they find a sudden bolt fast by the ABC, supported by the Government, to move part of project to Southbank. Therefore, those employees working particularly in radio, or who are associated with the orchestra, will have to commute to Southbank or sell their houses and move somewhere else. This decision to abandon the Burwood site and to go ahead with the Southbank project is really a very curious one. One of the concerns that we have is that no-one knows why the original decision to go to Burwood was reversed-it remains a mystery-although there are some who argue that this volte-face was prompted by middle and upper management who took the view that they would rather continue living in the area surrounding a central business district of Melbourne rather than moving themselves to Burwood or commute to Burwood on a daily basis. We do not know what that explanation is; nor does the Public Works Committee.

I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are a member of the Public Works Committee. I also know that-and I do not infer any criticism in saying this-you were not able to visit the site at Southbank. There were only two members of the Public Works Committee who were able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct.

—If that is not correct, I certainly know that two honourable members did visit the site, they being the redoubtable honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson). The interesting point is that they come from both sides of this House and they both oppose the Southbank project and the abandonment of the Burwood site. I agree with many of the concerns that they have expressed to me during the course of this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, it is also worth reflecting on one point that we often make on this side of the House: with public projects, including statutory authority projects, of this kind, organisations such as the ABC should not target central business district sites because of the much greater expense involved. The Opposition expresses great concern about the way this project has evolved; about the additional costs which will ultimately be involved with this project than would have resulted from the concentration of ABC resources at Burwood; and about the fact that no explanation has ever been given to the satisfaction of most honourable member on this side of the House for the abandonment of the Burwood site and the partial relocation at Southbank in Melbourne.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (ARRANGEMENTS WITH THE STATES) REPEAL BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Repeal Bill 1989 will give effect to my announcement of 12 March this year that the Government would repeal the Income Tax (Arrangements with the States) Act 1978. It will also make a number of consequential amendments to the income tax law to dismantle the mechanisms that authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to administer State income tax laws.

The legislation we are acting to repeal today constitutes the last relic of the Fraser Government's ill-fated `New Federalism'. This legislation enabled each State, if it so chose, to legislate to increase personal income taxes or to give-at a cost to that State-a rebate on personal income tax to its own residents. No one would be surprised to learn that no State has taken up the option of imposing its own separate income tax. The reality has been that none has been prepared to risk the political odium of doing so. To all intents and purposes `New Federalism' was dead long ago. However, recently the Federal Opposition took steps to revive it. Two months ago, the then shadow Finance minister, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)-in remarks consistent with the policy outlined in the Opposition's Future Directions manifesto-foreshadowed his intention of encouraging the States to impose their own income taxes. In the event, he was overruled by the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). However, given recent changes in the Opposition's leadership, the Government's determination to repeal this law has re-doubled. Already the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has appointed the former finance spokesman as acting shadow Treasurer. From such a position it is reasonable to conclude he will return to his agenda of double income taxes.

Our concern has also been heightened by the Opposition Leader's unambiguous endorsement of the Future Directions document at his Tuesday press conference following his election. That endorsement leaves up in the air the former Opposition Leader's repudiation of the double taxing proposal incorporated in that document.

This Government is determined to remove this legislation from the statute books to ensure that no backdoor method be left which would enable a future administration to impose a second layer of personal income tax upon the people of Australia. If any future Government wishes to pursue this course it will now have to do it out in the open-not by reactivating a relic of the Fraser years. We are strongly of the view that, far from being a step toward more responsible Government, States' income tax powers would instead threaten the entire thrust of macroeconomic reform in recent years.

This Government has already made enormous progress in cutting back government spending and reducing the size of the public sector. Commonwealth outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product have been reduced from more than 30 per cent of GDP in 1984-85 to about 25 per cent this financial year. Further reductions in the outlays ratio are already cemented into place for future years. The forward estimates show that by 1991-92 Commonwealth outlays will have fallen to 23 1/2 per cent of GDP-or in terms comparable with the period before the basic health cover was switched from the private to the public sectors; a ratio of 22 1/2 per cent. This represents a significant turnaround from the trend of the 1970s and early 1980s when the government sector claimed an ever-increasing share of national income. What is more, this declining share of Government outlays has paved the way for the real tax cuts.

Honourable members will be aware that this is the first Australian Government ever to have paid tax cuts from a Budget surplus. All our predecessors have paid tax cuts by borrowing more money. We have paid for them by cutting outlays in real terms. Compare that to the coalition Government which in 1982 ran up a $9.6 billion Budget deficit after paying irresponsible, unfunded tax cuts in that year. In contrast, this Government in 1989 has found room for responsible tax cuts of $4.9 billion while retaining a Budget surplus of at least $5.5 billion. We have paid for tax cuts by cutting and better targeting Government spending and delivering the proceeds back to the community.

In the years ahead-as the ratio of Commonwealth spending to the size of the economy continues to fall-likewise the amount of revenue needed to finance that spending will also fall. In other words, as economic conditions allow, there will be continued scope for further affordable personal income tax cuts. It is a simple equation, never understood by the Liberals. Lower government spending equals lower government taxes.

Far from being a step towards smaller government, the Opposition's proposal to give the States greater taxing powers would put all that achievement at risk. Handing the States taxing powers would merely provide them with the wherewithal to fund increased expenditures, claiming back to the public sector the area vacated by the Commonwealth. Australia just cannot risk leaving this act on the books.

The double taxing legislation we are repealing was in fact the second part of the Fraser Government's `new federalism' policy. The first part was equally misconceived. Introduced in 1976, it provided for the States to receive as general revenue assistance a designated proportion of Commonwealth tax revenue, initially a certain share of income tax revenue, initially a certain share of income tax revenue, but from 1982-83 to 1984-85, a smaller share of total Commonwealth tax revenue. In fact, these tax sharing arrangements were topped up by various funding `guarantees', such that in every year but 1982-83 the States received more than their fixed share of taxation revenues.

From an economic policy-making perspective, the main fault in these arrangements was that, as grants were linked to revenue collections in the previous year, no account was taken of the emerging budget and economic position in the current year. In other words, flexibility to adjust fiscal policy settings in the national interest was severely constrained. For a relatively small country such as Australia-heavily dependent on often rapidly changing international circumstances for our economic well being-this was a risky situation in which to place ourselves.

The Commonwealth must be in a position to act decisively and with substantial influence if it is to fulfil its macro-economic responsibilities. The so-called new federalism denied the Commonwealth that ability. The Hawke Government acted to remove the shackles of new federalism by replacing the tax sharing grants with financial assistance grants in 1985-86. Our aim has been to bring the growth in assistance to the States back under control and to help reduce the growth in public spending. The States, of course, have resisted the large and sustained reductions in general purpose payments that the Commonwealth has imposed. Similarly, I expect they will complain when, as I foreshadowed in the April statement, we maintain that restraint at the 1989 Premiers Conference next week. But the ritual complaints of State Premiers have worn thin. They too must play their part in economic adjustment.

There is no debate about the crucial need for continued public sector spending restraint. Reduced public sector spending makes an important contribution to providing scope for the increased private sector investment in new export and import replacing industries that is now taking place. Of course, the need for all levels of Government in Australia to play their role in this has been made all the more urgent by the recent deterioration in Australia's external accounts. It needs to be clearly understood by everyone in our community that each month's balance of payments figure is not a statistic in isolation. To the contrary, each month's figure amounts to a further loss on our external accounts which must be covered by borrowing. In other words, each month's figures adds more to our external debt and to our national interest bill.

Frankly, Australia just cannot afford to go on accumulating debt at the rate it is at present. We simply cannot afford the luxury of different levels of Government squabbling about how to divide up a pool of revenue when the overwhelming economic requirement is that all governments recognise the need to keep their financial demands in check. Australia's future economic security demands that we have the full support of the States in this endeavour. This year, more than in any other recent period, strong economic growth has ensured that the States have the financial capacity to do this.

The States have had a revenue bonanza in recent years because very strong growth in stamp duty revenue generated by the share market and property market booms has added enormously to their revenues. State stamp duty revenue alone last year rose by over 50 per cent. In recent years State finances have also benefited considerably from the Commonwealth's accord with the trade union movement. Since wage costs represent a major proportion of the States' costs in providing services such as education, health and police, wage restraint flowing from the accord has helped increase the effective level of resources at the disposal of the States. In view of these trends in the States' finances, it has been essential for the Commonwealth to significantly cut payments to the States to encourage them to restrain their spending.

In the past, the States have simply spent all the revenue that has come their way. Not to have cut back on Commonwealth payments to the States in current circumstances would have been economically irresponsible. The alternative would have been to allow the States to increase their own outlays, offsetting the work the Commonwealth has undertaken in reducing Commonwealth spending.

Some States seek to confuse this issue by producing a plethora of statistics comparing growth rates in outlays and revenue. Their favourite is to complain that the cuts in Commonwealth payments have exceeded the cuts in the Commonwealth's own outlays and that they are therefore bearing an unfair share of the burden of fiscal restraint. Such comparisons are simply irrelevant. The fact is that if the Commonwealth had not cut grants by the degree it has it is likely the States would have shown no spending restraint at all. The most appropriate measure of the relative fiscal restraint of the Commonwealth and the States is growth in each sector's own purpose outlays-in other words, comparing apples with apples.

On this basis, since 1986-87 the Commonwealth's own general purpose government outlays-that is, excluding public trading enterprises such as Telecom Australia and Qantas Airways Ltd-have fallen by 5 per cent in real terms. On the other hand, and despite the cuts in Commonwealth payments to the States, comparable State outlays have increased by around 2 per cent in real terms. This growth reflects, in part, the continued strong growth in the States' current expenditures on goods and services. These grew by nearly 4 1/2 per cent in real terms in 1987-88, and looks set to grow at about the same rate this year.

None of this is to suggest that the Commonwealth is seeking to impose draconian spending cuts on the States. We fully recognise that public services must be adequately funded. But by the same token, by cutting out waste and inefficiency and better targeting assistance, there is further scope for the States to curtail spending. They must continue to make a contribution to national economic adjustment in proportion to their importance in the economy.

I turn now from expenditure and taxation to policies towards Government borrowing, where it has also been necessary for the Government to diverge sharply from the policies of the previous Government so as to restore order in national public finances. When the Fraser Government came to office, borrowings by State authorities were effectively controlled by the Loan Council, under what was known as the gentlemen's agreement dating from 1936. These arrangements were allowed to fall into severe disrepair by the Fraser Government. Indeed, at times State authorities were encouraged to increase their borrowings, including from overseas. These increased borrowings were purportedly to be used to fund infrastructure for the much touted resources boom of the early 1980s. However, they also enabled some States to squirrel away substantial cash balances which they could later spend, thwarting national fiscal policy objectives.

Proper oversight of public sector borrowing under the Liberals was weakened in three ways: Loan Council failed to extend its oversight under the gentlemen's agreement to new non-conventional forms of borrowing such as financial leases and deferred payment schemes; from 1977-78, Loan Council agreed to a wave of special additions to State authority borrowing programs for major infrastructure projects; and from 1982-83, all domestic borrowings by State electricity authorities were excluded from control altogether. By 1983-84, when this Government came to office, over 75 per cent of State authority borrowings were outside Loan Council control, and the net public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) had grown from 1.7 per cent of GDP at the end of the 1970s, to 2.9 per cent of GDP in 1982-83, the highest level since the 1950s.

While there was much worthwhile public sector capital investment in the early 1980s, there was a significant component that could not be properly justified on any reasonable basis. Further, the concentration of infrastructure spending in that period added enormously to our foreign debt burden and contributed to the wages blow-out and high inflation that marked the period. The present Government, when it came to office, was faced with the task of re-establishing national control over the net PSBR through Loan Council. Accordingly, Loan Council's acceptance from 1984-85 of the global approach to authority borrowings was secured. This approach reasserted Loan Council's responsibility for control over all forms of financing by Governments at all levels.

In the early period the global limits did not bite as much as they should have because of the cushion left from the Fraser mismanagement of borrowings. Increasingly, however, the global limits have become a useful tool of fiscal responsibility. Even so, the States' net borrowing requirement has declined from only 2.3 per cent of GDP in 1983-84, to an estimated 1.2 per cent in 1988-89. In the same period, by contrast, the Commonwealth Government's net borrowing requirement has been cut from a 4.5 per cent deficit to a surplus of 0.9 per cent.

The stabilisation policy issues I have raised serve to highlight the role the States have to play in improving Australia's economic performance. But just as the States can impact-for better or worse-on broader fiscal policy settings, so they can have an important part in either promoting or frustrating necessary structural reforms. Regrettably, the States are frequently to be found dragging their feet when it comes to structural reform. Each State's financial position is affected by the expenditure consequences of its infrastructure and industry policies. It is of no use the States crying poor while, at the same time, their profligacy is revealed in continuing explicit or implicit industry subsidies and by subeconomic pricing of key resources, such as for outmoded rail services.

For its part the Commonwealth has matched its success in fiscal management with a broad ranging program of micro-economic reform. We demonstrated our determination to progress in this area by overriding restrictive State provisions in order to accelerate the essential deregulation of wheat transport and marketing. Earlier this week, further reforms in the area of science and technology were announced, while later this month a major statement will be made on coastal shipping and the waterfront. But we have to recognise that many of the structural rigidities and impediments to growth are rooted in State practices-particularly in the important area of transport. It is crucial to the objective of improving waterfront efficiency that State port authorities reduce their costs, charge economically sensible prices for their services and become more active in encouraging competition within ports. Where States have taken steps towards reform they need to be rigorously followed through. Most States have not even begun the reform process-they need to lift their game. The State railways are another area crying out for reform. They largely account for State enterprise subsidies of some $2.3 billion per annum.

In the skies Commonwealth deregulation of domestic trunk passenger aviation will begin in 1990, and the hard but correct decision was taken on the third runway at Sydney Airport. But most States seem reluctant to give up their detailed regulation of intrastate air services, even though this will frustrate the full benefits for customers of the Commonwealth's initiative.

It is also important that progress made by the Commonwealth towards a stronger industry structure is not dissipated by inappropriate state policies. There is a complex web of State incentives, taxes or charges and unnecessary and inconsistent regulation within and between States. Regrettably, one area where our Federal system has been all too productive is in the generation of unnecessary regulations; packaging and labelling regulations, occupational licensing, and the disparate regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries are cases in point.

We look to the States to play their part in helping to remove such impediments and structural rigidities. It is for all these reasons that we repeal the last relic of the Liberal Party's new federalism. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill amends a number of Acts administered within the Attorney-General's portfolio. Some parts of the Bill contain minor amendments designed to correct or update existing legislation. Other parts of the Bill contain more significant amendments designed to implement new policy and ensure that existing legislation is able to deal effectively with sophisticated crime. A detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I propose to address only the more significant aspects of the Bill.
Crimes Act 1914

The Bill contains a number of amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. There are significant amendments dealing with computer crime and fines under the Act are to be substantially increased. The Bill also inserts a new part into the Crimes Act that will provide for a scheme that will permit old convictions for minor offences to be spent.
Computer Crime

The provisions in the Bill relating to computer offences follow, substantially, the recommendations of the committee reviewing Commonwealth criminal law, chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs. The Committee was asked to report specifically on the need for new legislation in this area, and its report was presented and released last November and tabled in Parliament on 12 April 1989. The need for new legislation arises out of three main considerations.

The first is the possible vulnerability of information in computer systems, by comparison with paper records. Unauthorised access to paper files can be prevented by relatively simple security measures, and when such measures fail it is usually because an offence or at least a breach of duty has been committed by a person with authorised access. Not so with computer records, where access to restricted information by unauthorised persons can in many cases be obtained simply by ingenuity in overcoming technical barriers. Such access might be obtained from inside an organisation by persons prepared to exceed a limited access authority, or through the telephone communication system by external `hackers'. Vulnerability does not relate only to access. Computer information can be exposed to risk of damage, destruction or alteration from a large number of sources within or outside the computer-using organisation. Such conduct could have a variety of motives. It might be for gain, as in the case of traditional embezzlement; it might be a malicious desire to cause damage or create confusion or disruption in an organisation; or it might be simple unauthorised experimentation. All such conduct is socially undesirable and its consequences can be disastrous, as reports of damage from so-called computer viruses have shown.

The second consideration is the widespread and growing reliance of modern society on computer systems and communications systems that depend on computers. We need to foster confidence in the security and reliability of such systems not only from the point of view of governments and businesses that use them but from the point of view of individuals whose private information might be contained in them.

The third consideration is the need for the law to be relevant to modern technology. Our criminal law relating to forgery, uttering, fraud and false pretences was framed with people, pens and paper in mind. Now we have machines, magnetic memories and electronic impulses. How traditional offences can be applied in the setting of new technology can be very uncertain. We should not leave this situation to be tested in the trial courts and the appeal process when it is possible to create new offences directed at unauthorised and deliberate acts of misconduct done with, or aimed at, computers.

The Bill creates a series of offences involving either deliberate unauthorised access to data, or more serious offences where such access is gained and the offender either, gained that access with intent to defraud or, knew or ought reasonably to have known that the data was of a specified type which is considered particularly sensitive. It is not intended that the question whether the person ought reasonably to have known involve an objective test but rather that the court be able to have regard to all the circumstances surrounding the offence including the characteristics, knowledge, skills and attributes of the particular offender when determining this question. The amendments do not seek to cover computer crime generally. There is no need for such an approach as many situations can be more appropriately dealt with by State laws and law enforcement authorities. Instead, the provisions in this Bill are directed at two classes of situation where Commonwealth provisions are either necessary or useful.

The first relates to the protection of Commonwealth computers and data in them. This is clearly a proper function of Commonwealth criminal law. The second kind of situation is where the misconduct-that is, the unauthorised access, interference or damage-takes place by means of a Commonwealth facility, whether or not the victimised computer system is a Commonwealth one. We have here in mind particularly the Telecom Australia communication system through which all major computer networks, and many smaller systems, will be linked. One of the advantages of covering such situations by Commonwealth legislation is that a common offence will apply across all Australian jurisdictions-thus enabling a prosecution to be brought in the most convenient venue when the elements occur in two or more States or Territories. It is not intended that this offence of computer misconduct through use of Telecom and such facilities will displace any State or Territory offences that may also have been committed. One or other offence or both could be charged, subject to the usual rules against double jeopardy. It will, of course, be a matter for each jurisdiction to decide whether to enact specific computer legislation, and two have already done so.

In accepting the Gibbs Committee's recommendation for new offences involving use of Commonwealth communications facilities the Government is taking account of not only possible frauds and other offences that might be committed across boundaries but also the potential use of such facilities for hacking and for the deliberate causing of computer malfunctions through viruses or other means. I wish to make it clear that these new offence provisions are intended to protect information while it is in a computer system. They are not intended to give that information a special character so that after it has been obtained from a computer special penalties attach to its unauthorised use. Thus the ordinary law about unauthorised disclosure would apply in relation to a third party receiving the information. No new offence is brought into existence in relation to a third party except where that party is an accessory to the computer-related misconduct.
Penalty Provisions

The Bill makes two general changes to the penalty provisions of the Crimes Act. First, it will increase the maximum fine that may be imposed for certain Commonwealth offences-that is, for most offences in the Crimes Act and those other offences for which no fine is expressly specified. The relativities between imprisonment and maximum fines were last adjusted in 1982. When I speak of relativities, I should stress that specified maximum fines are not to be regarded in any sense as substituteable for, or to be served instead of, the corresponding period of imprisonment. As the review committee points out, maximum fines should have regard to the worst kind of breach that is appropriate for a fine rather than imprisonment. Therefore it is not possible to equate a fine with a particular period of imprisonment, for example by having regard to weekly earnings. Also, periods of imprisonment in default of payment of a fine are a quite separate matter. The new scale will be given effect by a simplified formula in place of a table. Some examples of the effect of the increased maximum penalties are:
6 months
imprisonment
$3,000 fine instead of $1,000
3 years
imprisonment
$18,000 fine instead of $10,000
20 years
imprisonment
$120,000 fine instead of $20,000
An offence punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment would become punishable by a fine of up to $200,000.

While the new relativities now provided for will be made generally applicable, through this Bill and future legislation directed to other offence provisions, the relativities will not be followed universally. Where a different relativity is justified as a matter of policy, special provision will be made for this. In cases where a fine would be imposed on a corporation a multiplier of five will continue to be used.

Secondly, it is intended to follow the practice for new offences in recent years by providing in relation to the Crimes Act, and elsewhere where not otherwise specified, that a fine may be imposed additionally as well as alternatively to imprisonment. The aim of this approach is to make available to the court the greatest possible range of sentencing within the limits of the maximum prison term and the maximum fine. For example, it would be possible to impose a short or suspended prison term together with a fine.

Both the changes I have described are intended to be steps towards adoption of a more uniform and rational scheme of penalties for all Commonwealth offences. Further steps in that process will be taken in the light of recommendations to be made by the committee reviewing Commonwealth criminal law.
Spent Convictions

The question of spent convictions has been the subject of a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) and extensive discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG). Queensland has had legislation dealing with the rehabilitation of offenders since 1986 which is more limited in scope than the ALRC proposals. As an exercise in uniformity agreement was reached in SCAG that all jurisdictions would enact legislation dealing with spent convictions broadly along the lines of the Queensland model. The spent convictions scheme is designed to give people a chance to live down a minor criminal conviction. Clearly it is in the best interests of society, and the person involved, that where the person has been convicted of a minor offence, has paid the penalty and subsequently been of good behaviour for an extended period then he should be protected from those who might discriminate against him. The scheme is rehabilitative and will contribute to the Government's efforts to reduce crime. The Government's perspective of the benefits of the scheme is supported by experience with similar schemes in operation in the United States, most European countries and Japan.

I will now briefly outline the details of the scheme. The legislation will prohibit disclosure of, or discrimination against a person on the basis of, a conviction for a minor offence where the person has been of good behaviour for 10 years after conviction. A minor offence is one where an actual sentence of 30 months' imprisonment or less was imposed. The prohibitions on disclosure and discrimination will apply generally to Commonwealth employment and in the non-self governing territories in respect of all convictions, Commonwealth, State and foreign. The prohibitions are a consequence of conviction of a Commonwealth offence and therefore will apply throughout Australia in respect of convictions for Commonwealth offences.

Having established a general rule, there will inevitably be circumstances to which that general rule should not apply. To this end the legislation provides a scheme of exemptions. Some of these are spelt out specifically in the legislation. Clearly a court or a prosecuting body should be able to take spent convictions into account when sentencing or deciding whether to prosecute. Certain types of employment require, for public policy reasons, full disclosure of any convictions. Persons employed in law enforcement and national security will therefore be exempt from the scheme and have to disclose spent convictions. In other types of employment certain convictions will always be relevant. An example of this is where a person has been convicted of a sexual offence involving children and seeks employment caring for children or as a teacher. In addition to these statutory exemptions it will be open to government to make regulations exempting persons, or classes of persons, from the scheme.

The mechanism contained in the legislation is that an application may be made to the Privacy Commissioner for exemption. The Privacy Commissioner will then make a recommendation to government on whether regulations should be made to exempt the applicant, or the class of which the applicant is a member. Rather than create a range of offences to enforce the scheme the Privacy Commissioner will be given conciliation and civil remedies powers, similar to those conferred by the Privacy Act, to resolve breaches of the legislation. The amendments will change the common law which provides that a pardon only relieves a person from the consequences of a conviction. If it is subsequently found that a person was wrongly convicted and a pardon is granted on that basis, justice requires that the person should be put in the same position as if he or she had never been convicted at all.
Customs Act 1901

In 1987 the Parliament passed legislation designed to strike at the heart of major organised crime by depriving persons involved of the proceeds of their criminal endeavours. That legislation, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, was a major advance on existing legislation which dealt with the forfeiture of property and the imposition and recovery of pecuniary penalties such as Part XIII, Division 3, of the Customs Act 1901. Part XIII, Division 3, of the Customs Act was inserted in 1979. It was stated during the second reading debate at the time that the objective of the legislation was to facilitate the imposition of `a pecuniary penalty equivalent to the benefit derived from dealing in illicit drugs'. Section 243b therefore provided for the imposition of a pecuniary penalty, to be assessed in accordance with section 243c. Quite properly, section 243c provided that the court, when assessing the value of the benefit derived by a person from dealing with illicit drugs, could have regard to property acquired by reason of dealing in narcotics, that had been diverted by the dealer into the possession of a person other than the drug dealer. Most commonly, this might be property which is disguised as the property of a company controlled by the drug dealer.

However it is a striking flaw in the legislative scheme of Part XIII, Division 3, that, when it comes to satisfying the pecuniary penalty, no provision was made for applying that other property in satisfaction of the penalty. That defect was cured in the Proceeds of Crime Act by the `effective control' provision-section 9-and the power to lift the corporate veil, section 28. Part 5 of the Bill now before the House will remove this defect from the Customs Act by inserting new provisions modelled upon the provisions of the Proceeds Act. Part 5 of the Bill makes a number of other amendments to Part XIII, Division 3, of the Customs Act with a view to harmonising its provisions with those of the Proceeds Act.
Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983

Part 6 of the Bill proposes two amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) Act. The first, confers a general power on the Director to file an ex officio indictment. This general power will not be delegable and a related amendment ensures that the general ex officio power must be exercised personally by the Director. This will put the Commonwealth DPP in the same position as his counterparts in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria.

The second enlarges the power of the Director to give an indemnity. At present the Director may give a use indemnity which is an undertaking that evidence given by a person in specified Commonwealth proceedings will not be used in evidence against the person in any civil or criminal proceedings, other than proceedings for perjury. The Act is to be amended to provide for full use derivative use indemnity. That is, the undertaking will extend to the use of evidence which is obtained as a direct or indirect result of the primary evidence given by the witness. This adopts a recommendation made by the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report on the National Crime Authority Bill.

A new power to give an indemnity against prosecution, to be known as a transactional indemnity, is also to be conferred upon the Director. Again, it is proposed that this power be exercised personally by the Director.
National Crime Authority Act

The Bill also provides for some fine tuning of the National Crime Authority (NCA) Act. The inter-governmental committee on the National Crime Authority has recently concluded that there is a need to clearly establish the management responsibility of the Chairman, while preserving the inquiry powers of other members. The Act is to be amended to make the Chairman responsible for the day-to-day management of the Authority with the power to make or delegate decisions in appropriate circumstances, give directions and undertake activities that are required to perform the functions of the Authority.

Certain Commonwealth agencies which are currently subject to section 19a of the National Crime Authority Act, which provides certain bodies with a discretion to provide information to the Authority upon request, will be made subject to sections 28 and 29 which enable the Authority to require the furnishing of information or production of documents at hearings. These agencies are operating as financial or quasi-commercial enterprises in the private sector and will be accorded similar status under the Act to private organisations in those fields. This is consistent with the Government's policy with regard to Government business enterprises. It is also proposed to amend section 19a to ensure that it provides sufficient protection for the requested agency from liability for breach of confidentiality. It is intended to insert a clause providing the requested agency with the appropriate protection.
The Bill also provides for a number of minor changes to the Act to streamline the Authority's day to day operations by reducing the need for meetings of the Authority wherever possible.
Financial Impact Statement

The measures outlined above have minimal financial impact. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission will require one extra person to handle workload generated for the Privacy Commissioner under the spent convictions scheme. While the amendments to the Customs Act will not require additional resources, there is an expectation that the revision of part XIII division 3 will result in extra revenue to the Commonwealth. The other amendments have no financial impact. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to remove section 41 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, which exempts from the operation of the Act discrimination in superannuation on the ground of sex or marital status and to insert a number of more limited exemptions dealing with superannuation practices. As section 41 also provides an exemption in regard to the terms on which insurance may be offered, the amendments have necessitated that the insurance exemption be rewritten and reinserted.

The process which has led to the Bill dates back to the preparation of a report by the Human Rights Commission titled Superannuation and Insurance and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 Part 1-Superannuation. That report was prepared in response to a request by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and was tabled in Parliament on 25 November 1986. The report was considered by the Government and the Government decided to remove the exemption and to insert into the Act certain more limited exemptions for particular practices in superannuation. Following the Government's decision, consultations on the proposed exemptions were held with the superannuation industry, employer groups, State and Territory governments and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

The Government, as indicated in its National Agenda for Women, is committed to the objective of removing discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy. The major effect of the Bill is to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in superannuation practices for new schemes. Where funds are unable to comply with the new obligations under the legislation, the reasonable expectations of the members will be maintained and the discriminatory fund will be allowed to continue. However, such funds will not be entitled to admit new members. Further, members of such discriminatory schemes will generally have to be given an option to obtain `non-discriminatory superannuation benefits'. The proposed continuing exemptions, shortly stated, deal with the following areas:
the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision which is based upon reasonable actuarial data upon which it is reasonable to reply;

the current practices whereby lesser death and disability benefits are provided to members who are single, that is members who do not have a spouse or a de facto spouse or to members who do not have a child; and
the possibly discriminatory effect of current vesting, preservation and portability arrangements in funds' conditions.

The introduction of the Bill has been delayed to date pending the reappraisal by the Government of a proposed exemption which would have allowed funds to confine the provision of superannuation benefits to permanent and full time employees. In January 1989 the Government decided not to proceed with this exemption. Following that decision a further round of consultations on the issue was held with the superannuation industry, peak employer bodies, State Governments and the National Women's Consultative Council. Those consultations have only recently been completed.

I turn now to a brief description of the proposed limited exemptions to be inserted in the Act. Because, statistically, women live longer than men, the actuarial exemption covers the resulting difference in costs of providing a pension for women. Schemes will be able to continue to offer optional conversions between lump sums and pensions which differ by sex, so long as the difference is based on reliable actuarial data. As many superannuation benefits are provided via insurance this exemption is interlinked with the insurance exemption.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is currently preparing a report on the exemption of insurance from the Sex Discrimination Act. The need for the actuarial exemption for superannuation will be reviewed in light of the Commission's recommendations concerning the insurance exemption.

The exemption for dependant superannuation benefits is designed to allow schemes to continue current practices, whereby upon a member's death or disability no benefits are payable to a member who does not have a spouse or children. In the absence of this kind of exemption it may have been possible for a member who was single to succeed in a complaint of marital status discrimination. There are a number of reasons for maintaining this exemption. As the former Human Rights Commission noted in its report, the exemption reflects the community's attitude that it is appropriate to make special provision for persons who have a spouse or who have children in the event of the death, or physical or mental incapacity, of members of superannuation funds. As was noted by the Commission, to provide benefits to all dependants of members on proof of financial dependency, would create difficulties both in administration and in finding a suitable objective test of dependency.

In regard to the exemptions dealing with vesting, preservation and portability, the issue of discrimination arises because there is evidence that women statistically do not remain in continuous employment for the same length of time as men. Matters such as vesting, preservation and portability fall within the area of the operating standards for superannuation funds administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Regulations made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 impose a number of operating standards with which superannuation funds must comply in order to be eligible for taxation concessions. I am advised that current vesting standards require a superannuation fund to vest in full in a member all benefits arising from contributions made by the member and earnings thereon. The effect of this is that all member-financed benefits are fully vested.
The preservation standards which require benefits to be preserved generally until retirement at or after the age of 55 apply to the following benefits, except for amounts less than $500:

any vested employer-financed benefits arising from employer contributions made in accordance with an agreement or award certified or made by an industrial authority-that is, the 3 per cent award based superannuation; and
any new or improved vested employer-financed benefits arising from any arrangements entered into after 21 December 1986.

The preservation standards do not extend to vested employer-financed benefits flowing from ongoing superannuation arrangements which were in place prior to 22 December 1986. They also do not extend to member-financed benefits arising from member contributions which are non-tax deductable made to employer sponsored funds.

As part of its review of retirement income policy, the Government is looking at the question of whether improved vesting and preservation standards should be developed in respect of superannuation funds. The issues are discussed in Social Security Review Issues Paper No. 6, Towards a National Retirement Income Policy, which was released for public comment last year. Submissions and comments on the paper are currently in the process of being assessed by the Government. It is to be noted that any improvements that are introduced would have the effect of reducing any indirect discrimination in vesting and preservation arrangements.

In order for funds to obtain the benefits of the proposed exemptions under section 41a, it will be necessary for the funds to amend their rules to ensure that the trustees do not exercise their discretions in a discriminatory way. Clearly, trustees are entitled to exercise their discretions as they believe appropriate. The proposed requirement in section 41a (3) only requires that a trustee, in exercising his or her discretion, not exercise it in a discriminatory manner by reason only of a person's sex or marital status.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill which are designed to protect the existing expectations of members in superannuation schemes. Proposed section 41b will enable schemes which cannot or do not wish to comply with the new requirements of section 41a to continue to provide benefits for existing members, providing that members of these funds have the option to obtain non-discriminatory superannuation benefits. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may, however, grant an exemption from this requirement pursuant to section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. This will enable trustees or employers to apply for an exemption where it is clear that it would not be beneficial for members to join a new scheme or obtain non-discriminatory benefits. It will not be necessary that members actually be offered the opportunity to join a new scheme, as it will be sufficient for the purposes of the option, that existing members be offered the option to obtain benefits which would comply with proposed section 41a.

Proposed section 41c will enable regulations to be made to repeal section 41a or 41b. This provision reflects the Government's commitment to progressively moving to a truly non-discriminatory superannuation industry. This provision continues the status of existing subsection (1) of section 41 of the Act which could be repealed by regulation. The Government believes that this provision will encourage the superannuation industry to progressively remove discrimination in the terms upon which superannuation is offered. Regulations under section 41c will only be able to be made after consultation with industry and will not come into operation until one year after their making.

The proposals put forward in this Bill should not impact upon Government expenditure. However, it is anticipated that Commonwealth schemes will be amended in separate legislation to comply with the Act by the time of the commencement of the amending Act. These changes may have some affect on Commonwealth expenditure.

Superannuation is a very technical area of the law and the issues of discrimination which may arise may vary from case to case and industry to industry. I have therefore written to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner requesting that guidelines be published on issues which have not been specifically addressed in these amendments. Where trustees or employers feel that they should be exempted from a particular requirements of the Act that may apply to the Commission for an administrative exemption under section 44 of the Sex Discrimination Act. Decisions by the Commission under section 44 are reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Government believes that the amendments outlined above represent a significant reform. While I am informed that most schemes will be able to comply with the new amendments, with only minor adaptations to their existing conditions, the amendments will require schemes which have not yet improved their benefits to do so over the next two years, or to close off their membership. Further, the amendments are likely to increase the opportunity for part-time employees to gain access to superannuation. This will significantly improve the opportunities for women to build up a worthwhile superannuation entitlement over their working lives. A large majority of part-time employees are women, and it is clear that women tend to return from child rearing to part-time employment. Where part-time employees are performing the same duties as their full-time counterparts and the full-time counterparts receive superannuation, it is likely that a court would find that a failure to provide access to superannuation to such part-time employees unlawfully discriminatory.

These amendments should therefore be viewed in the light of the Government's commitment to increasing superannuation coverage for the Australian work force. Arbitrated superannuation awards are providing increasing superannuation coverage. These amendments will not only encourage this development and help Australia make appropriate provisions for its ageing population, but the benefits which will be offered will be fairer and more equitable, and in line with the Government's commitments under the National Agenda for Women. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, for Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this portfolio Bill is to amend the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) Act 1970. The amendments to the AIDC Act represent another step in the Government's ongoing reform of the AIDC by further freeing the Corporation from the burden of unnecessary bureaucratic procedures while maintaining appropriate strategic controls.

Under this Government the AIDC has already been the subject of a number of reform measures which have allowed the Corporation to expand its role. These reforms have let AIDC provide finance for the restructuring of Australian industry and included relieving the restrictions on the use of its capital and removing Loan Council's controls on its borrowings. The AIDC responded well to these initiatives: the focus of its investment activities altered dramatically and the AIDC has made a significant contribution towards the Government's industry policy objectives.

Since 1983, the AIDC has experienced very strong growth. As at 30 June 1988, AIDC total assets stood at $2,488m compared with $963m at 30 June 1983, an increase of over 250 per cent. However, during 1987 a restricted capital base emerged as a factor that could have jeopardised the AIDC's future contribution to industry development especially in regard to its equity investment program.

Confronted with the capital problem, the Government examined a number of options before deciding to allow the AIDC to raise equity capital from the private sector. The AIDC is now in the process of establishing a listed subsidiary company that will conduct most of the loan and investment business of the AIDC, with up to 30 per cent of the equity being offered to the public. The necessary amendments to the AIDC Act clear the way for the establishment of the listed subsidiary, which measure passed through Parliament in the Budget sittings last year.

As a result of the changes implemented since 1983, the AIDC already conforms to a significant degree with the Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. However, many of the reforms were introduced prior to the issuing of the guidelines. Consequently, some modifications are required and in some cases the guidelines are inappropriate given the AIDC's unique role.

However, the Government has taken the view that AIDC should, to the maximum extent possible, comply with the government business enterprise (GBE) guidelines. To this end a number of reforms, such as the remuneration of the Chief Executive and dividend payments which bring AIDC in line with other GBEs, were contained in the legislation establishing the subsidiary. In regard to the listed subsidiary company, a balance has to be struck between allowing the subsidiary to operate as a commercial entity in the same environment as any other publicly listed company while having sufficient accountability befitting the Government's majority shareholding. The intention of the GBE reforms is to improve the efficiency of GBEs by placing them on, or at least approximating, a commercial footing. The listed subsidiary will be a fully commercial operation directed towards AIDC's statutory charter, especially AIDC's important role in developing a more internationally competitive industry.

It would be totally inappropriate for the Government unilaterally to impose, as part of a reform package, financial or strategic controls on the subsidiary. This would undermine the commercial nature of the company, jeopardise success of the company's public flotation, lower the price of the company's shares and run the real risk of negating the purpose of allowing AIDC to establish a listed subsidiary company. The Government believes the board of the subsidiary is the appropriate body to determine the company's corporate plan, set financial targets and declare any dividends after paying due regard to market conditions and the wishes of shareholders, of which the government is the largest. Part 2 of the Bill therefore concentrates on the reform measures for AIDC itself and not on the soon to be established subsidiary. To remove an unnecessary administrative burden and promote efficiency, board members of AIDC are now to be appointed and subject to dismissal by the portfolio Minister. The grounds for dismissal have been expanded to include ongoing under-performance.

In accordance with the GBE policy guidelines, AIDC must now provide the portfolio Minister with a three-yearly corporate plan commencing on 1 July 1989. Each plan will set out the objectives of the corporation and address the overall strategies and policies that are to be followed in order to achieve the objectives. Each corporate plan is to contain a financial target which will outline overall financial strategies and include a forecast of revenue and expenditure. The target is to be agreed to in advance by the portfolio Minister. The Bill contains the scope for variations to both the overall corporate plan and the financial target should circumstances warrant any changes. The provision of a corporate plan and financial target replaces the annual general policy statement the corporation currently supplies to the portfolio Minister.

In line with the Government's May 1988 economic statement on reform of taxation of GBE's, this Bill removes AIDC's exemption from State and territory stamp duty effective from 1 July 1989. However, this applies only to a transaction entered into, or a document executed, on or after 1 July 1989. An advance made on or after 1 July 1989 under a document executed before that date will continue to be exempt from stamp duty. AIDC operates on commercial principles. To put AIDC on the same footing as its competitors, the Bill will allow the board to recommend to the portfolio Minister an auditor of its own choice. This will have effect from 1 July 1990.

With AIDC having to work to a corporate plan and a financial target, this Bill formalises AIDC's annual reporting requirements, which will now include performance indicators against established targets. The Bill also corrects a definitional problem that occurred in last year's amendments to the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act 1970 which cleared the way for establishment of the subsidiary company. The problem involved defining the value of assets being transferred to the subsidiary for the purpose of calculating any capital gains tax.

Part 3 of this Bill amends the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985. The proposed amendment to increase the number of government members from one to two on the board of the Australian Trade Commission recognises that a single government member cannot adequately represent cross-portfolio interests and concerns impacting on the Commission. In particular, the amendment will provide the opportunity to balance government representation between domestic industry and foreign policy and trade orientations.

Part 4 of the Bill involves a minor amendment to the National Measurement Act 1960 which is being made to include a definition of `measuring instrument'. This is necessary because the uniform trade measurement legislation is to be enacted in the States and Territories and it refers to this definition. The present definition of `instrument' is inadequate. It has been redefined to cover all measuring instruments. Consequent to this, it has been necessary to define the word `component' wider than its natural meaning. So that there is consistency between the National Measurement Act and the uniform trade measurement, the definition of `use for trade' had to be amended in the former. The opportunity has also been taken to insert the definition for a `standard of measurement' which in turn requires the definition of `material measure'. This is needed to remove the possible confusion between written standards and standards of measurement. The penalties imposed under the National Measurement Act are being increased to keep pace with inflation.

The main purpose of the amendments of the patents, trade marks and designs Acts made by Part 5 of the Bill is to enable the Commissioner of Patents and registrars of trade marks and designs to delegate statutory powers and functions to the appropriate levels of responsibility within the patent, trade marks and designs offices. The amendments will also bring the three Acts into conformity in this regard and provide simpler and more flexible administration of various statutory functions of the offices.

Part 6 of the Bill will repeal a number of unproclaimed amendments of the Patents Act which provide for the lodgment and preparation of abstracts of patent specifications. While there is merit in applicants for patents being required to provide abstracts in plain English of their patent specifications, the Government's main priority for use of Patent Office resources has been focused, since 1986, on reducing the Office's backlog of unexamined patent applications. New provisions will be introduced when appropriate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, for Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of the Higher Education Funding Amendments Bill 1989 is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to provide increased funding to higher education institutions over the 1989-91 triennium. The additional funding will total some $24m in 1989. The increased funding is being provided in accordance with well established government procedures for the cost supplementation of higher education grants. Under these arrangements provision is made for the additional costs of increased salaries of higher education staff and for increases in other costs such as equipment and building costs that are incurred up to the start of the program year.

The Bill also provides for a reduction in operating grants for 1990-1991 to take into account the Government's decision to phase out the subsidised overseas student program. The amounts involved are $23m in 1990 and $43m in 1991. These funds will be used instead to finance scholarships to enable overseas students to obtain full fee places in Australian higher education institutions. The new arrangements therefore will not reduce the total level of funding available for institutions.

The Bill also makes provision for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. Under the amended Act the Signadou College of Education will receive its grant payments through the ACT Treasury on the same basis as payments are made to institutions in the States and the Northern Territory. The Australian National University, the Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Canberra Institute of the Arts remain as Commonwealth institutions and accordingly will be funded through appropriations as at present.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Sinclair had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the House declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for-

(1) its prevarication over major national development projects where minority viewpoints have been allowed to prejudice a rational balance between valid environmental concerns and development proposals and delay Government decision;
(2) its failure to recognise land use as properly the responsibility of State and Northern Territory Governments;
(3) not providing an explicit role for the States in the Resource Assessment proposal;
(4) failing to ensure consultation with the States before the appointment of special Commissioners to the Resource Assessment Commission;
(5) using the Resource Assessment Commission concept to atone for public reaction against the Government's last minute intervention on the Wesley Vale Pulp Mill; and

(6) providing yet another layer between development applications and Government approval to the detriment of proposals designed to ameliorate Australia's chronic balance of payments problems through their contribution to Australian export revenue and in offsetting domestic imports'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). In his contribution last evening, the right honourable member pointed out that the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989 seeks to set up a new body which will be called the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC). However, this body would be a totally inappropriate and unnecessary addition to the bureaucracy in Australia. We simply do not need such a body in order to be able to make proper assessments of the way in which Australia's resources should be developed. This legislation is an indication of the fact that this Government is effectively devoid of any new initiatives. It is devoid of ideas as to how Australia's resources should be developed properly. By introducing this Bill the Government is clutching at straws in an attempt to get itself off the political hook because it has run out of ideas. It has been caught effectively with its pants down with new resource developments coming forward such as the Wesley Vale proposal. The Government is caught in a political bind by lobby groups such as the conservation movement.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is being brought forward as a so-called initiative because, in political terms, the Government simply does not know where to move. It is buying time and in the process it is setting up a totally new and unnecessary addition to the bureaucracy that will do no more than retard any new additions to our resource development. I hope that, when the Liberal-National party government comes into office after the next election, this will be one of the first bodies to be abolished.

In reading through the Bill and the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), it is quite clear that this legislation attempts to take over from the State governments significant powers that traditionally have been exercised by the States. Since the inception of Federation, it has always been assumed that issues such as land management will be exercised by the States. But this Bill entrenches in Commonwealth legislation the right of the Commonwealth to be able to usurp those powers from the States.

Any person in this country who believes in the rights of the States and the Federation of Australia could not possibly support this measure because, to a large degree, it makes redundant the powers that have traditionally been exercised by the States. It is clear that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants to establish this new Commission, which he will control, so that he can have a mechanism to control his Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). It is clear that in some of the debates that have ensued in recent times, such as the debates on Wesley Vale and the management of forest areas and other national park areas, it is Senator Richardson who is running the Government, and that the Prime Minister does not have a mechanism to be able to control him. The Prime Minister is seeking to establish this Commission as a means of controlling his environment Minister.

This legislation will be very detrimental to the development of Australia because it seeks to establish another bureaucratic body to which any proposer of a new industry or a new resource development must justify any proposal. Already we have in place the requirement for any proposer to prepare an environmental impact statement which points out the impact on the environment or on the local community. That will still be required. But this proposal means that in addition to all of the other requirements, a proposer must also go through Resource Assessment Commission which is just another bureaucratic body that will be put in the way of proper and sensible resource development in Australia. The sooner this body can be abolished, the better it will be for Australia.

If the Government is genuinely seeking to have a proper assessment made of Australia's resources and how those resources should be managed and developed, it already has at its disposal quite adequate resource facilities. Already we have the Industries Assistance Commission, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. We also have the massive resources of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Those bodies are available to make technical assessments of how our resources should be developed. If that is not adequate for the Government and it needs more research facilities, I remind the House that we have available the very adequate research facilities of universities. There is no need to have a new body called the Resource Assessment Commission. It is not necessary. The establishment of this Commission is a political gimmick which the Government is using because it is in political trouble with the environmental movement and because the Prime Minister is in political trouble as a result of the actions of his Minister for environment. I cannot see any justification for establishing this body. As I said earlier, I hope it will be abolished at a very early stage by an incoming conservative government.

The Minister made the point in his second reading speech that the first matter to be referred to this new Commission would be an extensive inquiry into the forest industries in Australia. I question the legitimacy of putting such a reference to this new Commission because already the Government has made decisions which have a long term impact and involvement with the forest industries in Australia. My colleague from Bass would be well aware that not so long ago the Federal Government established the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests to inquire into the forest industries in Tasmania, which it did. It reported extensively on its views of the forest industries in Tasmania. But, when the Helsham Commission presented its report, the Federal Government would not accept its recommendations. It overrode them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three million dollars.

—Yes, it cost $3m to conduct that inquiry and when the recommendations were presented the Federal Government simply would not accept them and it overruled the Commission. So, if that is the track record of the Federal Government, I question what might happen to the recommendations made by this Resource Assessment Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that, in addition to the Helsham inquiry into the forest industries in Tasmania, over the past 25 years there have been about 15 inquiries into the forest industries in Tasmania. We pointed out at the time the Helsham inquiry was established that it simply was not necessary to have another inquiry because all of the research was done and all of the information was already available for assessment. But the Federal Government did establish that inquiry, and now it is proceeding to establish yet another inquiry into the forest industries. Perhaps it anticipates inquiring into other forest areas of Australia, such as the north Queensland rainforests. But it is quite apparent that this Federal Government has already made up its mind what it will do about them-it has locked them all up in national parks. So, I question why the Federal Government would want to conduct such an inquiry when clearly it has already made its decisions on that issue. It would seem that putting forward such a reference to this Commission to conduct an inquiry into the forest industries is nothing more than a whitewash to cover up decisions and actions that have already been taken by this Federal Government.
