I could talk at some length of my objections to the establishment of this Resource Assessment Commission; but I do not intend to delay the House, because, as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has already pointed out, we have considerable business to be concluded in the House tonight. I simply conclude my remarks by saying that this Commission is unnecessary; this Bill establishes a new bureaucracy; it will delay resource development; it will put another impediment in the way of industry being able to develop Australia's resources and thereby create new economic opportunities; and I hope at the earliest opportunity an incoming conservative Liberal and National Party government will abolish this new Resource Assessment Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Resource Assessment Commission, which will be established as a result of this Resource Assessment Commission Bill, is an important part of a package of measures which will resolve future conservation and development issues. Other aspects of the package announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 18 November last year were: a strengthening of the role and a streamlining of the operation of the Australian Heritage Commission; the negotiation of a forest accord; the development of a national forest inventory; the identification of gaps in existing environmental databases through review; the enhancement of the environmental expertise of the various industry councils; and the creation of greater community awareness of conservation issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's future requires-in fact demands-that this generation of Australians reconcile the requirements of development and of conservation of our environment. The Australian Labor Party is acutely aware of this. The introduction to chapter 9 of the Party platform-the section on the environment-states in part:
Labor believes that-
Environmental objectives will be integrated in a co-operative way into the government's overall economic strategies and industry development policies.
Environment and development must be planned in the light of the other.
There should be sustained, environmentally sound, humane development, planned within the constraints of, and in harmony with, the natural environment.
The restoration of full employment and environmental protection are compatible, rather than conflicting, objectives.

It is in this context that the three policy principles which are to be used to guide Commonwealth Ministers should be seen. These principles, which were yet again outlined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech are:
there should be an integrated approach to conservation and development by taking both conservation and development aspects into account at an early stage;

resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources, having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations and an equitable distribution of the return on resources; and

Commonwealth decisions, policies and management regimes may provide for additional uses that are compatible with the primary purpose values of the area, recognising that in some cases both conservation and development interests can be accommodated concurrently or sequentially, and, in other cases, choices must be made between alternative uses or combinations of uses.

In fact, this process is an attempt to move away from the ad hoc approach to resource development in Australia. It is intended to get in place a system whereby we can weigh up the competing and conflicting conservation and resource development aspects. That is important. If we look at some of the examples raised by honourable members opposite, we can see that in the past what we have had is an approach to resource development based on the bringing forward of single projects. Never before have we sat down and consciously tried to put in place a system whereby we could have an orderly development of resources. I think that is quite important. The Minister, in his second reading speech, indicated that Justice Stewart would be appointed as the first Chairperson of the Commission. No doubt all honourable members who have taken some interest in the way in which Justice Stewart was able to put in place the National Crime Authority as its original Chairman will realise that he has the attributes required to set in place this unique process which will be very important. That is a pleasing aspect of the present situation.

Let us turn to the Opposition's position. As my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) outlined last night, it is a bit hard to follow the Opposition's position on this type of legislation. Whilst we all now realise that it is opposing the legislation and has put forward a second reading amendment, as the honourable member for Dunkley mentioned last night, back in November the then shadow environment spokesman, Senator Puplick-I am not too sure whether he is still the shadow spokesman; everything with the coalition front bench is so fluid this week-welcomed the Government's announcement of the decision to establish the new Resource Assessment Commission. In fact, he claimed that it represented a major triumph for the Federal coalition. In his press release he said:
For months the Opposition has been calling for the development of a process along the lines now foreshadowed by the proposed RAC.

I note that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) is to follow me in this debate. I hope that he will be able to explain to me something which has been a bit of a quandary. When debating a motion about Wesley Vale last week-on 4 May-he said:

Look at what happened in this place yesterday. The Government introduced the Resource Assessment Commission Bill. I cannot pre-empt debate on this matter, but this Commission recognises that there was a failure at Wesley Vale. It recognises that the Federal Government failed to publish guidelines in advance. It recognises that people were going in a hundred different directions. This Bill may be an advance-it recognises a glaring gap in the development of balanced resources in this nation.

He having said that last week, it will be interesting to see what he has to say today. I agree with him that, if we are to have a balanced development of resources, we should have the guidelines. Let us look at what happened in the case of Wesley Vale: at the last moment the Tasmanian Government decided that it would change its environmental guidelines-environmental guidelines that were completely unacceptable to the Commonwealth Government. That was the real reason that that development did not go ahead. Let us not kid ourselves, even if we are in the run-up to a State election in Tasmania. What happened in relation to Wesley Vale, and the fact that the project did not proceed, lies in the hands of the Gray Government in Tasmania. It lies in their hands because they were not willing to sit down and take seriously the environmental consequences of the mill that was proposed. If we have an investigation into the forest industry and the use of forest resources overall, as has been outlined, without having to look at specific projects, it will be for the better because the type of guidelines that are required will come out of such discussions. I refer to the second reading amendment and a number of the matters which were raised. The second part of the amendment proposes that the Government should be condemned for:
Its failure to recognise land use as properly the responsibility of the State and Northern Territory Governments.

We are really talking about resource management. This is not some sort of town planning exercise, a normal run-of-the-mill land use requirement. We are talking about resource development. The Commonwealth Government has a major role to play in resource development-and that is recognised. If we look at past actions of coalition governments we will see that they understood that they had powers in this direction. We only have to look at the appropriate action taken by the Fraser Government in relation to sand mining. Now, we have this suggestion in a second reading amendment that suddenly the Commonwealth Government should walk away from this exercise. I reject completely that notion.

I wish quickly to turn to some earlier criticism by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) which was made soon after the announcement of the Resources Assessment Commission. The foundation contended that what was being put in place was very much a sop for resource developers. It contended that not enough recognition was taken of the importance of conservation considerations. I would like to think that there will be the appropriate consideration of those wider aspects of this legislation. One of the concerns that has been raised-and which has not been really addressed or amended in the legislation before us-is the fact that the recommendation to appoint additional commissioners will be made after consultation with the presiding members of the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Industries Assistance Commission. I know that those organisations have put to government that perhaps bodies such as the Australian Heritage Commission are appropriate to consult. In the perception of the way this commission will work I think this is very important. I would be interested if the Minister at a later stage could outline to the House why the Government has not been able to come to any agreement about the point put forward by the ACF. It is very important that the Government consciously goes back to conservation bodies such as the ACF, which have been quite responsible in recognising the need to reconcile economic considerations as well as the environmental considerations of many projects. So, they are not just ratbag type organisations which should not be listened to. I think that the Government should go back and allay the fears of the ACF.

Before concluding my remarks, I wish to raise two other aspects of the Bill. The first relates to section 20 which provides that at least two special commissioners will be appointed `unless the Minister otherwise directs'. Section 32 provides that the draft report will be prepared for public consideration, again with the proviso `unless the Minister otherwise directs'. I hope that where, in what I consider will be rare cases, the Minister will otherwise direct about those two aspects, that there will be a public announcement and that the public will be able to look at the reasons why the Minister so directed.

I know that many of my colleagues would have liked to have spoken in the debate on this legislation. But it is important in the bipartisan nature of the way we are seeking cooperation tonight to have this legislation proceed expeditiously through the House; so I will round off my contribution. As part of the second reading speech, the Minister also indicated that the Government will have the capacity under the Act to commission small-scale inquiries which might include only the chairperson. The worry about this is that people have thought, `How can we reconcile the notion of a small-scale inquiry with the fact that we have said that under the environmental protection and impact proposals there will still be the ability to look at small-scale proposals?' I hope that when applying this aspect of the legislation the Government will recognise that there is a fear that in some way we will subvert the environmental impact statement (EIS) procedures.

I know that many of my colleagues wish Justice Stewart and the commission all the best in the quite demanding task, but in doing so serve notice that the true test of the commission's value will be its ability to ensure that the community and especially the responsible members of the conservation movement perceive that it truly balances the expectations of conservationists as well as developers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, this debate is truncated again and I think that is to be regretted. The Resource Assessment Commission Bill was brought on last night at a very late hour and was again unable to proceed. I do not think that the very important issues raised here-given that the Opposition opposes this Bill-will get a proper airing. I think that is to be very much regretted.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal is to establish a Resource Assessment Commission to inquire into and report on the environmental, cultural, social, industrial, economic and other aspects of resources and their uses. It does not substitute for any existing legislation, such as the requirement for any environmental impact statement, and inquiries will be initiated and the terms of reference set by the Government. Several speakers have gone through this Bill. It is interesting to note that the Government's proposal is born out of conflict. There has been a great deal of conflict within the Government about this proposal. The most interesting first report that I saw about this matter was on 16 December in the Australian Financial Review in an item entitled `Ministers divided over handling land conflict'. At that stage it was revealed that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) were in extreme conflict over the direction the Government should take to deal with developmental issues.

What the Government has done effectively is to place between itself and the decision a new bureaucratic mechanism. In the Opposition's view, this bureaucratic mechanism is not necessary and only tries to delay and isolate Ministers from their allotted tasks of making decisions about the vital developmental issues of this nation. Of course, the Wesley Vale decision heightened the problem faced by the Government in this area. I refer to the statement made by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) about my remarks the other day. I think he took some liberty in that he took them out of context because what I was saying was that there is a problem here and that the Government's inability to make those tough decisions now means that it is looking for a mechanism to find its way through these issues. So, it has imposed this bureaucratic mechanism in a sense to let the commission be the lightning rod to draw the flak and the attention, so that the Government can sit back and say that it is acting on advice when it knows that this will add further to delays, which is something that the industry does not want and does not appreciate. We can see from the Wesley Vale decision that when we have delays, as we have had, ultimately projects will fall and fail.

It is interesting to see the reaction by Labor members of parliament to this proposal. I quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 November in which the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) said, `. . . the Government will lose votes as a result . . .'. Mr Milton is a member of the Government's environment committee and the environmental groups around this nation support Mr Milton and say that they do not want this Resource Assessment Commission. One of the reasons for this is that if the environmental movement does not want it, and those concerned with environment in the Labor Party Caucus led by Peter Milton and others do not want it, there is a great division within the Government. More and more the radical greenies seem to be saying that they want to have control of the total agenda. So, perhaps this commission is more about trying to control the conflicting views about land use policy within the Australian Labor Party than it is about trying to put something in place to address these very complex issues to which the nation and industry want and need answers. It comes back to the fundamental point I was making about the need to have a balance between environmental concerns and developmental needs. My point is that this Commission is born out of conflict within the Government, its inability to make decisions, and it is not the right sort of mechanism. It might, with its language, address the issues correctly but the mechanism which the Government is trying to put in place is not the correct way to do it.

If one looks at the Government's past record, the Bill is an admission of the ad hoc and confrontationist approach of the Government with regard to resource and land use issues. The Government's policy on these matters has been largely linked to the environment public relations machine, and an anti-development government department. This proposal is trying to offset that. It has been pushed very hard in the Cabinet, I understand, by Mr Kerin and Senator Cook, and it would appear that they have won. It is not a genuine attempt to address these issues. When one looks very carefully at what this Commission is empowered to do, one sees that in a sense it only sets up a formal mechanism of a Helsham inquiry. It does not have an ongoing staff. It has about three people, I believe, in the secretariat to be reposed in the Prime Minister's Department. It has a full time chairman. Justice Stewart had to be found a job somewhere and it seems to me that the Government is creating another Commission and putting him in there. That, I might say by way of an aside, is something we should be careful about in this Parliament. We keep putting judges into areas where they are not involved with the law per se. Now we have a judge in charge of a developmental, environmental assessment mechanism, and I do not know whether that is the best thing.

I return to the point I keep making about the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial and Research Organisation (CSIRO) and whether we ought to have a retired politician as chairman of it, or whether we should return to what we had in the CSIRO's heyday, when we had a leading scientist, David Rivett. We got far better value because those people had a detailed knowledge of what they were trying to do. We will see how Mr Justice Stewart performs in this role.

The scope of the inquiry is an interesting point which needs to be made. This body is required to inquire into and report on the environmental, cultural, social, industrial, economic or other aspects of resources and their uses. That is of concern on a number of counts. I have mentioned the problems we had with the Helsham inquiry which, as the member for Lyons (Mr Burr) indicated cost $3m. The scope suggested by this Bill is huge if one takes account of all the issues I have just mentioned. How far down the track do we go? Do we go to processing or assessment of marketing? For example, the Independents in Tasmania are promoting the idea of unbleached pulp. Where are the markets? One imagines that the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) would encompass all aspects from the resource end to the marketing end of any such inquiry. It might be a mammoth task.

To obtain the knowledge thought necessary on which to base a decision could be years in the making, putting us way behind our competitors. That is a point that needs to be made. It emphasises again the point that I make, in opposition to this proposal, about time constraints. We should not walk away from the difficulties which industry faces with ever-increasing competitive markets and time constraints. While we might be well-intentioned with the bureaucracies we put in the way, we need to look not at fast track systems that ignore issues, but at systems that certainly recognise issues and do not delay things. The second reading speech refers to `our incomplete understanding of complex resource issues', and the fact that we can rarely foresee all the consequences of the impact of human activity or their extent.

Forests and forest based industries have already been the subject of lengthy and detailed inquiries by the States and the Commonwealth. The first inquiry of the RAC is to be the forests and timber resources. We already have at the Federal level a Senate Standing Committee on Australia's Forestry and Forest Product Industries; and Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on pulp and paper, paper products and printing industries; and, of course, the Helsham inquiry. Only today we had Senator Sanders's proposal for a Senate inquiry into pulp mills, which has now been delayed because there is a CSIRO team which has just headed overseas to get such information. How many more inquiries are we going to be required to set up to be funded by the taxpayer to deal with some of those basic issues?
Taxation, royalties and pricing policies are key policy principles which need to be looked at to guide the Commission in resolving competing resource use claims. I quote from the Bill:

Resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources, having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations and an equitable distribution of the return on resources.

The latter surely involves a consideration of issues such as royalties, resource rent tax in the petroleum area-will it apply to fishing, will it apply to access to timber resources-all of which will now fall into the RAC inquiry. Its terms have not been properly described within the Bill. That gives me some concern and it ought to give industry concern as well. In some quarters industry has welcomed this Bill, but it has accepted it as a fait accompli. I do not think this proposal has been subject to sufficient debate or sufficient scrutiny by all those who will be subject to its inquiries.

The point we make in our amendment concerns the State's responsibilities. That issue has been canvassed widely. One would expect that in a Federation the roles and concerns of the States about land use policy ought to be considered. We do not say there is no role at all for the Federal Government on major land use issues. That is certainly my own personal view. This Bill does not recognise the role of the States and, being a Tasmanian in this place, everybody would expect me to draw attention to and give specific examples if that was necessary.

There is a comparison that this Bill is very tame, like the IAC legislation. Members will remember that the IAC grew out of debates years ago on the tariff industries, and has done very useful work. The Bill gives the RAC the power to determine whether a submission should remain commercial-in-confidence. By contrast, the IAC legislation gives the option to those making the confidential submission. Hence, again, the amendment that has been moved by my colleague the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) which I support. It is vital to the efficacy of the Commission that governments and industries are assured of confidentiality. It will have only a small permanent secretariat, and there will be no on-going analytical capacity or consistency. It will just be an inquiry mechanism. It will do an inquiry here and an inquiry there. All it does, as I said, is formalise the Helsham inquiry system.

I do not think it is necessary to talk about the Chairperson and the Special Commissioners, although I do have some concern about what evidence can be taken, and the long-term appointment of the Chairperson. Given that they will only be doing one or two inquiries here and there, it seems to me all that this is doing is setting up a full time Chairperson with a couple of secretaries, and an ability for him, whenever there is an inquiry, to bring on board special consultants. I do not know whether that will achieve anything. Surely if there is an issue to be assessed then an expert panel is immediately set up to address a specific issue, report and then fold up. I do not see any reason for these appointments other than the point I made earlier-that it is an effort to resolve internal conflicts within the Labor Party.
The final point I make is about striking a balance. Some things need to be remembered. The National Conservation Strategy for Australia (NCSA) states:

It follows that the strategy must have regard for the general economic climate, which has an important bearing on the speed with which the strategy can be implemented, and for the inability of Australia to isolate itself from the world economic system. It also requires a proper accounting of the costs and benefits to society.

The point is that much land has been locked up for conservation and other purposes without a proper accounting of costs and benefits to society. It should be beholden on governments who wish to alienate land, as it is on industry to develop land, to assess the impact of these proposals in the fullest possible way. In order to tackle the big environmental issues, the Government needs the money to fund a range of research. Australia's continued economic and social well-being depends on its ability to trade profitably with other nations, and in the long term our capacity to conserve our natural and cultural heritage will depend on our economic performance. Environmental issues relate not only to heritage, wilderness and quality of life, but also to standards of living, which depend on wealth generation. Those in the Labor Party Caucus ought to remember that, and those in the environmental movement ought to remember that. We are trying to strike a balance. For some time the balance between conservation and development has been steadily tipped in favour of preservation, and it is time for a balance to be struck.

I do not think this proposal does anything other than set up a bureaucratic mechanism. That does not answer the issues. It is an ad hoc approach. It puts in place another mechanism which industry will regret has been set up. As my other colleagues have said, we are opposing it because we do not think it does anything other than formalise some Helsham-type inquiries. The role of the States has been ignored, and another layer of bureaucracy has been set up. I think the ultimate political aim of this body is to put controls on the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr Richardson), that born-again greenie who is chasing votes in capital cities, who ignores regional Australia, who ignores the development and downsteam processing of the comparative advantages Australia has in minerals, in agricultural products and forestry products, and I think that is to be regretted.

The Government needs to address these issues in a more meaningful way. There are mechanisms already in place. I find it interesting that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, for example, could be doing much of the work that is proposed in this Bill. This is just a lot of flowery language that sets up something that is very small. It is nice rhetoric, but it does not address the issue. There are existing mechanisms. Why does the Government not utilise the CSIRO more to undertake these types of inquiries? The Government used the CSIRO at the last moment with the Wesley Vale proposal. Why is it necessary to set up this Commission? The Government is trying to put in place a bureaucratic mechanism to protect itself from making the hard decisions. There is no escape for anyone in this place from making hard decisions. The sooner honourable members on the Government side of the House recognise that they were elected to make the tough decisions as well as make good fellows of themselves, then the better off we will all be in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) suggested that the truncation of this debate was in some way going to affect Opposition speakers, but those who have had an opportunity to look at the speakers list will notice that four speakers from the Government side who put their names down to speak on the Resource Assessment Commission Bill, and none from the Opposition side, will miss out.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to establish the Resource Assessment Commission, which will inquire into and report on the environmental, cultural, social, industrial, economic and other aspects of resources and their uses. Three principles are outlined in the second reading speech. The first is that the approach to the issues of conservation and development should occur in the early stages of development. The second is that it is important to optimise the net benefits of efficient resource usage with regard to environmental considerations and an equitable distribution of returns. The third principle is that Commonwealth decisions, policies and management regimes should provide for additional uses of resources. It may be that environmental and developmental interests can occur concurrently or sequentially. In some cases, alternative uses or combinations of uses may be required.

It is important to understand how assessments will be made. The commissioners will have the prerogative and will be left to determine how assessments are made. Clause 8 of the legislation empowers the Commission to do these things as far as is practicable. Understanding that there are some very complex issues involved in resource recognition and usage, it is important to understand the limitations of our knowledge. We try wherever possible to increase our knowledge, and certainly it is to be hoped that the views of the Resource Assessment Commission will do that. Individual projects will still require an environmental impact study. Indeed, the specific project purpose and the specifics of any project will require that study to oversee it.

The Resource Assessment Commission will be able to look at industries, regions and issues as a whole. The debate on energy usage in this country concerns not just exploration for oil but public transport and its availability, the amount of energy used by public transport vis-a-vis private transport, car design, engine design, road construction and alternative transport opportunities. All sorts of other issues are involved, not just exploration for oil.

What is the position of the Opposition? As pointed out by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), it has done a backflip on this issue. In November 1988 the Opposition spokesman in this area, Senator Puplick, was saying that this represented a triumph and a victory for the coalition because the Australian Labor Party was endorsing a policy that they endorsed. Last night the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) came into this place, bounced up on the back bench and moved that the House decline to give the Bill its second reading. We expect this sort of yo-yo tactic from our opponents. Indeed, they have had a number of changes in leadership. But what do we find? Under the dry Howard leadership of two or three days ago, we found a pro-conservation position. Under the wet Peacock leadership, we find that this legislation is opposed.

The criticisms directed at the legislation, principally by the right honourable member for New England in his speech last night, were, firstly, that the Government is doing this to avoid making difficult decisions; and, secondly, the old perennial that the States were not being consulted and that this legislation would, in some way, cut across the rights of the States. He suggested, in some sort of a plea for more mining and exploration, that his would have a terrible impact on our balance of payments. Just for good measure, he put in a criticism of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the Government's commitment to science and technology. Indeed, the historic commitment of $1 billion that was announced earlier this week is a matter of some concern. I have been in this place asking questions on science and technology over the last five or six years. Every time I ask a question on science and technology and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) comes to the dispatch box to answer, honourable members opposite turn around and talk; they are uninterested. They do not have a sincere interest in science and technology and never have. When we make this historic commitment, we find them crying crocodile tears. The tragedy of the coalition's position, illustrated by the speech of the right honourable member for New England last night, is that it is so one dimensional and so conceptually flawed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I interrupt the honourable member for a moment. Would the honourable members on my immediate left either cease their discussion or lower the level of conversation? I do not think you realise that the microphones are picking it up. It is distracting to be hearing about Queen Bess when I am trying listen to the honourable member for Perth.

—I am glad you are listening so intently Madam Deputy Speaker. I cannot imagine why the right honourable member for New England, who is in here at the moment and sitting on the front bench, is not taking notice of what I am saying. The Opposition says that its concern is that the Government does not want to make decisions, but its principal concern is that the Government does not make decisions that it wants the Government to make. We can look at the monumental Franklin decision of 1983. It has now been shown that had the Franklin River been dammed it would have been environmentally negligent and economically unnecessary. We look at rainforests in north Queensland and find worldwide acclaim for that decision. We look at the decision concerning the pulp mill recently in Tasmania. How can one justify the environmental impact of 13 tonnes of dioxin a day going into the ocean? The Opposition is concerned because the decisions the Government makes are not the decisions it wants. Indeed, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said at the time, the joint partners in the proposal for the pulp mill in Tasmania believed that they could fulfil the environmental conditions, but they did not want to be required to fulfil those conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: It makes me very angry to look at land degradation, which is perhaps the greatest environmental problem in this country at the moment. The Liberal-National Party governments played a significant part in that development. For 20 years there were all sorts of incentives in Western Australia to clear trees. The experience in the eastern States could have told us very simply that that was the wrong philosophy. The problems at Jerramungup in the south-west of Western Australia are wind, water erosion, water logging and salination. All of those things have been brought about by clearing, which was encouraged by previous coalition governments. The information was available, we knew the effects, we had the experience overseas and in the eastern States, yet Western Australia went ahead with those proposals. They resulted in an environmental disaster. There is no point apportioning blame now, I understand that. What we have to do is get something in place to sort out the problem.

The second issue is that of States' rights. The Opposition has said that the States were not being consulted. No statement damns the position of the Opposition more than this one. It shows how completely bereft of philosophy it is and how lacking it is in the concept of conservation. This is everybody's problem. It is not just a regional or a local problem, it is the whole of Australia's problem. However, conservation and resource management goes beyond that. It is something that goes over oceans, beyond regional and national boundaries and over continents. Everybody on earth is involved in this issue. It is an issue that the citizens of this planet need to be concerned about. I really believe that the pettiness of the Opposition is indicated by its objection which says that the States will not get a chance.

If one looks at the greenhouse effect, and at the way in which debate on that issue is gaining momentum, one finds that it is something of immense consequence. The climatic change will impact on everybody's life if and when it occurs. How does one effect political change? There are very many obstacles in the way of political change and it is necessary that those barriers to action be broken down. The Resource Assessment Commission is one means by which that can occur. There is uncertainty about the greenhouse effect. Consider some of the scientific data.

As is the way with human nature, we think that, because it is uncertain and because we are unsure about it, perhaps it will go away. There is an unwillingness to believe that the worst will happen. The consequences are like something out of a science fiction movie. It is something far beyond our imagination, and there is no historical precedent, so we tend to deny that it will happen. Others say that we will adapt to the change when it occurs. But that will be too late. Yet others just want to be ignorant; they just do not want to hear about it. Then there are those for whom the problems are so alarmingly difficult that they shy away from them.

The greenhouse effect is just one example. Let me give an example of what is happening in Western Australia, the State that I come from. The State Government has introduced the Tree Trust. It is talking about the largest reafforestation program ever initiated in this country. One hundred and five million trees are going to be planted on cleared farmland. We will have integration of commercial tree cropping and existing farming for the first time; voluntary participation by farmers; the production of high-quality raw materials, and their export. What are the benefits of the Tree Trust going to be? They are going to be a large number of jobs in the south west of Western Australia; a new resource for the State's timber industry; the rebirth of water and soil resources in the south-west; and-perhaps the most important benefit-a dramatic decline in Western Australia's contribution to carbon dioxide and the greenhouse effect. But it will not matter a hoot what we do in Western Australia if the rest of Australia or the rest of the world or other areas do not follow suit. If trees continue to be cut down in Brazil and in Malaysia, it will not matter a hoot.

The Resource Assessment Commission is something that is beyond yesterday's men and beyond yesterday's views. I suggest it is something that looks to the future and that it looks at the big picture. Indeed, I believe that it is an approach which should make use of the scientific knowledge that we have. It needs to balance conservation and development, but it needs also to take a global perspective, not just a local or regional perspective, and it needs to plan long-term. This legislation should be supported by every honourable member. If Opposition members cannot support it they remain the spoilers and the destroyers. They remain the spoilers of rational conservation and development in this country. Indeed, they have no conservation credentials at all

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the debate, I thank honourable members for their contributions. A number of points were made during the debate. Again the position of the Opposition is that of a negative spoiler. We have heard no positive contribution from it. Honourable members opposite know, as we know, that there are very considerable arguments going on right across the length and breadth of Australia as to the way in which our natural resources ought to be developed. Those members are perfectly happy that these continue to be areas of confrontation and antagonism.

SPEECH.PARA: They are perfectly happy to see the kind of situation that developed at Wesley Vale in Tasmania. There, the responsibility was left to the State but finally, the Commonwealth, on the basis on scientific information provided by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), said that a situation could not be permitted in which, by virtue of a development which everyone conceded was important economically, 13 tonnes of organic chlorides would be pumped into Bass Strait every day. The effect of dioxin in Bass Strait, not just on the environment but also on the commercial fishing industry, was not a matter of concern to honourable gentlemen opposite. But the Commonwealth-not on the basis of some odd thought dragged out in the middle of a cabinet meeting, but on the basis of scientific evidence-said, `You will not do this to our environment'.

At that stage, partners to the consortium walked away. Why? Because they knew that if they accepted those standards in Australia they would have to accept them in other parts of the world. Of course, what we have here are apologists for the Tasmanian Government saying that any kind of economic resource development, no matter what it does to the environment, is good enough for them so long as there is a dollar in it somewhere along the lines. It may be good enough for them, but it is not good enough for this Government, and it is not good enough for the average right-thinking Australian, who is becoming increasingly concerned-this is true at every level of our society-at the way in which our environment is being despoiled.

The honourable gentleman opposite knows-it has been pointed out by my colleague-that the question of land use and land degredation is costing average Australian taxpayers $600m a year. In many of the most fertile regions of Australia the salt table is rising. Is that not a matter for concern? Is that not a matter that needs investigation? Is that not a matter that strikes at the very heart of our primary industries and of our capacity to continue to trade in areas that are so important to us? Of course, to the honourable gentlemen opposite-this apology for an Opposition-these are not matters of immediate concern.

What is the heart of this proposal that has caused such a stir in the mind of the former leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair)? Is there anything basically wrong with the creation of a structure which makes the proper development and use of our resources a subject of inquiry, rather than a subject of continual confrontation as one resource proposal follows another? It does not matter whether we are talking about the forests of Tasmania or the forests of East Gippsland. Is it not more appropriate in our society that the relevant interest groups be able to put their arguments before an independent body, which will have available to it a range of expertise and capacity so that all the arguments, including arguments that may come from the State Government or from the local region, can be examined? On the basis of the evidence, and calling upon the resources of our scientific institutions, that body will be able to point out to the community not merely the problems but, hopefully, the solutions. That is what this proposal is all about.

As my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has pointed out, this Opposition is not merely incapable of making an independent assessment of the issue; it has two positions. When this matter was first announced, it was welcomed by the relevant shadow Minister. Let me quote his words. He not only endorsed the proposal; he claimed that the credit for it lay with the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is when they had a dry leadership.

—It does not matter whether it is dry or wet, as the reality is that as far as the one relevant voice, the spokesman for the Opposition, is concerned it is a great idea but the only problem is that the Government pinched it from the Opposition. We had to come in here and listen to the arguments that were dreamed up by the former Leader of the National Party on what was clearly a very bad night, because all of a sudden the very proposition which had been endorsed and supported by the Opposition's shadow Minister was rejected. It is no longer worthy of the Opposition's support.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the arguments? All we are told is that this proposition imposes another level of bureaucracy. Another level of bureaucracy! Can a State obtain the services of a distinguished judge, someone who has established a reputation and a capacity not merely for judicial impartiality but also the ability to weigh evidence and produce an objective assessment, give him a small unit where he has available to him all the best resources within the Commonwealth and ask him to invite comment from industry and conservationists and produce a report? To the dullards opposite that is another level of bureaucracy. Honourable members opposite prefer the confrontationist approach. They prefer to see people chained to trees and society in torment. That approach is easier for them than to try to move to a positive resolution of these problems.

The fact is that this Bill will not delay proposals that must be considered. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) suggested that this is seen as an opportunity for the Government not to take hard decisions. Honourable members opposite may not like all the decisions taken by this Government from time to time, but the reality is that this Government not only takes hard decisions but also takes correct decisions. The only decision that the mob opposite is capable of taking on important issues is one on which leader it will knife at any particular time. That is its only capacity for decision-making.

The other argument brought forward is that we are interfering with the role of the States. Does anyone believe that the potential to pollute Bass Strait or the potential to destroy the Great Barrier Reef or some of the important wetlands throughout Australia is simply a matter for the State parliaments? Only these backwoodsmen opposite would argue that. We have long passed that situation. Of course the States do not have an explicit role. Their role is like the role of any other interest group that comes to this body and says that it either supports or opposes a particular proposal. They should then put all their arguments and use the resources available to them to support their proposition.

The reality is that the States have been consulted on this proposition and, basically, they support it. The States were informed of this process when it was first conceived and they were provided with good opportunities to be involved and to have all their views, whatever they might be, taken fully into account. Obviously, given the importance of their capacity to influence those decisions, their contributions will be of significant importance. This is not another layer of bureaucracy: it is the Government trying to reduce the area of conflict and tension in our society. They are not simple issues of black and white. If one visits a community where people have made their living by felling trees, one can understand the anguish and concern when they see their jobs in jeopardy and they see that they have no prospect of future employment. That must be a matter of concern. Equally it is a matter of concern to see that our forest resources are usefully and positively used.

We have a duty not merely to take hard decisions but also to look at what decisions are made and how they will affect the quality of the lives of people who work in the industry. That is being responsible. That is essentially the underlying philosophy in this proposition. The fact is that we have a negative Opposition which simply tells us that it is all too hard and produces these odd arguments telling us what it is against, but it never tells us what it is for. Honourable members opposite are for stabbing each other as hard as they can to see which particular member can obtain the most prominent position on the Opposition benches. That is what they are about. We watch with interest. They are here today and gone tomorrow. Some have been recycled and others hope to be recycled, but that is a matter about which I do not feel that I should delay the House at this time.

We on this side of the House are interested spectators. Nevertheless, I ask honourable members opposite to spare us of their mediocrity, the boorishness of their comments and the speciousness of arguments which do not go to the heart of this matter and do not seize upon the great issues which are involved in the examination of environmental issues in this community. Spare us that and get on with the knife stabbing. If honourable members opposite cannot make any decent contributions to this debate, it is better that they say nothing at all. We reject the amendment.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Sinclair's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 14, page 5, before paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
``(aa) the State or States relevant to the subject matter of the inquiry;''
(2) Clause 16, page 5, line 17, after ``Minister'' insert ``after consultation with the State Minister or Ministers relevant to the subject matter of the inquiry,''.
(3) Clause 29, page 8, lines 9-16, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:
``(2) Where a person appearing to give evidence at a hearing objects to doing so in public because the evidence is of a confidential nature, the Commission shall take the evidence in private.''.
(4) Clause 30, page 8, lines 36 and 37, omit ``the Commission''.
I wish to speak briefly to each of these amendments.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I advise honourable members that we are dealing with some complicated amendments. We want the opportunity to hear the right honourable member for New England.

—In case honourable members opposite do not know, if one is leading for one's side, one always has a prerogative to speak from the dispatch box. I am exercising that prerogative. I am sure that some honourable members opposite might like to see me here again.
—It is quite within the Standing Orders for the right honourable member to do so.

—While we have already expressed our opposition to what we see as this additional layer of bureaucracy and when in Government we will be determined to see the Resource Assessment Commission terminated, we recognise that there may well be support from this Parliament for the concept of the Bill. Therefore, I have moved four amendments. It might be that the Resource Assessment Commission can take account of some of the land use responsibilities that we believe are the responsibility of the States. It is for that reason that I have moved the first two amendments. Each amendment seeks a reference to the States before the Bill can proceed. For example, in clause 14, which relates to the selection of special commissioners, it is proposed that there should be consultation with the chairperson-or Mr Justice Stewart in this instance-of the Resource Assessment Commission. Clause 14 (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: the presiding members (however described) of the Australian Science and Technology Council-
or ASTEC-
and the Industries Assistance Commission;

It is also proposed that there should be consultation with the State or States relevant to the subject matter of inquiry. In other words, because the States have prime responsibility, as is the case in the first proposed reference on the forest industry, we believe it essential that the States should be consulted about the appointment of special commissioners. So too in clause 16 on page 5 of the Bill, where there is reference to the holding of an inquiry, we believe that it is not only a matter of the Government taking the decision but also of the States, whose interests are so vitally affected, being consulted-hence the second amendment.

The third amendment, which is made to clause 29, relates to the question of confidentiality. We believe it necessary that a person giving oral or written evidence that he believes to be of a commercial or confidential nature, should have the capacity to determine whether that confidentiality should be protected. What we seek to do in amendment (3) is to insert a specific provision which will say, instead of the present subclause (2):
Where a person appearing to give evidence at a hearing objects to doing so in public because the evidence is of a confidential nature, the Commission shall take the evidence in private.

We see that amendment as being one which will allow a commercial enterprise, believing the evidence to be confidential, itself to claim that confidentiality and then it will not be subject to the other provisions of this clause, which say that the evidence can subsequently be published. I believe that this is appropriate. It is important that there be an ability for industry, if there is a matter which affects the investors in the stock market or which for any other reason might affect the value of the company's shares, to have that confidentiality protected. Therefore, I suggest that this amendment to clause 29 should be made.

Similarly, in relation to clause 30, where we are referring to written evidence, the words `the Commission' should be omitted, because we are quite sure the position should be that, if the person who seeks to have the evidence removed believes that it should be so removed, then of course the evidence is given, it is given in private and there is no suggestion subsequently that the matter can then be published. I believe that that is only appropriate.

These several amendments are designed to ensure, in the first instance, that the States' interests are protected. Let no-one make any mistake: the States and the Northern Territory do have prime responsibility for land use. We see no reason for the Commonwealth to usurp that responsibility. It is for that very reason that in that second reading amendment, on which we voted a moment ago, we referred to our concern that that indeed was part of the purpose of this Bill. The second two provide an opportunity for the declaration of commercial confidentiality. Again, we believe that they are appropriate in the nature of this legislation.

Quite contrary to the assertion by the Minister at the table, the objective of the coalition parties in this measure is to try to ensure that developments will proceed. We do not believe that this device is the appropriate way to act. We see it rather as a device by the Government to avoid taking responsibility. We see it as an attempt by the Government to intrude upon the normal mechanisms yet another layer of bureaucracy. As I explained last night, it is in that climate that we believe that the Bill should not be supported. It would be our intention in government to revoke the legislation and to proceed to the proper course, where environmental impact statements, which are still required under this legislation, proceed according to that legislation, and then the development project can be allowed to be processed with expedition, without the considerable delay that we believe will be the product of this legislation.

We do understand why industry, in a climate where the Government has delayed so many projects, seeks the measure. But we believe that it is better for the Government to change its own approach than to have yet another layer of bureaucracy inserted. It is for that reason that I strongly urge this Committee to accept the four amendments which I propose on behalf of the coalition parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened, as has the relevant Minister, to the arguments put forward by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). These amendments constitute his thinking and the thinking of the Opposition on this matter. We do not agree with that thinking. He referred to the clauses in respect of the States. The States have a full capacity at any stage to be involved in this process. I have no doubt that they will be involved and that they will influence it.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of confidentiality, when it has been decided that any kind of tribunal is going to hear evidence in public, there are very few tribunals-certainly not in our court system-which would, simply on the basis of one person averring that in fact what he has to say is of a confidential nature, say that that is the conclusion of the matter. The process that is set out in the Bill establishes the availability of that person establishing it to the satisfaction of the Commission. If the nature of the confidentiality outweighs the public interest in the hearing of that information and it being averred to in public, then the Commission will decide that on the basis of the prima facie evidence that is before it. That is part of the due process of our legal system. It is part of the due process of our quasi-judicial tribunals. The Opposition certainly has not made a case why that general principle ought to be abandoned in this instance. For those reasons, we reject the amendments.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Holding)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:DEFENCE SERVICE HOMES AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill concurrently with the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. There being no objection to that, I will permit that action to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have yet another leg down the path of this long day, looking at defence or veterans' matters-on this occasion the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, or the Nambia Bill as it might well be termed, and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. After this legislation is dealt with the House will deal with the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill. This follows on the response to the Cross report, which we heard today, and the debate on that, as well as the now famous matter of public importance debate which took place earlier this afternoon in relation to veterans, war widows and ex-prisoners of war.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not opposed to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill; indeed, we support the Namibia component of that legislation which, of course, provides repatriation cover for our defence forces, now committed to and now in Namibia, carrying out their duties on behalf of this nation. I think it behoves the House to pause for a moment and dwell on the fact that there are Australians not only on the African continent but also in the Middle East and elsewhere carrying out their duties in relation to their service with the Australian armed forces, primarily in the peacekeeping role beyond Australian shores, and doing their work proudly, efficiently and effectively and at some risk to their lives. Last year a captain was killed in the Middle East in tragic circumstances. It is a risky business to be involved with peacekeeping forces. The Parliament should not underestimate that risk, and that is why there is clearly a need for the passage of the relevant requirements for repatriation cover, as provided for in this Bill.

I will not dwell on this particular aspect of the legislation at any length-the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who has so recently retired from the Navy, will carry that burden in the debate-because I want to focus on one or two of the other areas. But in so doing, I am reminded that Namibia is and has been a commitment which has evolved over many years. It is some 10 years since planning commenced for an Australian peacekeeping force to go to Namibia. Certainly, once the General Assembly approved without vote the spending of some $416m for the Namibia independence operation and the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG), the momentum sped up greatly for the forces to take up their positions in Namibia. Again it was not an overnight decision. Again it was developed over many months, if not years, in a situation of an early warning order circumstance.

Australia has known about it for a long time yet the forces actually left Australia without repatriation cover in place. It is regrettable that, while there is bipartisan support for that force and bipartisan support for the repatriation cover, the force was sent from Australia without that repatriation cover in place. It does not speak well for the planning of the Government and its legislative program that this has been the case in respect of this legislation, but certainly it now makes amends. I have double checked the fact that the repatriation cover is being backdated to the relevant dates in February to ensure that the coverage is from the date of commencement of the UNTAG operation and the Australian involvement with that operation in Namibia. So that backdating is particularly welcome.

I now move on to other sections of the legislation. There are technical and administrative adjustments to align the Australian War Memorial with other Commonwealth statutory bodies in relation to powers to make investments without ministerial approval and a series of other minor adjustments which were explained in the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). The Opposition has no objection to them.

I now turn to clause 11 (c) in the broader context of discussing it in the second reading debate. I want to spend some little time on it because it is a clause that really should not be in this Bill. It suits the Government's convenience to try to lock it in with the Namibia provisions, because the Namibia provisions will have a momentum of their own, and hope that the Parliament will blink and the Bill will pass through both Houses and, in it, clause 11 (c). What does clause 11 (c) do? It deals with the service pension eligibility of British or Commonwealth veterans who have come to Australia, have lived in Australia for at least 10 years and one day and have exercised their right to apply for a service pension. That circumstance was created incidentally by a previous coalition government, and it is interesting to reflect on a number of initiatives taken by the previous coalition government in repatriation, such as the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service and the creation of the modern Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Clause 11 (c) seeks to clarify the definition of eligibility of British or Commonwealth veterans by focusing specifically on the minimum condition of an award, that being a campaign medal, as opposed to the slightly broader definition of the Defence Service Medal, which would pick up many British veterans who in fact never left the shores of Britain until after the war when they came to Australia and may now have an eligibility following the ruling of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) quite recently.

I do not believe in legislation by stealth. I do not believe that this matter should be tucked away and not given any publicity for fear that more people will apply. The determining system has to face up to the responsibility of dealing with those applications. The Government must face up to the responsibility and the position does need to be clarified. That is the point of this clause. We have to realise-I have discussed this at length with veterans' organisations-that on any objective assessment of the circumstance arising after the AAT ruling there would be a more generous availability of service pensions for British veterans paid by the Australian Government than for Australian servicemen, should clause 11 (c) be deleted from the Bill.

I am very conscious, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you are one who falls in the category of having served his country in a time of war. Having served in the theatre of war in the northern parts of Australia, in fact you do not have an eligibility for a service pension. There are many people in that category. I know that it would be improper for me to dwell on the personal circumstances of Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is a case in point.

There are thousands of Australians who served their country in World War II but who have not qualified for a service pension. It is often listed on various priority requests. It is a matter which, in a perfect situation, the Government of this day and the coalition government of the next day would very much like to address. But in the situation facing this Parliament this night, the objective assessment has to be that the deletion of clause 11 (c) from the Bill would in fact create a circumstance which has not existed in the main in the past because the parent Act refers to campaign medals.

I will not delay the House by going into specific definitions but this is something that I have no hesitation in highlighting to the House because, right at this moment, the McGirr inquiry, which was appointed by this Minister and this Government, is looking into the entitlements of allied veterans, Commonwealth veterans and merchant marine personnel, many of whom are ex-prisoners of war and are yet to get coverage under the Veteran's Entitlements Act. That inquiry is due to report, under the official terms of reference, by 1 September this year.

It is with that in mind that the coalition has circulated an amendment to clause 11 (c) to provide simply a slight alteration not to the fundamental dynamics of the clause but to its commencement date to provide that it cannot be proclaimed in effect to a date some time after 1 January 1990, that is, after we have the benefit of the McGirr report. While McGirr has, in her role as the officer conducting that inquiry, given an indication in a letter, which was kindly made available by the Minister, that her inquiry may not deal with this particular aspect in any detailed way, she has given a further indication in relation to the possible contents of her report. We still do not have the benefit of that report. We still do not have the benefit of those recommendations. I feel quite strongly about this, and the coalition, having weighed this matter, feels that to provide this new tight definition in respect of a service pension, when the Government has its own official inquiry proceeding at this time, is an unwise approach, an unfair approach and, at the very least, the Government should accept our amendment so that the same Bill can go through the Senate without delay so that the Namibia repatriation cover will be adopted. It is a minor amendment in one sense. It merely alters the commencement date. I shall speak to it in a little more detail at the committee stage but, in the broad sense, that is what we are all about. We want the Government to give us the benefit of its report and the recommendations under the McGirr inquiry. This Parliament, this nation, deserve that much.

There is one other aspect of clause 11 (c) and I am wondering whether I can draw this to the Minister's attention. It relates to the provisions whereby, under the commencement date, the Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs cannot go back and take a service pension away from a British or Commonwealth veteran by virtue of the provisions of this legislation. What I invite the Minister to do is provide an assurance in response that not only is that not the intention of the Government but also in fact that there is no provision for the Minister to do that by virtue of the commencement date of the provisions of this legislation. That would help address our concerns in relation to the more detailed aspects of clause 11 (c). This is a tiny clause, tucked away in the small print of this Bill, but one which I quite properly draw attention to as this Parliament considers this legislation tonight.

The second Bill being dealt with tonight in this cognate debate, which the Opposition helped facilitate, is the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. This relates to the defence service home loans scheme which received a fair jolt this afternoon when the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) responded to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on personnel wastage in the Defence Force-the Cross report. Those who have the benefit of printed copies of the Minister's response and the creation of a new post-May 1985 defence service home loans scheme for enlistees ought to be aware at the outset that there is a typing error on page 8 of the report that was made available to the House as the official response. At first this created some confusion. The error is in the fourth paragraph under the heading `Post May 1985 Housing Assistance'. I raised it with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). He kindly pointed out that that has now been corrected. I quote the paragraph:
For example, a 16 per cent market rate would mean a subsidised loan interest rate of 9.6 per cent. Loan subsidies will be available for a maximum of 25 years. The maximum subsidy period is 20 years.
That is clearly in conflict. The word `subsidies' should have been deleted so that it read:
. . . Loans will be available for a maximum of 25 years. The maximum subsidy period is 20 years.

I mention that because there has been a lot of confusion about the defence service home loans scheme. We have had $215,000 paid to just one consultant. I acknowledge the Government's right to appoint a consultant and I acknowledge the capability of the consultant. But equally I query the size of the amount paid.

The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill will ensure that the portability provisions of the Defence Service Homes Amendment Act 1988 do not inadvertently include eligible veterans who have previously discharged their loans. In effect it will tighten up on double dipping. It will fix up problems relating to certain estate circumstances. It will broaden the definition of the term `annual report' so that the Defence Service Homes Corporation's reporting procedures are in line with other Commonwealth government procedures.

The Opposition unreservedly supports the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill but, as I mentioned, we will move an amendment to clause 11 (c) of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill during the Committee stage. We wish our Namibia United Nations Transitional Assistance Group troops every onward success in their important and dangerous work on behalf of this nation and the world. We commend the fact that the repatriation cover provisions have been backdated to the date of commencement of Australia's involvement in Namibia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Burke, the Chair will steal a moment of the House's time to make an observation, perhaps a plaintive observation. There was a time when the Chair would have been obliged to rule an honourable member out of order when the honourable member, in the course of his remarks, made specific reference to clauses and features of the Bill as distinct from making general comments on it. I make the observation simply to put it on record that the Chair is not being consciously derelict. The fact is that because of the insidious process of gradualness the practice has developed, both in Ministers' second reading speeches to Bills and, possibly as a consequence, in speeches by other honourable members of the House. Standing Orders in fact do not permit it but it has become practice. I just draw the attention of the House to that particular point without wishing to be critical of any particular honourable member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to the particular clause as we go along. I welcome the contribution of the shadow spokesman for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I accept the spirit in which he made his contribution and the spirit in which the Opposition on the whole is supporting the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. It is pleasing to see a joint approach, particularly in sensitive areas such as the entitlements of our defence forces when they perform these roles overseas. There are a couple of comments made by the honourable member for Farrer that I want to pick up and correct. Before doing so I make the point that the role of our peacekeeping force in Namibia is not only an important one but also one that all Australians should understand is fraught with difficulty. Our troops in Namibia will have to carry out their task with professionalism and sensitivity.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) said in his second reading speech, recent events in Namibia indicate that the transition to independence will remain fraught with difficulty. There have been armed clashes in the early stages of the implementation of the United Nations plan and some members of the Australian contingent have been called on short notice to man assembly points on the border. So there is a continuing danger. It is in that context that I want to make some comments, brief though they will be, on this Bill tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear hear!

—I thank the honourable member. His interest in veterans' affairs is well known to the House. He has a long family association in this area. He has played a great role in the Government in making sure that veterans are properly looked after. I know that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs appreciates his support on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer, in his contribution, picked up the fact that there are components of the legislation that have a retrospective application to the date when the forces set forth. Obviously that has to be. When Opposition members come into the House and make complaints about the Government's legislative program and the delays in it--

TALK.START.PARA: —We would never do that.

—As my friend knows, it happens from time to time. One has to remember that on the other side of the House there is often a deliberate obstructive process. This makes it difficult not only in the House of Representatives but also in the other place. We are seeing this occur again tonight. Last night we were here until midnight dealing with a whole lot of amendments. I have no doubt that this will go on. If the Opposition is going to come into the House-I do not in any way say that this is relevant in this particular case-and continually bring forward often spurious amendments, and also do so in the Senate, of course the Government's legislative program will be set back. So of course we will have situations where very sensitive legislation has to have retrospective application. To the Minister's credit, he has foreseen this situation. He has ensured that the operative date of the legislation guarantees those entitlements to the forces in Namibia. I commend him for this.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer mentioned his concern about clause 11 (c). I will not go into this in any detail because I know that the Minister will do so in his summing up and in later debate. It ought to be self-evident that at the moment we have a potential anomaly. Until the inquiry is completed there is doubt about the interpretation of these clauses. Therefore, it is appropriate that, at its earliest opportunity, the Government bring forward some definitions and incorporate them in this Bill. I have no difficulty in supporting clause 11 (c) as it appears in the legislation.

I also want to make a passing comment-again, I would not have mentioned this except for the fact that it was raised by the honourable member for Farrer in his comments-about the cost to the Government of the consultant to do the analysis of the transition of the defence services home loans scheme. The process that was gone through in transferring that operation to the banking sector had to be done professionally by the Government, and it had to be done and, more importantly, be seen to be done, without favour. We went through an analysis and a comprehensive program. I tell the honourable member for Farrer this: before entering this place I had quite some experience in the banking sector. When one gets professionals in the field, no matter where they are from, to do assessments of major corporate portfolios-we are talking here about $200m to $300m worth of portfolios-one's professional assessment fees can run to several million dollars. The fee that the Government has paid is, I understand, in the vicinity of $210,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member says that it is $215,000. I commend the Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for going out and making a good bargain. I do not have any difficulty with that point. It is not really relevant to this debate but I understand the context in which the honourable member for Farrer raised it. I do not want to appear in my support of the Bill to be carping or narkish about the contribution of the honourable member for Farrer. I respect his involvement in these areas. I make reference to a task that I have just completed with the honourable member. We worked together and I found his assistance and approach valuable and understanding. The task relates very much to what the Minister has done in this legislation in giving appropriate recognition in the formal sense and in the sense of entitlements to the forces in Namibia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the recent inquiry conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Community Affairs into the services required to provide ongoing support to Vietnam veterans and veterans of other conflicts post-World War II, which has led to our report After The March, we found a very real feeling about government promises, appropriate recognition and being looked after down the track. I well realise that the sorts of undertakings that were given to Vietnam veterans and veterans of Korea, Malaya and other places were not given by Labor governments. It was before our time, but it does not matter. The fact of the matter is that when our defence forces participate in these exercises, governments of all persuasions make guarantees. Having made those guarantees, all of us in this place have an obligation to make sure they are carried through, that they are recognised, with no argument, as first cab off the rank.

I commend the Minister on having got this legislation into the House. In the context of our other studies and the things that we now know, it is an important part of the morale process that our peacekeeping forces and the members of the Services performing these functions know that they are getting appropriate recognition and guarantees of support. It is even more important that future governments and future members of this House realise that down the road at some stage there will be a tab to be picked up as a result of this legislation. No government in the future should shirk that or try to back away from it. To the credit of our Government, the Minister is facing up to those responsibilities from previous conflicts. I commend the Minister on the way that he is doing that.
