I also signal in the House tonight that, certainly for the time that I am in this place, our forces in Namibia will receive ongoing recognition in terms of support in the public sense as well as in the form of the entitlements that this Bill bestows, and they will be guaranteed those entitlements down the road.

In winding up, I give my personal assurance and request that all members of this House understand that when we bring legislation like this into the House and when we make the undertakings that are given in these Bills, we must be prepared to carry them through and make sure they happen. I am sure that that is something that all members of the House are happy to guarantee tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), I welcome the opportunity to provide a very large measure of bipartisan support to this legislation. I say at the outset that I agree entirely with the comment of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in his second reading speech on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 that the Government has a responsibility to ensure that its service men and women, who will bear the brunt of the country's commitment, are provided with repatriation benefits appropriate to the dangers they are likely to encounter and the tasks they clearly will have to perform.

SPEECH.PARA: This is, of course, the situation in Namibia today. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) team is in the middle of that country's difficult transition to independence and has already had to negotiate a difficult operational situation with South African forces. Minefields on the Angolan borders now pose and, will continue to create, substantial personal danger. The Opposition, therefore, strongly supports the provisions of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill whereby Namibia and specified surrounding regions are declared operational areas for the purposes of the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 and, housing assistance under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 is provided to ADF members who serve with the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG) in these operational areas.

In conjunction, these Bills will provide disability pensions on the same basis as for other war veterans; age service pensions; free repatriation medical treatment; family cover in the case of resultant illness or death; and subsidised low interest housing loans and insurance. The Opposition particularly welcomes the starting date of 18 February 1989 for all benefits, as it was the day on which the first Australian representatives arrived in country.

That said, I must admit some disappointment that when the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill, covering certain entitled persons, was introduced into this place on 5 April it made no provision for our Namibian force, despite the fact that a substantial element of that force had already been in the country for some weeks. We had to wait another month for the introduction of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill before we saw evidence of the statutory coverage of benefits for the force. I accept that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) gave undertakings early in March that members of the ADF would be provided with those benefits. However, like the earlier comments of the honourable member for Farrer on these points, those undertakings are no substitute for provisions given legal effect in both Houses before the force departed. For practical reasons that may not have been possible in this case. Nevertheless, such casual treatment is indicative of a government that pays lip service to many veterans' benefits, as my colleagues the honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) put so well in this place earlier today.

The Government's record in those matters is poor, full of broken promises and adhockery. Bearing in mind the late hour and the need to complete today's heavy business program, I do not wish to delay the House unnecessarily. However, I must say that we see further evidence of what the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) referred to as penny pinching, miserable and narrow minded people with cash register hearts in the rhetorical, evasive and bureaucratic statement of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) earlier today in which he responded, very inadequately, in my view, to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, tabled in this place in November last year. In particular, I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who are at the table, to pages 17 and 18 of the detailed response to specific recommendations on service housing of that report which, in part, state:

After considering a number of options for home ownership assistance for post-May 1985 entrants to the ADF, the Government has endorsed the introduction of a new housing loan interest subsidy scheme. This scheme has been designed to assist in retention, and give members freedom of choice in their housing needs by enhancing opportunities to buy their own homes. It will come into operation on 15 May 1991 when the first of the post May 1985 entrants reach the eligibility point of six year service.

Eligible members will have access to a portable subsidised housing loan of up to $40,000 with an interest subsidy to the member of 40% of the market interest rate for housing loans. For example, this would result in an interest rate of 9.6% when the market interest rate is 16%.

In the interest of harmony between the pre-May 1985 and post-May 1985 entrants, and to address the retention objectives, those pre-May 1985 entrants who have not yet taken up their entitlement under the existing Defence Service Homes loan scheme will be given the option of taking up the alternative assistance provided under the new scheme after 14 May 1991.
The Government believes that this new scheme will provide a very strong incentive for members to remain in the Australian Defence Force.

Bearing in mind that our Namibian force undoubtedly contains a mixture of pre- and post-1985 entrants, can the minister for Veterans' Affairs assure the House that there is no conflict between the statement made by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel on housing proposals for the Defence Force generally and the more general Namibian provisions under the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill before us this evening? If there is no conflict, I rest my case. If there is a conflict, this needs to be resolved quickly to provide an incentive the Government so rightly seeks.

Finally, I have much pleasure in supporting the amendment of the honourable member for Farrer to clause 11 (c) of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill on the commencement date of the definition of the term `service pension'. In conclusion, I join my colleague the honourable member for Farrer in wishing our Namibian force a fruitful, safe and speedy completion of its very necessary task in Namibia under the auspices of the United Nations. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on both the pieces of legislation we are dealing with tonight. The first, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, makes provision for those troops who have gone to Namibia to assist in the transition of that country to independence. They have a particularly significant task and it is gratifying to know that the Government has moved quickly to ensure that the rights of these men are upheld when it comes to matters such as defence service homes, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give some examples to the House so that honourable members know the context in which the South Africans are operating. As far back as 1957, South Africa has refused to abide by the United Nations request to allow what was then South West Africa, now Namibia, to come under the trusteeship of the United Nations. For many years the people from Namibia strove to gain independence for their nation. They formed an organisation called the South West Africa Peoples Organisation (SWAPO).

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrorists!

—Many people have died for the sake of gaining independence. We get this knee-jerk reaction from the honourable member for Gippsland that those people were terrorists. It is interesting that people who are seeking independence-freedom-in their own nation are called terrorists. There is no reference to the South Africans who, with their jack boots, have kept the Namibians in absolutely slave-like conditions. The Namibians have been in conflict since then and thousands have died-people with limited weapons against the superior weapons of the South Africans.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1975, when Angola gained independence, this conflict was extended with the assistance of Cuban troops. Cuba, Angola and South Africa fortunately after many years reached an agreement in December 1988 which enabled the facilitation of the transition of Namibia to independence. The plan included a monitoring role for the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG). Australia has made its contribution which is a contingent of 305 engineers and support staff. Recent events have forced those Australian units to man assembly points along the border to enable the SWAPO irregulars to move back into Angola which has been a place of refuge. Unfortunately the South Africans have obviously been seeking them out and gunning them down as they sought to move out of Angola. This places the Australian troops in a situation of considerable peril.

It has been mentioned that the areas along the border are littered with mines. This imperils the lives of our troops. As we indicated, in 1979 the United Nations Security Council resolved that independence be established for Namibia. In 1979, through the Fraser Government, Australia made the initial commitment to send an Australian contingent to assist in the establishment of self-rule in Namibia. I think it is a sad commentary on the intransigence of the South African Government that it has taken so long to actually come to the table and agree that this very sad chapter in the history of the people of South West Africa, now Namibia, would be brought to a reasonably happy solution.

The first Australian representatives arrived in Namibia on 18 February 1989. Our responsibility is to ensure that the service men and women who will face these risks in Namibia and the environs will be provided with the repatriation benefits that are appropriate to the dangers that they are likely to encounter and the tasks that they will have to perform. These are provided under schedule 2 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

I commend the Government for the way in which it has met the responsibility of this nation so readily. If on their return to Australia service men and women find themselves in a position of being able to qualify under the normal conditions they will receive repatriation benefits. I will make an aside on this matter while the Minister is in the chamber. I would like the Minister to take this matter on board and raise it with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I have received correspondence over time seeking permission for Australian troops that were in United Nations peacekeeping forces to be able to wear the medals of the United Nations. I am very happy to be able to say that that appears to have been resolved with the Sinai troops. I hope that a principle can be established whereby whenever Australian troops are involved in peacekeeping forces they will automatically be in a position to be able to wear the medallions on their return.

In the short time that I have left I would like to make comments about the major amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act which were brought in during the last session. There have been a couple of minor anomalies. Honourable members will be aware that the new arrangements included the sale to the Westpac Banking Corporation of the defence service homes mortgage portfolio and the right to make defence service homes loans. This was worth about $1.4 billion to the Commonwealth. There are some very important aspects of this which we ought to bring to the attention of the House and to those listening to the broadcast who can take advantage of it. As we are aware, previously it took at least 10 months for someone to gain a defence service homes loan. This meant he had to take out a mortgage, which would have cost him about $2,500 then and possibly somewhat more now. This enables the transaction to be completed very rapidly, so that it is far more convenient. Not only does it save the Commonwealth money; it also saves money for those people who are seeking loans. It enables them to overcome the frustration which certainly occurred.

The main point of the Bill is that it deals with the issue of portability. We know that those people who gained loans subsequent to 9 December 1987 had the privilege or the right to take advantage of portability of their loans so that if they moved from one house they could take that loan with them. People who had a loan prior to that period have had to seek special permission from the Minister. There are set conditions for this; it is not that simple. The portability applies to those people who have received that permission. They have to receive that permission only once. Thereafter they do not have to go back to the Minister to seek permission if they wish to take out another loan. It is somewhat similar to receiving a new loan. It is a very logical thing. It means that those people who had that transaction subsequent to 9 December 1987 will be treated on a level playing field with those people who are seeking a loan for the very first time. This is a very sensible and sound measure. I commend the Minister for it. It is to be hoped that many thousands of servicemen will take advantage of it.

Finally, coming from a rural electorate there is a small source of frustration. The Westpac agencies have about 1,200 outlets throughout Australia. The post office agencies number 5,400. It certainly does cause some inconvenience to people living some distance from a Westpac bank. It can even cause problems in the cities, such as my own city of Ballarat. Certainly out on the plains and in the western districts it causes a certain amount of frustration and inconvenience. I seek the Minister's support in looking for some way to resolve that problem so that those people will not be frustrated. Most of them are aware of the fact that those people seeking home loans will be able to get a loan far more readily, which is a desirable thing. I would like to think there is some way in which we can overcome this inconvenience to people who previously had access to a post office outlet and who now do not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to get up to speak to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill because there is a lot of agreement on them. As the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and others pointed out, there are some distressing aspects of the whole subject of veterans' affairs. It is not all entirely the fault of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). He has certainly limitations in terms of the funding that he can get. He is in a similar situation to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who would love to be able to put into operation the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and all the financial projections that are supposed to take place in the implementation of that report but cannot because he cannot get the money from Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are discussing the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill because the Government did not get its original legislation right. Tonight we are allocating the Parliament's scarce time-apparently it is going to be a late night, although not as late as it was going to be-to considering minor technical amendments to clarify the intention of certain provisions of the original Act. Unfortunately, as has been mentioned by others, the one amendment that might have been appropriate to this Bill, an amendment to extend home loan benefits to our soldiers serving in Namibia-the Minister is probably getting tired of hearing about that-was overlooked by the Government in the drafting of the Bill and is now dealt with in supplementary amendment legislation included in this cognate debate. This amendment Bill, nevertheless, gives us an opportunity to comment on veterans' affairs and this Government's quite shoddy treatment of these men and women who served this country in war.

When a schoolyard bully gets caught out terrorising a smaller child because that child has been reduced to tears the bully usually responds by trying to comfort the crying child to silence him and to ensure that the adults coming to the child's aid find on arrival a caring senior who professes to be unsure of why the little one is crying or upset. As parents we have all witnessed the guilt provoked affection of a bully. In the statement brought down in April by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) we witnessed a similar guilt provoked and sudden affection for the veteran and pensioner victims of this Government's heavy-handed economic management. Just as in the schoolyard, neither the victim nor the witnesses to the victim's distress will be fooled by the bully's sudden turnabout and concern. We all welcome the decision to bring forward the indexation of veterans' affairs pensions. We welcome the indexation of guardians' allowances and orphans' pensions. We welcome the additional pensions for children of service pensioners and increases in pensioner tax rebates. We welcome restoration of the defence force retirement and death benefits scheme cuts.

These decisions do not make up for the harsh treatment dished out over the last six years to veterans by this Government-not necessarily by the Minister, who, I believe, does have a compassionate heart and is trying to do his best to help the veterans. As I said earlier, he is hamstrung by the lack of commitment of the Cabinet in this regard. The Government cannot heal the deep sense of hurt and cynicism that this Government's dishonourable conduct has engendered amongst veterans. As I said on another occasion, it is that hurt and cynicism which has generated movements such as Grey Power.

Let me recall the litany of cutbacks which preceded the April statement's compensation for veterans and war widows. Travel allowance was reduced by half to a flat 11.6c per kilometre in 1985, particularly affecting country veterans. There has been only a small increase since then. Subsistence allowance, including meals and accommodation, was reduced substantially for veterans, resulting in less government expenditure in this area of nearly $500,000. There has not been that big a dropoff in the number of veterans who are requiring these services. Under the dental scheme, four categories of treatment have been limited to a maximum of $300 annually, with no consumer price index adjustments on which I can find any information.

Totally and partially incapacitated pension criteria have been tightened up and veterans in the retirement phase of their lives are no longer eligible for TPI. Provision was made for termination of dependants' allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, and for no further increases in the dependants' allowance. War widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners with their fringe benefits, will no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

In 1986 a 2 per cent cut in Defence Force retirement benefit pensions was imposed, along with a six-week deferment from early November 1986 of the consumer price index related increases for veterans' pensions. From 1 January 1988, a $5,000-plus statutory patient contribution was imposed on veterans in nursing homes for war-related conditions. There has been a series of cutbacks in the list of drugs available under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, along with an increase in the number of drugs requiring prior authority. This has added greatly to the administrative burden.

That litany of cutbacks provided the context for the April economic statement, as it affected veterans. That list is the context for considerations of veterans' affairs legislation such as the Bill before us tonight. In passing, it should also be said that the very sorry conditions in our repatriation hospitals for staff and veterans alike-I include nurses-must be seen as part of the context for the consideration of the diversion of hundreds of millions of dollars to bodies like Qantas Airways Ltd, for example, because the Government will not get its social priorities right and privatise.

Before concluding my comments, I must express my immense respect-not in a pat- ronising way; it is genuine respect-for the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) for his efforts, best reflected in his speech yesterday on veterans' affairs, to draw attention to the needs and rights of veterans and ex-prisoners of war in particular. There is not a person in this building who was not impressed with that speech. I would refer anyone who wishes to understand what the veterans' affairs policy area is all about or wants to grasp the importance of all governments giving the honour and practical support our veterans are due, to the Hansard report of the contribution made by the honourable member for Reid.

The coalition supports the Bill. However, because it believes that the relationship between government and our veterans and their widows and children should be an honourable one, it takes this opportunity to stress the disappointing record of the Government in veterans' affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1989, I too take the opportunity to pay a tribute to my good friend the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) for his contribution yesterday. It was a remarkable performance which obviously affected honourable members who heard the speech in the House. Fortunately, I was able to see part of it in my room and I too was most impressed. Many members have paid tribute to the honourable member. We all realise that he is a man who over the years has been a fighter and a person who sticks by his convictions. I feel that both sides of the House have a great respect for the honourable member because of his contribution over the years to the work of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill is to replace section 19 of the principal Act. The purpose of the amendments would ensure that any previous assistance a person may have received under the Defence Service Homes Act 1988 to purchase or build a home is taken properly into consideration in determining the entitlement of that person to any further assistance under the Act for that purpose and the amounts and terms of any such assistance.

The other amendments in the Bill are mainly of a minor cosmetic nature and tidy up the Act in line with other Commonwealth legislation. As the excellent Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) point out in his second reading speech, since 9 December 1987 veterans, members and ex-members of the Australian Defence Force have been able to receive defence service home loans which are portable from home to home. This allows people who have taken out a defence service home loan after 9 December 1987 to have any amount still owing on that loan immediately before its discharge re-loaned for the subsequent purchase of a new home. The arrangement which applied in all cases before 9 December 1987 was that the approval of the Minister had to be obtained before the balance of the defence service home loan could be re-loaned to purchase a new home. This arrangement continues to apply to borrowers who received their loans before 9 December.

It has been argued that the Act does not require that ministerial approval be obtained for the re-use of the balance of a defence service home loan where the loan was discharged before the vesting of the Defence Service Homes Corporation's assets in the Westpac Banking Corporation. Again, it would appear from the earlier Act that any person who has received ministerial approval for the re-use of the balance of a loan must seek such approval again for any subsequent use of any remaining balance of the loan for the purchase of another home. As the Minister has indicated, neither of these possible interpretations was intended; hence the necessity for the amendments outlined in the Bill.

It would be folly for members on this side of the House to say that the defence service home loan scheme is a perfect scheme. It does have its warts. Certainly, the involvement of the Westpac Banking Corporation in the scheme has aroused the ire of many of the older ex-servicemen. They are particularly annoyed that their mortgages have been transferred without any attempt to obtain their consent to the transaction. I have taken up this matter with the Minister on a previous occasion. Whilst I have a deal of sympathy for their attitude, the legislation has been changed and for a new person seeking a defence service home loan there will be the distinct advantage of having just one loan-not two, with the second loan often being at a very high rate of interest.

However, I feel that Westpac is showing less sensitivity to the individuals who apply to it for a loan than was the case under the previous scheme. I have been involved personally with one or two cases which support that view. I support the point made by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), namely, that Westpac, with its fewer agencies, places the ex-serviceman at a greater disadvantage than was previously the case, when ex-servicemen could repay the loans at the nearest post office. Certainly, this nation has a prime responsibility for caring for those people who have served in the defence services of the Commonwealth. Recently, members of the House attended Anzac Day ceremonies, in all parts of the Commonwealth. We were able to participate in those ceremonies, to pay our respects to those people who made the final sacrifice on behalf of their country.

It is in the light of the debt that we owe to those who served in our defence forces that I commend the recently completed report by Major-General Morrison, a repatriation commissioner. This report examines the future needs of veterans and war and defence widows who are eligible for treatment under section 5 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The main recommendations are: first, Veterans' Affairs staff should be more accessible to veterans and war widows in the community by setting up regional offices in centres with high numbers of ex-service men and women; secondly, future health care arrangements for veterans and war widows should include social support as well as medical care, particularly for clients who are entitled to treatment and may be at risk of admission to nursing homes, hostels or long term hospital care; thirdly, the Department of Veterans' Affairs should be able to arrange, if it is medically necessary, services additional to those available under the home and community care (HACC) program run by the Department of Community Services and Health.

Major-General Morrison points out that at this time the majority of our veterans and war widows are over 65 years of age but that within the next 10 years the majority will be over 75 years of age. By the year 2000, 66 per cent of those who have a treatment entitlement will be 70 years of age or older. Many will be classified as frail aged. It is this latter group, the 70s and over, who have the greater need for health care. Major-General Morrison states that the quality of community care and other services for veterans and war widows in the community needs to be improved to meet the needs of those aged 70 years or more. Certainly as most of these veterans and war widows would be holding mortgages obtained before 9 December 1987 I trust the Minister will be sympathetic to those with a defence service home loan who wish to give up a house which has become too big for them to manage to move into a retirement village. With my knowledge of the present Minister, I am sure he will.

I would like to pay a tribute to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for its encouragement and provision of seeding grants for joint ventures. There are more than 250 of these joint ventures throughout Australia. They are aimed at providing services which help veterans and war widows remain independent in their own communities. They are projects run by ex-service organisations. These projects include home and garden maintenance services, wood provision, telelinks for blinded veterans, dog clubs, transport assistance for the frail aged and a friendly visitor service. I strongly support the continued seeding by the Department of those and similar projects. They all serve to assist those aged veterans and war widows to stay in their own homes.

I am pleased that the April economic statement included benefits for over 500,000 clients of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. These benefits include bringing forward the indexation of Veterans' Affairs pensions, introducing indexation of guardians' allowances and orphans' pensions, increasing additional pensions for children of service pensioners and increasing the pensioner tax rebate. I am also pleased to note that the 2 per cent discount on Defence Force retirement benefits and Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensions made in the 1986-87 Budget will restored to the advantage of many veterans.

Returning to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill itself, the amendments help to clarify the intention of the original Act. They are necessary to avoid the confusions that could occur if the Act was unamended. I therefore support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable members for their contribution to this very important legislation. It once again shows the Government's firm commitment to the defence forces and to the veterans of Australia. We never deviate from that commitment in any way. I thank the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) for his contribution. I give him the assurance that he sought; that it is not the intention to remove or take away pension entitlements established before the commencement of the campaign medal definition. He has that guarantee. I am very happy to give that assurance, and I am sure that the honourable member is happy with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). I will deal with their complaints in a second. I thank the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) for his very important contribution. I thank him for his great support for the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service report. He is a very dedicated member of this Parliament and is very dedicated to the veterans' cause. I thank the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) for his contribution. I will try to answer a few of his queries in a second. I will also answer a few queries that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) would like me to deal with.

Let me deal with the contributions of the honourable members for Groom and Macquarie in relation to what they were referring to as the cutbacks in the Department of Veterans' Affairs since we came into Government. I find it very hard to understand. We know that the honourable member for Farrer has to do his job on behalf of the Opposition, but we do not know how he can talk about cutbacks. When we took office the budget for Veterans' Affairs was $2.5 billion, as I have reminded this House on many occasions, and it is now $4.5 billion. There is no doubt about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In real terms?

—Yes. We have guaranteed that the veterans are looked after, and not just through the contributions that this Government makes. I do give a little credit to the Opposition. I challenge the honourable member for Farrer-and he knows that I have challenged the leaders of the various veterans' organisations-to prove to me where there is a better repatriation system in the world.
—Send me overseas and I will have a look.

—The honourable member wants to go overseas. Since becoming the Minister for Veterans' Affairs I have asked the Department to find out and tell me where there is a better system. There are only two countries in the world-and I am happy to admit this-where certain categories of veterans are looked after in a better way than happens here but overall these countries do not have a better system. Those categories-the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) mentioned this-are ex-prisoners of war in the United States of America and Canada and merchant mariners. Overall, our repatriation system is better. There is none better. I challenge any honourable member in this House to tell me where there is a better one. We would be happy to take any of the points they make on board. I can assure the House of that. Opposition back-benchers should be careful what they say after reading the paper the honourable member for Farrer gives them. I know they are all genuinely interested in the veterans' community, but they should be very careful what they say. I recommend that they read the speech made by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) today. She spelt out all of the things that this Government has done for the veterans' community. I recommend that the honourable member for Farrer also read that speech. He knows it is there. He knows what this Government has done, but we will keep telling him about them. I do not have time tonight to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to make some points about what the honourable member for Groom and the honourable member for Farrer said about the Government being slow in bringing this legislation to the Parliament. The Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife), as an ex-Minister in this Parliament, would know the time it takes to get legislation drafted and to get it into this Parliament. Their comments are a reflection on the officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. They have worked overtime continuously. I pay tribute to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and his staff for getting this legislation into the Parliament at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't done anything for years.

—But what did those opposite do about it? What did Malcolm Fraser do? This Government did it. We have put the legislation before the Parliament. The honourable member for Farrer should read Hansard and find out what his Party did. This Government has done it. The honourable member says that he is happy that the legislation is there, but he takes all of the good things that this Government has done on behalf of the veterans and misrepresents the true facts. He should not do that because he is a veteran himself and he should know better.

SPEECH.PARA: I take on board what the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), who is a Deputy Speaker, told me about the second reading debate. In responding I will try not to refer specifically to clauses. The honourable member for Farrer and the National Secretary of the Returned Services League (RSL) have questioned the timeliness of certain aspects of the Bill. I refer to a clause which defines the campaign medals which would grant certain persons qualifying service and therefore render them eligible for a service pension. The Opposition has indicated that it will move an amendment to defer the date of the effect of the amendment proposed. It argues that this action is based on the fact that the findings and recommendations of the current inquiry into the needs of Commonwealth and allied veterans-the McGirr inquiry-could very well impact on the proposed operation of this clause. The RSL has claimed that the clause would remove existing entitlements. The fact of the matter is that the clause would formalise an intention based on the understanding that no allied or Commonwealth veteran would receive greater benefits than Australian veterans. Under current legislation, this situation could arise and be a genuine cause for concern among Australian veterans. I will return to this matter when the Bill is discussed in committee. I thank all honourable members for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to highlight to the committee clause 11, which relates to the meaning of `qualifying service'. The Opposition has no objection to clauses 11 (a) and 11 (b), which provide the backdating of the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG) repatriation cover to 18 February 1989. Whenever the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is passed, that repatriation cover will be backdated to the date when Australian soldiers went from Australia to Namibia. The controversy relates to clause 11 (c). Much of it has been discussed in the second reading stage of the debate, so I will not dwell on it other than to raise three additional specific points. In his summing-up the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) said that it was not the Government's intention to take away an eligibility for service pension where already granted. I welcome that dimension of an assurance from the Minister, but it stops short of saying categorically that, in accordance with this legislation, the Government will not take away any existing service pensions granted to Commonwealth or allied veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: The hour might be late, but I think the Parliament must get its legislation right and there must be a very clear cut understanding. What I invite the Minister to do, in response to these remarks, is consider tightening up that phraseology. It is a phrase that leaves a measure of doubt. On the basis of legal research and because of the way it is constructed in the parent Act, I believe that there is no problem in this area. But it would be helpful if the Minister could make a more definitive statement and not just shelter behind the phrase, `It is not the Government's intention'. I hope the Minister will pick that up, and I will not delay the committee.

Secondly, in the two page letter which the Minister sent to the Returned Services League of Australia in relation to cause 11 (c) in this quite important Bill, he said in the second paragraph on page 2:

There are 6,620 British Commonwealth ex-service personnel aged 60 to 64 years currently receiving service pensions. If this number was to double as a consequence of admitting all holders of a defence medal, the cost would be in the order of $60m to $70m a year in service pensions alone.

I say to the committee that one cannot predict that that number would double in that circumstance. I could develop the reasons for saying that at some length, but I believe that that is a bold and bald statement. I highlight the statement to the committee because to put that sort of cost tag on the interpretation of the eligibility for Commonwealth service pensions may not be remotely accurate. The committee needs to know that. Finally, on the whole question of eligibility, the coalition accepts that it would be wrong to create a situation which is more generous to British veterans here in Australia than to Australian veterans. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) summed it up very well when he said that there are Australian veterans who have the return from active service badge given to them by the Government but who do not have an eligibility for a service pension. They wear the official return from active service badge, but they do not have an eligibility for a service pension. That needs to be highlighted. It is an anomalous situation. If the world were perfect and if resources were unlimited or more readily available, certainly the government of the day, whichever party was in power, would seek to redress that. But in the current circumstances the House is addressing an eligibility for British veterans and not Australian veterans, and that ought to be clearly understood in relation to clause 11 (c). It is merely British Commonwealth veterans who have come to Australia, established their 10 years residency and then applied for service pension. There is a need to clarify the definition.

The Opposition's amendment to clause 11 (c) provides no interference with the Government's program and the essential thrust of what the Government is on about, but does provide a holding up of the commencement date until such time as we have the benefit of the McGirr inquiry into the whole area of Commonwealth and Allied veterans' entitlements and the Merchant Navy. I believe the amendment is sensible. It is a very responsible approach without interfering with the fundamentals of the Government legislation and the desire of all sides of Parliament to get the repatriation cover for Namibia through. So in providing for this campaign medal definition in specific terms, I believe that the Government would be wise to accept the Opposition's amendment at this eleventh hour. I commend it to the committee and formally move the amendment standing in my name:
Clause 11, page 4, line 18, omit the note in italics at the foot of paragraph (c), substitute the following note:
``Commencement: A date to be fixed by Proclamation, not being a date earlier than 1 January 1990''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before dealing with clause 11 (c), I do not know what the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) is concerned about, but I can state quite categorically that the Government will not take any pension entitlements established before the commencement of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. That is what I said before.
—No, you didn't. This is much tighter.
—It is quite strange for the honourable member for Farrer not to understand. Once I give my word in this Parliament, the Opposition has got my word and the Government's.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not support the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition. Now that I am allowed to refer to clause 11 (c), may I say that the purpose of this provision is to define the relevant campaign medals. These form the basis for service pension eligibility of Commonwealth veterans who rendered service in a theatre of war within the country of their enlistment during the Second World War. The effect of not defining these medals would be to grant pensions to veterans who have not satisfied the basic standards of danger that apply to all other veterans. The honourable member for Farrer knows that. This would have the effect of placing an additional burden on the already constrained resources and would reduce the Government's ability to direct benefits to new initiatives for the veterans' community.

The need for the Government's amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act has arisen because, after nearly 15 years of consistent interpretations of the qualifying service provisions, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has recently overturned the established intention of the Act. The AAT has decided that a British defence medal constitutes a relevant campaign medal for Commonwealth veterans who served within Britain during the Second World War.

For the benefit of honourable members and of anyone else listening to the debate, I should like to give a brief background to the service pension. This is an income support payment to veterans, paid five years earlier than the social security age pension, in recognition of the intangible deleterious effects of a particular standard of service. For all Australian veterans, that standard requires that they have incurred danger from the hostile forces of the enemy. In 1975, when the service pension was extended to Commonwealth veterans, the requirement of incurred danger applied to those who had served outside their country of enlistment. The campaign medal criterion applied to home service was intended to imply a standard no less rigorous than incurred danger. I stress that this was a minimum standard.

The conditions of award of a defence medal, as the Opposition spokesman-the honourable member for Farrer-knows well, do not require the recipient to have incurred danger. There are many examples of service during the Second World War which would qualify a person for the defence medal on the basis of three years' home service in uniform. That would involve no real danger. The Government recognises that there may be deserving cases amongst defence medal holders, but that does not change the fact that the campaign medal criterion was introduced in 1975 to set a minimum requirement. The repatriation legislation then in force made it quite clear that Commonwealth veterans were to be eligible for service pensions on no less generous standards than the veterans of our own defence forces.

If the Opposition spokesman is concerned about the original intention of the legislation, let him address that concern in the proper way-by a new policy measure, which the Government would consider in the usual budgetary context. Instead, the Opposition spokesman brings forward a proposal to postpone-not omit, but postpone-the definition of `campaign medal'. He does not actually oppose the provision; he merely wishes to delay its application until the McGirr inquiry into Commonwealth and allied veterans brings down its findings later this year. In short, he wants to have two bob each way. In the meantime, he is apparently relying on the Repatriation Commission to continue to apply the existing policy, which he knows perfectly well is the correct one.

I adjure honourable members to support the provisions of clause 11 (c). To do otherwise would be to admit to service pension cover a group which has never been entitled to that benefit and offend all those veterans who are justly entitled to it. I do not believe that the honourable member for Farrer has his heart in this amendment. I think that he is putting it forward because he made a promise to some person or persons and is trying the Government on. He complained earlier tonight that we were not doing the right thing and that we were not hurrying enough with this legislation. Once again, that was putting a slur on the officers of the Department. I thank those officers, and I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and all the officers of his Department, for having this legislation before Parliament at this early time. I just want to say that the persons behind the scenes do a great job and sometimes they do not get any thanks. This legislation is introduced to protect the veterans' entitlements and I hope the honourable member for Farrer agrees to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I welcome the tighter assurance given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) at the outset of his remarks with regard to the existing service pensions granted for British and Commonwealth veterans. We were seeking a much tighter wording. The Minister has deleted the words `it is not the intention' and has replaced them with a categorical assurance. That much is welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, at no stage-neither today nor at other times-have I reflected on the officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Nor have I reflected on the consultant who carried out the $215,000 consultancy for the transfer of the Defence Service Homes Corporation home loan to the Westpac Banking Corporation. He is a very capable person and the Government required a consultant. I make that very clear to the committee. I proffered no reflection on those officers. But, equally, I have a right to stand up here and query the timetable for this legislation when the commitment with respect to the contingent with the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group in Namibia has been known about by the Government for a lengthy period. It has been in the planning pipeline for, not weeks, not months, but years, and here we are, three months after the troops have actually left Australia for Namibia, discussing their repatriation cover.

The coalition stands by its constructive amendment. The Government appointed the McGirr inquiry which is looking into this area. But, at the same time, the Government has introduced a clause in relation to the entitlements of British and Commonwealth veterans. We stand by our amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 deals with Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI) and provides for a transitional period of six years for certain State and Territory requirements, such as land usage, dangerous goods, licensing of activities and some other minor matters. The Opposition is not opposed to this Bill and does not proffer any amendments to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I speak I am conscious that, some time ago, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) had indirect responsibility in this area in the previous coalition Government, particularly with regard to the Mulwala Explosives Factory. He was the member for the electorate in which that magnificent facility was situated and he had ministerial responsibility for it for a period. I am also conscious that today the Mulwala Explosives Factory is in the electorate of Farrer. It is the subject of a major boost from this Government with regard to the decentralisation of facilities from Melbourne to Mulwala under the rationalisation of explosive factories of Australia or REFA project.

That is a welcome, sensible and constructive boost to decentralisation. Not only is valuable land being released in Melbourne and not only is it classic decentralisation which will provide more jobs in the economic region based along the Murray Valley, but also it is good value in terms of explosives production as there will be more efficient, effective and cost benefit advantages, through the green fields site which exists at Mulwala, for a very big expansion of the Mulwala Explosives Factory. Construction is currently proceeding at a price of some $80m. So it is a very big project.

Indirectly, it relates to the Bill before the House. I will not dwell on it at length, other than to say that, clearly, Australia needs to have maximum efficiency with its defence support resources. Of course, explosives are central to defence support. Equally, many of the other facilities detailed in this legislation play their part in maintaining the viability of the defence forces of Australia. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) will develop some aspects of this in the course of the debate on this legislation.

It is food for thought that, some 101 years ago, Australia first established a colonial ammunition company. Here we are, 101 years later, fine tuning the operation of Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd and providing in the legislation a sunset clause to ensure that the exemptions granted by this Bill will not run on forever but will be specifically terminated under the terms of the legislation before the House.

Clearly, no country can take defence for granted. No country can take its security for granted. I had the privilege of serving in our armed forces between 1966 and 1969. That left me deeply conscious of the need for defence logistics, the defence support resources of Australia, to be boosted and equated to the efforts of the armed forces to provide the capability that we require for meaningful security for our great country in a region which is becoming increasingly turbulent and volatile, as we have seen in events in recent months, especially in the South West Pacific but also elsewhere.

Just in passing, in that context I have to say again that I am concerned that we now have on the western edge of our region the fourth largest army in the world-the Indian army. That army had some notable successes last year against the Maldives and previously in land conquests. In fact, right now a very tense situation exists between the giant nation of India and the tiny, landlocked nation of Nepal. Honourable members might argue that that is only of passing interest to Australia and especially to this legislation. But I would say to the House that we have to take a much deeper interest in our region and in the emergence of India as a country with the fourth largest army in the world, as a military power of considerable consequence, and also in the relationship between India and its neighbours which in turn affects Australia and our relations with our neighbours. We have a situation of some delicacy between India and Nepal with the closing of trading posts and the like.

I will not detain the House at this late hour, other than to say that the Opposition is not opposed to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. We support its provisions. We commend the sunset clause aspect of the matter. We know that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) has certain sensitivities with regard to components of Australian Defence Industries in his electorate and was exposed by Senator Julian McGauran, I think, to certain views about the future of that factory. We welcome the contribution which he is about to give. I know the honourable member for Casey will listen to every word that he says in that regard. I reaffirm that the Opposition does not oppose this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill which arises from the transfer of defence production facilities to Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI). The Bill is a relatively straightforward piece of legislation and it provides in simple terms for an exemption for ADI from certain State and Territory charges which might otherwise apply.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this House the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) made a detailed ministerial statement regarding Australian Defence Industries. The changeover to Australian Defence Industries represents a massive change for Australian defence production facilities. It ensures that our defence facilities will be commercially oriented and global in outlook. They are changes which seek to make our defence facilities more competitive and better able to contribute to Australia's defence and industrial efforts. It should go without saying that the more competitive and outward looking our defence industries are, clearly the better their prospects for a secure and strong future.

Those who believe that our defence industries should have remained in the cocoon of a heavily subsidised and protected industrial structure should carefully analyse their thinking. Defence capacity and self-reliance are closely linked to industrial capacity. The more competitive our industrial capacity, the greater the contribution which can be made to defence self-reliance. This is perhaps a truism. However, some detractors of the ADI changeover fail to understand or to recognise this fundamental fact.

When the Hawke Government won office in 1983, the average level of local content in new equipment acquisitions was about 30 per cent. Because of the improvements in efficiency which have already been achieved over the past six years, that figure has now reached 59 per cent. In other words, improved competitiveness has enabled our domestic defence industries to double their contribution to new equipment acquisitions and equipment. With the changes brought about through ADI, coupled with the submarine project already under way and the forthcoming frigate projects, the Government confidently expects that a figure of 70 per cent local content will be achieved by the 1990s. I believe that this is a momentous achievement and is one which unfortunately tends to be glossed over or ignored by those who oppose the transfer to Australian Defence Industries.

Let me make a few brief points in tonight's debate about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. I have been very clearly, and continue to be, a strong supporter of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. When I was elected in 1983, that factory was underequipped and heavily subsidised and it exported very little of its product. Under this Government, new equipment, facilities and technical laboratories have been provided and the factory is considerably more competitive than ever before. As to the future, I hope that the factory can become even more efficient and market oriented and that it can provide the maximum possible level of job opportunities in the Bendigo area. In my view, these two objectives are not exclusive. Indeed, to the contrary; the more efficient the factory the greater its potential to win domestic and export contracts in the future, hence to improve its work load and employment levels.

It concerns me greatly that, at a time when virtually every major political party and economic commentator in Australia recognises the need for our economy to become more efficient and export oriented, a National Party senator, Senator Julian McGauran, has made repeated forays into the Bendigo area to express his vehement opposition to the changeover to Australian defence industries. Senator McGauran and some other members of the National Party, I believe, apparently want to return the factory to the bad old days of under-equipment, heavy subsidies, and an inward-looking marketing strategy. There should be no doubt about this-what they want in reality is to sentence the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and other defence establishments to a slow but inevitable death.

It needs to be clearly understood that Senator McGauran's recent sojourns into Bendigo have absolutely nothing to do with a genuine interest in the welfare of workers at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. In fact, quite the opposite is true. As those who follow political events would be well aware, the good senator has been desperately scrambling to try to maintain a place on a joint Liberal-National Party Senate ticket. The support of National Party members in central Victoria has been crucial to that effort and he has been prepared to say and do just about anything in Bendigo to gain publicity. In effect, the good senator has been prepared to say anything to try to save his political neck.

At this stage, one would have to say that his efforts have been somewhat unsuccessful. The senator's prescription for the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is a recipe for certain disaster. It comes, as has been noted in debates in this House before, from a gentleman who took seven years to complete his economics degree and whose former employment before being bankrolled into this place was as a bookie's penciller.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Standing Orders I take a point of order-
—There is a lot more. Do you want me to go on about Senator McGauran?
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo will kindly resume his seat. There is a point of order.

—I take a point of order that, under Standing Orders, it is improper for an honourable member to refer, in the terms used by the honourable member for Bendigo, to either a member of this House or a senator and I ask, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you deal with the matter accordingly.

—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo did impugn the senator's academic record, about which I have no knowledge. The point has been taken. It would speed things up if the honourable member for Bendigo would concentrate on the principal issues.

—In concluding my remarks on this Bill, I should take the opportunity to put to rest once and for all another of the myths being perpetrated by Senator McGauran. In his desperate splurge of publicity, Senator McGauran has recently claimed that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory would be swallowed up by the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to a question without notice which I directed to the Minister for Defence in this House on 2 May, I am pleased to say that the Minister made it absolutely and emphatically clear that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was not about to be swallowed up by the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory. Indeed, the Minister made it clear that, under this Government, the Bendigo Ordnance Factory has a strong and secure future. When it comes to the crunch, despite all the wet-eyed rhetoric of the Opposition parties about micro-economic reform, the fact is that they are hopelessly incapable of delivering. It is no secret that the National Party is the worst offender. While its members always talk of the need for change in general, for our economy to become more efficient and for us to sell more exports, they are always hostile to change in particular. Their prescription for the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and their diagnosis that the best that can be done is to return it to the bad old days of under-equipment, heavy subsidies and an inward-looking strategy, are a certain recipe for disaster. If it were ever implemented it would mean the inevitable closure of that factory. Despite the efforts which have been made to undo the changeover to Australian Defence Industries by certain elements in the National Party, I am certainly pleased to support this legislation and the general thrust of the changeover. It will ensure that our defence facilities, our defence factories are stronger, more efficient, more outward looking and more competitive in the future than they have ever been in the past. With those attributes they will be able to make a much greater contribution to Australia's overall defence self-reliance. I support the shift and I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the hour is so very late-or very early, depending on whether one is an optimist or a pessimist-I intend to keep these comments very brief.
—It depends on when you conclude your speech.

—Under more favourable circumstances, I would have a lot more to say in this debate but it has been a long day and a long week and I see no useful purpose in unnecessarily prolonging proceedings. I hope those on the 7 o'clock flights tomorrow morning will appreciate this gesture and some time in the future perhaps even reciprocate if and when the opportunity presents itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill constitute yet another example of the Government's poorly disguised privatisation program. I am advised that the preferred term is `corporation', but that is really just a euphemism for privatising that one adopts when one is not meant to be in favour of such a progressive measure.

As Bronwyn Young observed in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 4 April 1989, in the case of the Department of Defence, ideology appears to have given way to pragmatism. In any event, I think we all recognise that corporatisation or commercialisation or privatisation-call it what one will-is a necessity if costly and inefficient government departments are to be converted into productive, commercially-oriented, enterprises. Certainly, in the case of the former Office of Defence Production-now Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI)-the Opposition welcomes this move. Any measure which has the dual purpose of improving both the cost effectiveness and the efficiency of Australia's defence industries, and which has a good prospect of achieving those admirable objectives, deserves support.

There can be little doubt that our government-owned defence industries should be organised and operated on a more competitive, commercial basis, and that significant cost savings through increased efficiency and greater productivity will, or should be the result. In the last week we have seen the launching of HMAS Melbourne from the former Williamstown naval dockyard as a key element in the thrust towards attaining these higher levels of productivity and efficiency. We have seen the first major warship of any significance launched in Australian waters in more than 20 years. If that is the way defence industries are going in this country, then it is a very favourable result indeed.

Further benefits will include an improved ability and capacity for ADI to react more quickly and appropriately to the equipment and services needs and requirements of our defence forces and the creation of new and additional export opportunities. It is an unfortunate fact of life, and a major argument in favour of the privatisation process, that it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, for government departments to become commercially competitive. If they are to succeed in the marketplace, they must be structured and must be allowed to operate on a commercial basis.

The legislation now before the House is designed to assist ADI in its quest to become a commercially oriented, competitive and viable company. In fact, it gives it a six year breathing space by exempting it from certain State and Territory laws dealing with land usage, dangerous goods or licensing of activities, or which impose taxes, charges or rates-including stamp duty-and exempting ADI employees from State and Territory firearms licensing laws. Perhaps it could be argued that six years is a rather over-generous period, and ADI Pty Ltd may be spurred on to greater efforts to improve its performance if all privileges and protections were removed at an earlier date.

However, the task facing the new company is not a simple one. The challenges of turning part of a government department into a company are considerable and enormously complicated and there is no guarantee of success without some initial assistance. If ADI were to fail it would have serious implications and consequences in so far as Australia's defence preparedness is concerned. It must be remembered that its primary objective is to provide specialised support to the Australian Defence Force while at the same time pursuing a new approach free from excessive political control and unnecessary bureaucratic involvement.

However we understand that the Auditor-General has been excluded from carrying out his normal functions in respect of ADI, except where the Minister calls for his services. I do not think we are entirely happy about that. In the movement of this Bill from this place to the other place, we will re-examine our policy in this particular respect. The Opposition first indicated its support for these changes last year and nothing has occurred in the meantime that would alter our attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will be very brief. I would not have intervened but I want to respond to the last comment made by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), who has just spoken. I thank those who have participated in the debate, who were necessarily brief because of the time of night, for the contributions they made. The Auditor-General will be deeply involved in the audit associated with the Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI). Effectively a dual audit will be done. The desire to use a private auditor as well as the Auditor-General emerges from a concern in the company that it get the best business orientated audit advice. It is looking for a capacity from its auditors to get advice in a way that is clearly commercially orientated. The Australian Audit Office does not provide that but at the same time the check that is provided by the Commonwealth Auditor-General will be incorporated by his extensive involvement. It was pointed out to me-I will not actually vouch for this figure because it is one of those anecdotal things that one gets from one's departmental officers from time to time which are generally valid but one would not like to be the object ultimately of a censure motion for misleading the Parliament, given that the figure never did appear before me in written form-that whereas the headquarters of ADI has been pared down from 1,000 for the Office of Defence Production-ODP-to 35, the Commonwealth Auditor-General has 40 officials working in the establishment so that currently the Auditor-General beats the headquarters establishment. As I said that is anecdotal. I would not necessarily vouch for its accuracy in all respects, but I can vouch for the fact that the Auditor-General will effectively be doing an audit over the affairs of ADI.
—India and Nepal?

—India and Nepal do not actually relate terribly deeply to this Bill. Hopefully there will be no connection, direct or indirect, in any shape or form. I am not sure how it would break down to sales. I have made a number of statements recently that we need to take an interest in all military developments in our region. One of the most interesting features of the way in which capabilities are expanding in the area is that we will, at the turn of the century, confront a region in which the power balances will have changed dramatically. We will be looking at a situation not of classic east-west balance in a bipolar system, but something which is much more reflective of nineteenth century Europe in which there are a number of competing great powers. Probably one could readily discern five. The Soviet Union and the United States will still be significant. Japan, India and China and also some fairly substantial middle powers can be discerned.

SPEECH.PARA: We are beginning to lose the technological edge in military terms in this region inevitably, given the changing nature of the economies and technical proficiencies of the societies. One of the most unusual features of our Air Force, for example, is that it actually has a superiority in regional air force terms emanating from numbers as much as from technology. This is an unusual position in which Australia might find itself. Certainly one of the powers which will play a very significant role in this region will be India which is emerging as a very substantial naval power. We do not take an interest from the point of view of regarding it as a potential enemy, or whatever, but simply because prudence determines that we take an interest in all military developments in the region. The growing maritime capacity of India, along with substantial maritime capacities in China and a very extensive defence budget in Japan, is a matter which these days is of as much interest to us as the current state of Soviet-American relations. This suggests to us that we should sustain a very close interest in keeping in a reasonable state of repair those good relationships which we have established with a number of South East Asian states over the past 20 or 30 years. One thinks particularly of our friends in the five-power defence arrangements who, whilst increasingly calling the shots at the Malaysian and Singaporean end of it, are at the same time looking increasingly to Australia as the principal external participant in that operation.

That is an enormous deviation from the subject of the legislation, made possible under Standing Orders by the fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, that your appropriate liberal chairmanship permitted the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) to digress. I hope the initial point that I made on the Commonwealth Auditor-General has been reassuring to the honourable member for Casey. If he desires further briefing on that, I am certainly prepared to have departmental officers advise him on the status of the Auditor-General's role.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and the Restoration of Cultural Property

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and the Restoration of Cultural Property (Rome Centre) (ICCROM) established and when did Australia join it.
(2) When and where have there been sessions of the General Assembly and Council of ICCROM and at what level was Australia represented.
(3) When and where will the next sessions of the General Assembly and Council of ICCROM be held and at what level will Australia be represented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and the Restoration of Cultural Property (ICCROM) was founded by UNESCO in 1959. Australia became a member state of ICCROM on 26 June 1975.
(2) All General Assembly and Council meetings of ICCROM are held in Rome. Council meetings are held annually and General Assemblies bi-annually.
In 1977 the 9th Session of the General Assembly was attended by a counsellor from the Australian Embassy in Rome as an observer.

In 1979 the 10th Session of the General Assembly was attended by a member of the Australian Embassy in Rome and a European-based liaison officer of the National Library of Australia also attended as an observer.
In 1981 the 11th Session of the General Assembly was not attended by an Australian representative.
In 1983 the 12th Session of the General Assembly was attended by the Head of Conservation of the Australian Museum in Sydney.

In 1984 the 13th Extraordinary Session of the General Assembly was attended by the Australian Ambassador to UNESCO. (At this General Assembly Dr Colin Pearson, Principal Lecturer, Cultural Heritage Science Division of the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) was elected as an Australian delegate on the Council of ICCROM.)
In 1985 and 1987 the Council meetings of ICCROM were attended by the Principal Lecturer, Cultural Heritage Science Division of the CCAE.
In 1986 and 1988 the Council meetings and the General Assembly of ICCROM were attended by the Principal Lecturer, Cultural Heritage Science Division of the CCAE.

The next session of the Council of ICCROM will be held in Rome on 5 and 6 May 1989 and will be attended by the Principal Lecturer, Cultural Heritage Science Division of the CCAE. The 16th General Assembly will be held in 1990 and Australian representation at that Assembly is not known at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 6 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedures must be followed before homosexuals may enter Australia as immigrants and become Australian citizens.
(2) Have Members of Parliament sponsored such immigrants; if so, (a) how was this done and (b) how many has each Member sponsored.

(3) Has a program been initiated through which homosexuals may enter Australia and become Australian citizens; if so, (a) what are the details, (b) when was it initiated, (c) by whom was it initiated, (d) as a result of what demand, (e) how many immigrants, (i) from which countries and (ii) in total, (a) for each year and (b) in total, have entered Australia under the program since its inception, (f) how many applications does the Minister have before him now, (g) does the Minister personally approve all applications or is this done by his Department, (h) what public announcements have been made by the Government regarding this program, (j) what response has the Government had to the program since its inception, (k) does the program allow homosexuals into Australia over and above other immigrant groups or do these immigrants replace other groups and (l) does the Government intend to maintain, increase, decrease or stop the program.
(4) Is any provision made, or intended to be made, for testing homosexuals for AIDS before immigration is permitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) People are not prevented from migrating, nor from obtaining citizenship, because they are homosexual. The procedures applying to homosexuals are identical to those applying to any other applicant: that is, for migrant entry they must satisfy policy requirements for the category under which they are applying and they must meet health and character requirements; for citizenship they must meet residential and other requirements, including a good character requirement.

Homosexual relationships are not equated with marriages or heterosexual de facto relationships for migration purposes. An Australian citizen or resident cannot sponsor a homosexual partner under the criteria relating to spouses and heterosexual de facto partners. Nor is the homosexual partner of a principal applicant eligible for entry as the ``spouse'' of that person.

(2) An individual's sexual orientation is not a relevant factor in considering an application for migrant entry and hence may not be known to my Department, and is not recorded. Hence, while it is conceivable that people who are homosexual have been sponsored by Members of Parliament in accordance with normal procedures, the incidence of this occurring is not documented.

(3) There is no special program through which homosexuals may enter Australia and become citizens. However, once in Australia the homosexual partners of Australian citizens or residents may apply for the grant of resident status (GORS). In answer to the specific points of the question:

(a) Applications for GORS on strong compassionate grounds under Section 6a (1) (e) of the Migration Act 1958 may be lodged in Australia by homosexual partners of Australian residents and citizens who have entered Australia as visitors or temporary residents. Where an application for entry as a temporary resident on the basis of such a relationship is lodged overseas, it is submitted to the Minister for personal consideration.
(b) Applications for GORS on strong compassionate grounds based on a homosexual relationship have been considered personally by successive Ministers since September 1985.
(c) The first applications were considered by the Minister at the time, the Honourable Chris Hurford.

(d) Arrangements to consider applications of this kind were discussed by Minister Hurford with a task force made up of representatives of interested groups. The Opposition has been kept advised of these arrangements.

(e) The following table gives details of the numbers of GORS applications lodged, approved in principle subject to outstanding requirements being met, refused and lapsed or withdrawn since September 1985.

The country of origin of applicants year by year is not available from material at hand but a census of the nationality of applicants at the end of November 1987 gave the following results: Danish, 2; Swedish, 4; Dutch, 2; German, 11; Swiss, 2; Greek, 1; Spanish, 4; Yugoslav, 1; Canadian, 9; American, 30; Lebanese, 1; Argentinian, 1; Brazilian, 4; Chilean, 1; Colombian, 2; Venezuelan, 1; Zimbabwean, 1; South African, 6; Chinese, 3; Hong Kong, 1; Indonesian, 5; Japanese, 12; Malaysian, 30; Filipino, 16; Singaporean, 9; Sri Lankan, 3; Thai, 14; Fijian, 3; New Caledonian, 1; Papua New Guinean, 1; Vanuatuan, 1; British, 58; Irish, 4.
(f) the Minister currently has 4 applications before him; there are a further 121 on hand being processed by his Department before submission to him for decision.
(g) all applications are personally considered by the Minister.
(h) the subject has been raised previously in Parliament, in the Press and in other forums, and members of the public who have written on the subject have had full replies to their enquiries.

(j) members of the public who have written opposing these arrangements have generally been under the misapprehension that homosexual partners were being equated in migration policy with spouses. This is not the case.

(k) the small number of persons granted resident status under these arrangements has had no effect on the number of migrants approved for entry or the number of persons granted resident status on other grounds.
(l) these arrangements are expected to continue. The figures given in answer to (e) above indicate that the level of applications has remained constant at round 100-120 per year.

(4) All people applying to enter Australia as migrants or long-term temporary residents, and all persons applying for GORS, must undergo a thorough medical and radiological examination. If indicated by the doctor's examination or the applicant's history, a test for the Human Immuno-deficiency Virus (HIV) which causes AIDS would be required. Evidence of AIDS or and AIDS-related condition is cause for recommending rejection of an application.
